[See DirybapN.]) And Durba Ealayohimu AlbaEovu (assumed tropical:) The being sent to the war was appointed them and imposed upon them as an obligation. (Mgh in art. bEv.)
Daraba AlXRabakapa EalaI AlTRaAYiri (assumed tropical:) He cast the net over the bird: (Mgh:) and Duriba AlfaxRu EalaI AlTRaAYiri (tropical:) [The snare was cast over the bird]. (A, TA.)

Daraba AllRayolu biOaruwaAqihi (assumed tropical:) [The night cast its folds of darkness;] meaning the night came. (TA.) [And (assumed tropical:) The night became dark, or was dark; as appears from the following verse.] Homeyd says,

L.foreign: saraI mivola naboDi AlEiroqi waAllRayolu DaAribN

sense.s: (assumed tropical:) [He went on in his night-journey, like the pulsing of the vein, while the night was casting its folds of darkness over the earth, and the dawn had almost risen]. (TA. [See also DaAribN.]) You say also, Daraba Ealayohi HijaAbFA (assumed tropical:) [He put, or let down, a veil, or curtain, or covering, over him, or it]. (TA.) And Duriba bayonahumaA sadRN (assumed tropical:) [A barrier was set between them two]. (A in art. sd.) DarabonaA EalaI McaAnihimo [in the Kur xviii. 10] means (tropical:) We prevented their sleeping; (K, TA;) as though by putting a covering over their ears; a metonymical [and elliptical] mode of saying we made them to sleep by preventing any sound from penetrating into their ears, in consequence of which they would have awoke: (Zj, L, TA:) or Daraba EalaI McaAnihimo means (assumed tropical:) he poured upon them sleep so that they slept and did not awake: and one says also, Darabotu AlnRawoma EalaI Oucunihi [meaning (assumed tropical:) I poured sleep upon him by closing his ear]. (Msb.)
Darabati, AlEaqorabu, (A, K, * TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) The scorpion stung. (A, K, * TA.)

[Darabatohu AlrRiyHu (assumed tropical:) The wind beat it, or blew upon it; namely, herbage, and water, &c.] And Darabahu Albarodu (IKtt, K, TA) (assumed tropical:) The cold smote it so as to injure it; namely, herbage; and in like manner one says of the wind: (IKtt, TA:) and ADrbhu↓ Albarodu (A, TA) (tropical:) The cold smote it by its vehemence, so that it dried up; and in like manner one says of the wind: (TA:) and AlDRariybu AlOaroDa ADrb↓ (assumed tropical:) The hoar-frost, or rime, fell upon the land, so that its herbage became nipped, or blasted. (AZ, TA. [See also Dariba.]) And Duriba bibaliyRapK (assumed tropical:) He was smitten with a trial, or an affliction. (L, TA.)
Tariyqu makRapa maA DarabahaA AlEaAma qaTorapN (tropical:) [The road to Mekkeh, not a drop of rain has fallen upon it this year]. (A, TA.)

Daraba AlfaHolu AlnRaAqapa, (S, A, * Msb, K, * TA,) aor.
Dariba
, (TA,) inf. n. DiraAbN (S, A, Msb, K) and DarobN also, accord. to Fr, but this latter, though agreeable with analogy, is disallowed by Sb and Akh, (TA,) (tropical:) The stallion leaped the she-camel; (Msb, TA;) i. e. (TA,) compressed (A, K, TA) her. (TA.) DiraAbu Aljamali is used elliptically for vamanu DiraAbi Aljamali (tropical:) The hire of the camel's leaping the female: the taking of which, as also the taking of the hire of any stallion for covering, is forbidden in a trad. (TA.)

Daraba AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaIoCi (tropical:) He mixed the [one] thing with the [other] thing; (A, K;) as also DrRbhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taDoriybN: (TA:) accord. to some, said peculiarly in relation to milk; (MF, TA;) but [SM says,] this I have not found in any lexicon. (TA.) Daraba AllRabana fiI AlsRiqaMCi means (tropical:) Haqanahu [i. e. He collected the milk in the skin, and poured fresh milk upon that which was curdled, or thick, or upon that which was churned; or he poured the milk into the skin, and kept it therein that its butter might come forth]. (A.) In the L and other lexicons it is said that Darabotu bayonahumo fiI AlXRarRi means I caused them to become confused [or I involved them] in evil or mischief. (TA. [And DrRbt bayonahumo has a similar meaning: see 2.]) And Durbati AlXRaApu bilawoni kacaA means The sheep, or goat, was intermixed with such a colour. (L, TA.)
Daraba AlXRajaru biEuruwqihi fiI AlOaroDi [The trees struck their roots into the earth]. (A and TA in art. Erq.)

[Hence, the saying,] Darabato fiyhi fulaAnapu biEiroqK ciI OaXabK i. e. AilotibaAs; (S and TA in the present art., and in like manner, in both, in art. AXb, with the addition of ciI before AilotibaAsK;) (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a woman implanted, or engendered, in him a strain, i. e. a radical, or hereditary, quality, of a dubious kind: or the pronoun in fyh relates to a family, or people; for it is said that] the meaning is, such a woman corrupted their race by her bringing forth among them: or, as some say, Erqt fiyhimo Eiroqa sawoCK [i. e. EarRaqato, or, accord. to more common usage, OaEoraqato, i. e., implanted, or engendered, among them, or in them, an evil strain, or radical or hereditary disposition]. (TA. [This saying is also mentioned in the A, as tropical, but is not expl. therein.])

Daraba biAlqidaAHi, (S, Mgh, K,) and Daraba AlqidaAHa, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He turned about, or shuffled, (OajaAla,) the arrows, [in the ribaAbap (q. v.), in the game called Almuyosir,] EalaI Aljazwri [for the slaughtered camel]. (Mgh. [See HuroDapN.]) [And (assumed tropical:) He played with the gamingarrows; practised sortilege with arrows, or with the arrows.] You say, Darabotu maEa Alqawomi bisahomK (assumed tropical:) I practised sortilege with the people, or party, with an arrow; syn. saAhamotuhumo. (Msb.) And Daraba biAlqidoHayoni (assumed tropical:) He practised sortilege with the two arrows; one of which was inscribed with the sentence “ My Lord hath commanded me, ” and the other with “ My Lord hath forbidden me: ” a person between hope and despair is likened to one practising this mode of sortilege, which was used by the people of the Time of Ignorance when they doubted whether they should undertake an affair or abstain from it. (Har pp. 465 and 553.) One says also, Daraba fiI AljazuwribisahomK meaning (assumed tropical:) He obtained a share, or portion, of the slaughtered camel. (Mgh.) And hence the saying of El-Hareeree, waDarabotu fiI maroEaAhaA binaSiybK (assumed tropical:) [And I obtained a share of its pasture]. (Mgh.) And the lawyers say, yaDoribu fiyhi biAlvRuluvi i. e. (assumed tropical:) He shall take thereof somewhat, according to what is due to him, of the third part. (Mgh.) They say also,
Daraba fiI maAlihi sahomFA i. e. (assumed tropical:) He assigned [a share, or portion, of his property]: and thus is expl. the saying of Aboo-Haneefeh, laA yaDoribu lilomuwSaI lahu fiymaA zaAda EalaI AlvRuluvi (assumed tropical:) He shall not assign, or give, to the legatee, aught of more than the third part; the true objective complement being suppressed. (Mgh.)

Daraba biyadayohi [lit. He beat with his arms; meaning (assumed tropical:) he moved his arms about, or to and fro; brandished, tossed, or swung them]: you say, Daraba biyadayohi waHarRakahumaA fiI miXoyatihi (assumed tropical:) [He swung his arms, and moved them about, in his manner of walking]. (TA in art. jdf. [See jadafa.]) And Daraba fiI AlmaMCi [biyadayohi being understood after the verb] (assumed tropical:) He swam. (K.)

Daraba biyadihi UilaI XaIoCK (assumed tropical:) He made a sign, or pointed, with his hand, towards a thing. (TA.) And Daraba [alone] (assumed tropical:) He made a sign, or pointed. (K.) And Daraba biyadihi UilaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He put forth his hand towards such a thing, to take it, or to point, or make a sign. (TA.) And Daraba yadahu UilaI Eamali kacaA (assumed tropical:) [He applied his hand to the doing of such a thing]. (Lth, TA.) [And Daraba yadayohi fiI AlmaAli a phrase expl. to me by IbrD as meaning (assumed tropical:) He busied his hands with the property, in the giving, or dispensing of it.]

Daraba EalaI yadihi (assumed tropical:) [He struck his (i. e. another man's) hand; meaning] he struck, or made, the bargain with him; or ratified the sale with him: for it is a custom, when two persons are bargaining together, for one of them to put his hand upon the other's in ratifying the bargain. (TA, from a trad.)

And (tropical:) He prohibited, or prevented, or hindered, him, from doing a thing, or from doing a thing that he had begun: (TA:) and [in like manner] Daraba EalaI yadayohi (tropical:) he withheld, or restrained, him, or it. (K, TA.) And (i. e. the former phrase) (tropical:) He (the judge, A, Mgh, TA) prohibited, or interdicted, him from the using, or disposing of, his property according to his own free will. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA.)
Also (tropical:) He corrupted, vitiated, marred, or disordered, his affair, or case, or state. (A, Msb, TA.)

Daraba Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He turned away a person or thing from him [or it]; as also ADrb↓: (TA:) [or] Enh ADrb↓ signifies, (S, Msb,) or signifies also, (TA,) and (Msb, TA) so does Daraba Enh, (Msb, K, TA,) [the latter app. for Daraba nafosahu Eanohu,] (assumed tropical:) He turned away from, avoided, shunned, or left, him, or it; (S * Msb, K * TA; *) namely, a person, (TA,) or a thing. (Msb.) OafanaDoribu Eanokumu QlcRikora SafoHFA, in the Kur [xliii. 4], is said to mean (assumed tropical:) Shall we then neglect you, and not teach you what is incumbent on you? the phrase being taken from a rider's striking his beast with his stick when he desires to turn him from the course that he is pursuing: or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) shall we then turn away the Kur-án from you, and not invite you thereby to the faith, turning away ourselves from you? (TA.) One says also, Darabotu Eanohu SafoHFA meaning (assumed tropical:) I turned away from him and left him. (S and TA in art. SfH: see 1 in that art.) See also the saying Daraba OaxomaAsahu fiI OasodaAsihi voce xumusN.
And fulaAnN yaDoribu OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK: see voce ximosN.

Daraba binafosihi AlOaroDa, (K,) inf. n. DarobN, (TA,) [lit. He smote with himself the ground; and hence, (assumed tropical:) he cast, threw, or flung, himself upon the ground; app. often used in this sense; (a phrase similar to Daraba bihi AlOaroDa expl. before;) and hence,] (assumed tropical:) he remained, stayed, or abode; (K;) and so ADrb↓ (AZ, ISk, S, K, TA) as used in the phrase ADrb AlrRajulu fiI Albayoti (tropical:) The man remained, stayed, or abode, in the tent, or house, (AZ, ISk, S, A, TA,) not quitting it: (ISk, A, TA:) and [in like manner] Daraba bcanabihi, [AlOaroDa being understood,] (assumed tropical:) He stayed, or abode, and remained fixed. (K in art. cnb. [See also other explanations of this last phrase in a later part of this paragraph.]) And Daraba Alwatida bimaHalRi kacaA (tropical:) He remained, stayed, or abode, [lit., struck the tent-peg,] in such a place of alighting. (A.) And Darabati AlUibilu biEaTanK, [AlOaroDa being understood after AlAbl,] (assumed tropical:) The camels lay down [in a place by the water]: (S in art. ETn:) or satisfied themselves with drinking and then lay down around the water or by the watering-troughs, to be brought again to drink another time: (IAth, TA in that art.:) and [hence,] Daraba AlnRaAsu biEaTanK, occurring in a trad., (assumed tropical:) The people's camels satisfied themselves with drinking until they lay down and remained in their place [at the water]: (TA in the present art.:) or the people satisfied their thirst and then abode at the water. (K in art. ETn.)
Daraba bicaqanihi AlOaroDa (tropical:) He was cowardly; and feared; (A, O,* K, TA;) and clave to the ground: (O, TA:) or he was, or became, affected with shame, shyness, or bashfulness. (A, TA.)

yaDoribu lahu AlOaroDa kulRahaA [lit. He beats for it the whole land, i. e. in journeying,] means (assumed tropical:) he seeks it through the whole land: so says AZ in explanation of the phrase here following. (O, TA.) yaDoribu Almajoda (assumed tropical:) He seeks to gain, or obtain, glory: (O, K:) or he applies himself with art and diligence to gain glory, (yakotasibuhu,) and seeks it through the whole land. (AZ, TA. [See also 8.])

Daraba AllRabina, (A,) or AllRibona, (tropical:) He made [or moulded] bricks. (MA.) And Daraba AlxaAtama (tropical:) He made, fashioned, or moulded, the signet-ring. (TA.) [Hence one says,] AiDoribohu EalaI TaboEi hecaA i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Make thou it, fashion it, or mould it,] according to the model, make, fashion, or mould, of this. (IAar, O and K in art. TbE.) And hecihi Dariybatuhu AlRatiI Duriba EalayohaA, and DuribahaA, and Duriba alone, [for Duriba EalayohaA,] meaning TubiEa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) This is his nature, with an adaptation, or a disposition, to which he was moulded, or created; or to which he was adapted, or disposed, by creation]. (Lh, TA.) And Duriba fulaAnN EalaI Alkarami (tropical:) [Such a one was moulded, or created, with an adaptation or a disposition, to generosity; or was adapted, or disposed, by creation, or nature, to generosity]. (A.)

Daraba mavalFA (S, A, O, &c.) (tropical:) He rehearsed, propounded, or declared, a parable, a similitude, an example, or a proverb; said of God [and of a man]: (S, * O, * Msb, TA:) or he mentioned, or set forth, a parable, &c.: or he framed a parable: thus expl., the verb has but one objective complement: or the phrase signifies he made [such a thing] an example, or the subject of a parable or similitude &c.; and so has two objective complements: in the saying in the Kur [xxxvi. 12] waQDoribo lahumo mavalFA OaSoHaAba Qloqaroyapi (assumed tropical:) [And propound thou to them a parable, the people of the town] i. e., the story of the people of the town, [or make thou to them a parable, or similitude, or an example, the people of the town;] mvlA may be in the accus. case as an objective complement, ADHAb Alqryp being a substitute for mvlA; or ASHAb Alqryp may be regarded as a second objective complement [i. e. second in the order of the words, but first in the order of the sense]: the phrase is differently expl. on account of the different meanings of the verb Daraba; which signifies he described, or rehearsed; and he declared, propounded, or explained; and he made, caused to be, or constituted; &c.; accord. to some, it is taken from the phrase Daraba Aldirohama [q. v.]; because of the impression which a parable or the like makes upon the mind: accord. to some, from DariybN signifying “ a like; ” because the first thing is made like the second: accord. to some, from Daraba AlTRiyna EalaI AljidaAri [q. v.; because the mud, applied as a plaster, conforms to the shape of the wall]: and accord. to some, from Daraba AlxaAtama [q. v.]; because of the correspondence between a parable or the like and the object to which it is applied, and the correspondence between the signet and its impression. (TA, from the M and L &c.) yaDoribu QllRehu QloHaqRa waQlobATila, in the Kur [xiii. 18], means (assumed tropical:) God likeneth, or compareth, truth and falsity. (TA.) One says also, Daraba bihi mavalFA (assumed tropical:) [He made him, or it, a subject of a parable, a similitude, an example, or a proverb; he propounded, or framed, a parable, &c., respecting him, or it]. (TA.) And yuDorabu Almavalu likacaA [The proverb, &c., is applied to, in relation to, or to the case of, such a thing]. (Meyd &c., passim.)
Daraba lahu OajalFA (assumed tropical:) He specified, or notified, to, or for, him, or it, a term, or period. (Mgh, Msb. *)
Daraba lahumo TariyqFA (assumed tropical:) He assigned to them, or made for them, a way; syn. jaEala. (MA. [App. from a phrase in the Kur xx. 79, q. v.])

AlDRarobu as a conventional term of the accountants, or arithmeticians, means The multiplying a number by another number; (Mgh, Msb;) as when you say, [Daraba xamospF fiI sitRapK He multiplied five by six; and] xamosapN fiI sitRapK bivalaAviyna [Five multiplied by six is thirty]. (Msb.)

Daraba [is often intrans., and thus] signifies also taHarRaka [i. e. (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, in a state of commotion, &c.]: (K:) [see also 8, which is more commonly used in this sense:] or, so with strength, or force. (TA.) [And hence several phrases here following.]

Daraba AlEiroqu (A, TA,) inf. n. DarobN and DarabaAnN, (TA,) (tropical:) The vein pulsed, or beat, (A, TA,) and throbbed: (TA:) and Daraba, inf. n. DarabaAnN, (tropical:) it (the vein) pained, and was, or became, in a state of strong commotion. (TA.) And Daraba AljuroHu, inf. n. DarabaAnN, (S, A, Msb,) (tropical:) The wound [throbbed; or] pained violently: (A, Msb:) and so AlDirosu (tropical:) [the tooth]. (A, TA.)

Darabati AlnRaAqapu, (A, K,) or, as in some lexicons, AlmaxaADu, (TA,) (tropical:) The she-camel, (A, K,) or the pregnant
camel, (TA,) raised her tail, and smote her vulva with it, (A, K, TA,) and then went along. (K, TA.)
Daraba fiI jahaAzihi (tropical:) He (a camel) took fright, and ran away at random, (S, A, L, TA,) and ceased not to gallop and leap until he had thrown off all his furniture, or load. (L, TA.)

jaMCa yaDoribu biXarRK (tropical:) He came hastening [with mischief, or] in an evil affair. (A.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, When such and such things shall happen, (mentioning faction, or sedition, or the like,) Daraba yaEosuwbu AldRiyni bicanabihi, meaning, accord. to AM, (assumed tropical:) The leader of the religion shall hasten to go away through the land, fleeing from the faction, or sedition: or, as some say, shall go away hastily through the land, with his followers. (O, TA. [But see yaEosuwbN: and see also canabN.]) And you say also, Darabotu fiIAlsRayori, (Msb,) inf. n. DarobN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) I hastened in journeying. (S, * Msb.) And Daraba fiI AlOaroDi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Dariba
, (TA,) inf. n. DarobN (S, K, TA) and maDorabN (S, TA) and DarabaAnN, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He journeyed in the land (S, Mgh, Msb) seeking sustenance, (S,) and for the purpose of traffic: (Mgh:) [and Daraba AlOaroDa, as shown above, has a similar meaning:] or (tropical:) he went forth in the land as a merchant; (A, K;) or warring and plundering, (K,) or so Daraba fiI sabiyli QllRehi [meaning in the cause of God]: (A:) or he hastened through the land: (A, K:) or he arose, and hastened in his journey through the land: (TA:) or he went, or went away, in the land: (A, K:) or he traversed, or journeyed through, the land. (TA.) The verb is [similarly] used in relation to almost all employments: you say, Daraba fiI AltRijaArapi (assumed tropical:) [He travelled for the purpose of traffic]: (TA:) and UinRa liIfiI Oalofi dirohamK lamaDorabFA i. e. DarobFA [Verily I have to make a journey for the sake of, or on account of, a thousand dirhems]. (S, TA: but in my copies of the S, lI is omitted.) And Darabati AlTRayoru, aor. as above, (tropical:) The birds went, or went away, [or migrated,] seeking sustenance. (K, TA.)

Daraba said of time, (assumed tropical:) It went, passed, or passed away. (K.) And Daraba AldRahoru mino DarabaAnihi, or, accord. to one reading, mino Darobihi, occurring in a trad., (tropical:) The time in part passed; [the time pursued a part of its course;] or a part of the time passed. (TA.) And Daraba AldRahoru DarabaAnahu (assumed tropical:) Fortune, or time, produced, or brought to pass, its events: (IKtt, TA:) a phrase like quDiIa mina AlqaDaMCi. (S, L, TA.) And Daraba AldRahoru mino DarabaAnihi Oano kaAna kacaA wakacaA (tropical:) [Fortune, or time, brought to pass, among its events, that such and such things happened]. (A, L, TA.) And Daraba AldRahoru bayonanaA (tropical:) Fortune, or time, separated us: (AO, A, TA:) or made a wide separation between us; syn. baERada. (K.)
Also (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, long: (K, TA:) so in the saying, Daraba AllRayolu Ealayohimo (assumed tropical:) [The night was, or became, long to them]. (TA.)

And Daraba Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) It inclined to it. (TA.) [One says, yaDoribu UilaI AlsRawaAdi (assumed tropical:) It inclines to blackness, and UilaI AlHumorapi to redness, &c.: often occurring in the lexicons.]

DaArabahu faDarabahu, aor. of the latter
Daruba
: see 3.
Darubato yaduhu i. q. jaAda DarobuhaA [meaning Excellent, or how excellent, is his hand, or arm, in beating, striking, smiting, or hitting! a phrase similar to ramuwto yaduhu]. (K.)

Dariba, (IKtt, A, K,) aor.
Daraba
, (K,) inf. n. DarabN, said of herbage, (tropical:) It was marred, or spoilt, by the cold: (A:) or it was smitten by the cold, (IKtt, K, TA,) and injured thereby, and by the wind. (IKtt, TA.) And Daribati AlOaroDu, inf. n. DarabN, (assumed tropical:) The land was smitten by hoar-frost, or rime, and its herbage was nipped, or blasted, thereby: (AZ, TA:) and Duribat [in like manner] (tropical:) it (i. e. land) was smitten by hoar-frost, or rime; or had hoar-frost, or rime, fallen upon it. (S, A, TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence; and in two places in a sentence shortly after that.
DrRb AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaIoCi: see 1, in the second quarter of the paragraph.
[Hence,] AltRaDoriybu bayonu Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) The exciting discord, or strife, or animosity, between, or among, the people, or party. (S, TA.)
And DrRb, inf. n. taDoriybN, signifies also (assumed tropical:) He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, and roused to ardour, a courageous man, in war, or battle. (TA.)
DrRb AlmuDarRabapa, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He sewed (S, Mgh, Msb) [meaning quilted] with cotton (Mgh, Msb) the muDarRabap [q. v.]. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
DrRbt Eayonuhu His eye became depressed in his head. (K.)

DrRb, inf. n. as above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He exposed himself, or became exposed, (taEarRaDa,) to the snow, (K, TA,) i. e. the Dariyb [which signifies also, and more commonly, hoar-frost, or rime]. (TA.)
And He drank what is termed Dariyb, (O, K, TA,) i. e. the milk thus called, (O,) or Xahod [meaning honey, or honey in its comb, or honey not expressed from its comb]. (TA.)

3. DArbhu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. muDaArabapN (Msb, TA) and DaraAbN, He contended with him in beating, striking, smiting, or hitting; he beat him, &c., being beaten, &c., by him; (TA;) [he returned him beating for beating, blow for blow, or blows for blows; he bandied, or exchanged, blows with him: and] he contended with him in fight. (S, TA.) One says, DArbhu faDarabahu↓, aor. of the latter verb
Daruba
, (K, TA,) agreeably with the general rule respecting verbs signifying the surpassing, or overcoming, in a contest, (MF, TA,) He contended with him in beating, &c., and he surpassed him, or overcame him, therein. (K, * TA.) See also 6.

[Golius says, as on the authority of the KL, that DArb signifies also “ Coivit camelus; ” and Freytag, as on the authority of the K, that it signifies “ inivit camelus camelam: ” but in the KL it is only said that DaraAbN is an inf. n. of a verb having this meaning; and its verb in this sense, as is said in the S and A and Msb and K, is Daraba, which has been thus expl. in the first paragraph.]

DArb fiI AlmaAli and biAlmaAli, inf. n. muDaArabapN, means (tropical:) He trafficked with the property. (A.) And DArb lahu (A, Mgh, K) fiI maAlihi, (A, Mgh,) or DArbhu fI AlmaAli, (S,) inf. n. as above, (S, A, Mgh,) means (tropical:) He trafficked for him with his property [or with the property]; (A, Mgh;) because he who does so generally journeys in the land seeking gain; (Mgh;) app. from AlDRarobu fiI AlOaroDi [the journeying in the land] for the purpose of seeking sustenance: (TA:) and is syn. with qaAraDahu, (S, * Mgh, K, * TA, *) he gave him of his property for the purpose of his trafficking therewith on the condition that the gain should be between them two or that the latter should have a certain share of the gain: and accord. to En-Nadr, DArbhu is said of him who does thus and also of the person thus employed. (TA.)
4. ADrb AlfaHola AlnRaAqapa, (S,) and ADrb AlnRaAqapa AlfaHola, (A, TA,) inf. n. UiDoraAbN, (TA,) (tropical:) He made the stallion to leap the she-camel. (S, * A, * TA.)
ADrb jaOoXFA liOamori kacaA (tropical:) He disposed, or accommodated, and subjected, himself to such a thing, or such an affair. (A, TA.)
ADrb AlsRamuwmu AlmaMCa (assumed tropical:) The smwm [or hot wind] caused the earth to imbibe the water (OanoXafahu AlOaroDa). (K.)
ADrb linafosihi xaAtamFA (tropical:) [He caused a signet-ring to be made, fashioned, or moulded, for himself]. (A, TA. [See also 8.])
ADrbhu Albarodu: and ADrb AlDRariybu AlOaroDa: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

[Accord. to the TA, OuDoribonaA (there written ADribnA) seems to signify (assumed tropical:) We were smitten by hoar-frost, or rime: or our land, or herbage, was smitten thereby: thus resembling OujolidonaA and OuSoqiEonaA: but perhaps the right reading is OaDorabonaA: for]
OaDoraba Alqawomu, (K, TA,) inf. n. UiDoraAbN, (TA,) signifies (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, had hoar-frost, or rime, fallen upon them. (K, TA.)

ADrb Alxubozu (assumed tropical:) The bread (K, TA) i. e. the bread baked in hot ashes (TA) became thoroughly baked, (K, TA,) and in a fit state to be beaten with a stick and to have its ashes and dust shaken off. (TA.)

ADrb Eanohu: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph, in two places. [ADrb Eani AlOamori is expl. in a copy of the A as meaning EarRafa Eanohu, and in the TA, (probably from that copy of the A, as I have reason to believe that it was used by the author of the TA,) is expl. by Erf Enh; but the right reading is indubitably Eazafa Eanohu, with the dotted z; meaning (tropical:) He turned away from the thing, or affair; a signification given in the first paragraph: it is said in the A to be tropical. And ADrb Eanohu also signifies (assumed tropical:) He digressed from it; made a digression, or transition, from it; namely, a subject of speech or discourse: and particularly (assumed tropical:) he turned from it and retracted it.]
ADrb AlrRajulu fiI Albayoti: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
ADrb signifies also (tropical:) He was silent; he spoke not: or he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground: syn. OaToraqa. (S, TA.)

5. tDrRb [He beat, struck, smote, or hit, himself much, or violently; or several, or many, times]. One says, tDrRb biAlHaSaI [He smote himself much with pebbles], (K in art. kvH,) and biAltRuraAbi [with earth, or dust, as a man sometimes does in vexation]. (L ibid.)
See also 8, in two places.

6. tDArbwA, (A, MA, Mgh, Msb, K, in the S tDArbA,) and ADTrbwA↓, (A, Mgh, Msb, K, in the S ADTrbA,) and DArbwA↓, (K,) [They contended in beating, striking, smiting, or hitting, one another; and particularly, in fight;] they smote one another with the sword. (MA.) One says, AlEabodaAni ADTrb↓ biAlEaSawayoni, meaning The two slaves beat each other with the two sticks, or staves. (Mgh.)
8. ADTrb: see 6, in two places. The inf. n. is AiDoTiraAbN, of which the dim. is DutayoriybN↓, the T being changed [back] into t because the D becomes movent. (S and O in art. Tlq.)

[Hence, said of a thing, Its several parts collided; or were, or became, in a state of collision: and hence,] i. q. taHarRaka (S, Msb, K) and maAja; (K;) [but more significant than either of these; meaning he, or more generally it, was, or became, in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, disturbance, or disorder; was, or became, agitated, convulsed, or unsteady; struggled; floundered; tossed, or shook, about, or to and fro; moved, or went, about, or to and fro, or from side to side; wabbled; wagged; quivered, quaked, trembled, or shivered; fluttered; flickered; and the like;] and tDrRb↓ signifies the same. (K. [Daraba, also, is sometimes used in the sense of taHarRaka, as mentioned before.]) One says, Almawoju yaDoTaribu The waves [dash together, are tumultuous, or] beat one another. (S.) And ADTrb Alwaladu biAlbaToni [The child was, or became, in a state of commotion in the belly]; (A;) And fiI tDrRb↓ AlbaToni [which means the same]. (TA.) And ADTrb Albaroqu fiI AlsRaHaAbi The lightning was, or became, in a state of commotion in the clouds; [or it flickered therein;] syn. taHarRaka. (TA.) And ADTrb fiI Oumuwrihi He went to and fro occupied in his affairs for the means of subsistence: (Mgh:) and ADTrb, alone, signifies he sought to gain; or applied himself with art and diligence to gain; syn. Aikotasaba; (K, TA;) and is used by ElKumeyt with Almajoda as its objective complement. (TA. [See also yaDoribu Almajoda, in the latter half of the first paragraph.]) And ADTrb AlrRajulu (assumed tropical:) The man was tall, and therewithal loose, lax, flabby, uncompact, slack, or shaky, in make, or frame. (K, * TA.) And ADTrb Haboluhumo [properly, Their rope was shaky, loose, or slack; meaning] (assumed tropical:) their word, or sentence, or saying, varied, or was discordant: (K:) or their words, or sayings, [conflicted, or] varied, or were discordant: and so OaqowaAluhumo [their sayings]. (Kull p. 56.) And ADTrb raOoyuhu (assumed tropical:) [His opinion was, or became, confused, weak, or unsound]. (TA in art. rx.) And ADTrb Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) [His mind, or intellect, was, or became, disordered, confused, or unsound]. (K, in art. twh.) And ADTrb Oamoruhu (assumed tropical:) His affair, or state, was, or became, disordered, unsound, or corrupt; (S, K; *) syn. AixotalRa; (S, K;) [it was, or became unsound, or unsettled; as is indicated in the TA in art. zl:] and ADTrbt AlOumuwru (assumed tropical:) The affairs were, or became, complicated, intricate, confused, discordant, or incongruous; syn. Aixotalafat: (Msb:) and ADTrb AlOamoru bayonahumo (assumed tropical:) [The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them]. (Msb voce Xajara, q. v.)
ADTrb xaAtamFA (assumed tropical:) He asked, or ordered, that a signet-ring should be made, fashioned, or moulded, for him: (K, * TA: [see also 4:]) occurring in a trad. (TA.)
ADTrb binaMCF fiI Almasojidi occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) He set up a structure upon stakes driven into the ground in the mosque. (TA.)
10. AstDrbt (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) desired the stallion. (K.)
And AstDrbhu faHolFA He desired, or demanded, of him a stallion to cover his she-camels; like AsTrqh fHlA. (TA. in art. Trq.)

AstDrb AlEasalu The honey became Daraba; (S;) i. e., became thick; (A;) or became white and thick: (S, K:) the verb in this sense is similar to Aisotanowaqa in relation to a he-camel, and Aisotatoyasat in relation to a she-goat. (S.)

DarobN an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.; (TA;) i. q. maDoruwbN↓ [Beaten, struck, &c.]: (K, TA:) in some of the copies of the K, it is made the same as DarobN signifying “ a species ” &c.: but this is a mistake. (TA.) One says dirohamN DarobN (tropical:) [A coined dirhem]; using the inf. n. as an epithet, as in the phrases maMCN gaworN and maMCN sakobN. (S.) And hecaA dirohamN Daroba AlOamiyri, in which Drb may be thus put in the accus. case as an inf. n., [the meaning being hecaA dirohamN maDoruwbN Daroba AlOamiyri (tropical:) This is a dirhem coined with the coining of the prince,] which is the most common way. (L, TA.)

(tropical:) A light rain; (S, K, TA;) or so maTarN DarobN: (A:) diymapN signifies “ a lasting, or continuous, and still, rain; ” and DarobN, a little more than diymapN, or a little above this: and DarobapN↓ [as the n. un.] signifies a fall, or shower, of light rain. (As, TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A make, form, fashion, mould, or cast; syn. SiygapN. (S, TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A sort, or species; (S, K;) as also DariybN↓; (K;) and accord. to some copies of the K maDoruwbN, but this is a mistake: the pl. of the first is DuruwbN. (TA.)

Also (tropical:) A like [of a thing and of a person]; (ISd, A, K, TA;) and so DirobN↓, as related on the authority of Z; (TA;) and DariybN↓; (IAar, S, A, TA;) as in the phrase Dariybu AlXRaIoCi the like of the thing, (S, TA,) and fulaAnN Dariybu fulaAnK such a one is the like of such a one: (IAar, TA:) or DarobN signifies a like in stature and make: (IAar, TA:) its pl. is DuruwbN; (TA;) and the pl. of DariybN↓ is DaraAYibu (S) and DurabaMCu, this latter occurring in a trad., in the phrase, cahaba hecaA waDurabaAWuhu This went away, and the likes of him. (TA.) One says also Daroba qawolihi [meaning (assumed tropical:) In the like of his saying; referring to a saying in the Kur-án, &c.; a phrase similar to naHowa qawolihi]. (AZ, T voce Uino in several places.)

A man penetrating, or vigorous and effective; light, or active, in the accomplishment of an affair or of a want; (K, TA;) not flaccid, or flabby, in flesh. (TA.) And (K) a man (S, TA) light of flesh, (S, A, K, TA,) lean and slender. (TA.) The pl. is DurubN; or, accord. to IJ, this may be pl. of DaruwbN↓. (L, TA.)
The last foot of a verse: (K, * TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaDorubN and [of mult.] DuruwbN. (TA.)
See also DarabN.
[Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, explains it also as meaning Sour milk: but this is app. a mistake for SarobN, with the unpointed S.]
DirobN: see the next preceding paragraph.

DarabN (S, A, Msb, K) and DarobN↓, but the former is the better known, (K,) Thick honey: (A:) or white honey: (Msb, K:) or thick white honey: (S:) or, as some say, wild honey: and DarabapN↓ signifies the same: or a portion thereof: (TA:) DarabN is masc. and fem.: (S:) [for] it is said to be pl. of DarabapN↓, or a coll. gen. n., which is in most cases masc. [but is also fem.]. (Msb.)
DaribN: see miDorabN.

Also (tropical:) Herbage smitten and injured by the cold, and by the wind. (TA.) And (tropical:) Herbage smitten by hoar-frost, or rime. (TA.) And OaroDN DaribapN (tropical:) Land smitten by hoarfrost, or rime, so that its herbage is nipped, or blasted, thereby. (AZ, TA.)
DarobapN [inf. n. un. of Daraba; A single act of beating, striking, &c.: a blow, stroke, &c.].
See also DarobN, fourth sentence.

DarobapF waAHidapF means (assumed tropical:) At one time; once. (Mgh, Msb.) So in the saying, laA Mxucu maAliI Ealayoka UilRaA DarobapF waAHidapF (assumed tropical:) [I will not take what is due to me on thy part save at one time, or once]. (Mgh.)

Darobapu AlgaAYiSi, which is forbidden, is (assumed tropical:) The saying of the diver for pearls, to the merchant, I will dive for thee once, and what I shall bring up shall be thine for such a price. (T, Mgh, TA.)
DarabapN: see DarabN, in two places.
DaruwbN: see miDorabN: and see DarobN, near the end.
DariybN i. q. maDoruwbN↓ [Beaten, struck, &c.]. (K, TA.)
A tent-peg, or stake, struck so as to be firm in the ground; as also maDoruwbN↓. (Lh, TA.)
See also DarobN, in three places.

Also, (As, ISd, K, TA,) or Dariybu AlXRawoli, accord. to Aboo-Nasr, (assumed tropical:) Milk of which some is milked upon other: or, accord. to some of the Arabs of the desert, milk from a number of camels, some of it being thin, and some of it thick: (S:) or milk of which some is poured upon other: (As, TA:) or such as is milked from a number of camels (ISd, K, TA) into one vessel, and mixed together, not consisting of less than the milk of three camels: (ISd, TA:) or milk upon which other has been milked at night, and other on the morrow, and which has been mixed together. (TA.) [See also SariybN.]
And What is bad, of the kind of plants called HamoD: or what is broken in pieces, thereof. (K.)
See also miDorabN.

[Hence,] (tropical:) The person who is intrusted, as deputy, with [the disposal of] the gaming-arrows [in the game called Almayosir]: or the person who shuffles those arrows, or who plays with them; (AalRaciI yaDoribu
biAlqidaAHi;) as also DaAribN↓: (K:) or both of these epithets signify the person who shuffles those arrows (AalRaciI yaDoribu biAlqidaAHi); and he is the person who is intrusted, as deputy, with [the disposal of] them: (S:) the former is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Sb, TA:) and the pl. is DurabaMCu. (S, A.) You say, huwaDariybiI, meaning (tropical:) He is my playfellow with the gamingarrows (mino yaDoribu AlqidaAHa maEiI). (A, TA.)

And AlDRariybu is a name of (assumed tropical:) The third arrow of those used in the game called Almayosir: (K, * TA:) that arrow is thus called by some: by others AlrRaqiybu [q. v.]: it has three notches; and three portions are assigned to it if successful, and three fines if unsuccessful. (Lh, L, TA.)
[Hence, app.,] DariybN signifies also (assumed tropical:) A share, or portion. (K.)
Also (assumed tropical:) Hoar-frost, or rime; (S, K;) like jaliydN and saqiyTN: (S in art. jld:) and (assumed tropical:) snow. (K.)
And (assumed tropical:) The head: (K:) so called because often in a state of agitation. (TA.)
And i. q. XahodN [i. e. honey, or honey in its comb, or honey not expressed from its comb]: and EasalN DariybN honey becoming, or become, white and thick. (TA. [See also DarabN.])
Also Big-bellied, (baTiynN, [in some copies of the K baTon,]) [as an epithet] of men, (K, TA,) and of others. (TA.)

DariybapN A man, (K,) or anything, (T, S, * TA,) living or dead, (T, TA,) struck, or smitten, with the sword: (T, S, K, TA:) the p is affixed, though the word has the meaning of a pass. part. n., because it becomes numbered with substs., like naTiyHapN and OakiylapN. (S.)
[And also] The place [or part] upon which the blow, or stroke, falls, of the body that is beaten, or struck. (Ham p. 129.)

And Wool, or [goats'] hair, separated, or plucked asunder, with the fingers, and then folded together, and bound with a thread, and spun: (S: [more fully expl. voce saliylapN:]) and wool that is beaten with a mallet: (TA:) or a portion of wool: (K:) or a portion of cotton, and of wool: (TA:) pl. DaraAYibu. (S.)

Also (tropical:) An impost that is levied, of the poll-tax or land-tax and the like, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) and of [the tolls, or similar exactions, termed] OaroSaAd: (S, O, TA:) pl. as above. (S, A, Mgh, &c.) And (hence, TA) (tropical:) The galRap [as meaning the income, or revenue, arising from the service] of a slave; (S, K, TA;) i. e. Dariybapu AlEabodi means what the slave pays to his master, of the impost that is laid upon him: DariybapN being of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (TA.)

And (tropical:) A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like: [as though signifying a particular cast of constitution, moulded by the Creator:] syn. TabiyEapN, (S, A, K,) and sajiyRapN: (S:) pl. as above. (A, TA.) You say, fulaAnN kariymu AlDRariybapi [(tropical:) Such a one is generous in respect of nature]; and laYiymu AlDRariybapi [(tropical:) mean &c.]; (S;) and UinRahu lakariymu AlDRaraAYibi [(tropical:) Verily he is generous in respect of natural dispositions]: and xuliqa AlnRaAsu EalaI DaraAYiba XatRaI [Men are created of diverse natures &c.]. (TA.)
See also maDoribN.
DarRaAbN: see miDorabN.
DaAribN [Beating, striking, smiting, or hitting: &c.:] act. part. n. of Daraba [in all its senses]. (K, TA.)

A she-camel that strikes her milker: (S, K:). or one which, having been submissive, or tractable, before conceiving, afterwards strikes her milker away from before her: or [the pl.] DawaAribu signifies she-camels that resist after conceiving, and become repugnant, so that one cannot milk them. (TA.)

Also, and DaAribapN, (K, TA,) the former a possessive epithet [i. e. denoting the possession of a quality], and the latter a verbal epithet [i. e. an act. part. n.], (TA,) (tropical:) A she-camel that raises her tail, and smites with it her vulva, (K, A, in which latter only the pl. is mentioned,) and then goes: (K:) pl. DawaAribu. (A, TA.) And the former is like tDrAb, [i. e. tiDoraAbN↓, as appears from what follows,] expl. by Lh as meaning (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that has been covered by the stallion, [and app. that raises her tail in consequence thereof,] but respecting which one knows not whether she be pregnant or not: (TA:) or tiDoraAbN↓ signifies a she-camel recently covered by the stallion [and therefore often raising her tail]. (Mz, 40th nwE.)
The former (DaAribN) signifies also (assumed tropical:) Swimming, (S, TA,) in water. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
[In the nights of diversion he calls me and I follow him as though I were swimming in a deep water, sporting therein]. (S, TA.)
TayorN DawaAribu (tropical:) Birds seeking sustenance: (S, A, TA:) or birds traversing the land, [or migrating,] in search of sustenance. (L, TA.)
See also DariybN.

DaAribN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A dark night: (K:) or a night of which the darkness extends to the right and left, and fills the world. (S, O. [So in my copies of the S and in the O and TA: but accord. to Golius, as from the S, “ yet not filling the air. ”]) See the verse of Homeyd cited in the first paragraph. [J cites as an ex. of the last of the meanings expl. above, and so does Sgh in the O, the verse in the sentence here next following.]
(assumed tropical:) Anything long: applied in this sense to a night: thus in the following verse:
(assumed tropical:) [And that she helped me in lifting and putting on the loads, beneath the darkness of a long night, with a plump fore arm and a hand dyed with hinnà]. (TA.)

(assumed tropical:) A place, (S,) or a depressed place, (K, TA,) and a valley, (TA,) in which are trees. (S, K, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A piece of rugged ground extending in an oblong form in a plain, or soft, tract. (K, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) The like of a raHobap in a valley [app. meaning where the water flows into it from its two sides: see art. rHb]: pl. DawaAribu. (K.)
DaAruwbN [an irregular instrumental noun, like TaAHuwnN and some other words of the same measure,] (tropical:) A snare for catching birds. (A, TA.)
DutayoriybN dim. of AiDoTiraAbN, inf. n. of 8, q. v.
tiDoraAbN: see DaAribN, former half, in two places.
maDorabN is an inf. n. (Ham p. 129.) [See the sentence explaining the phrase Daraba fiI AlOaroDi; and also the sentence next following it, towards the close of the first paragraph.]
And it is also a noun of place [and of time, like maDoribN, which is the regular form]. (Ham ibid.) See the next paragraph, in five places.
maDoribN [and maDorabN↓, q. v.,] A place, or time, [the latter, as is said in the explanation of a phrase mentioned in what follows,] of beating, striking, smiting, or hitting:
and also, (assumed tropical:) a place, or time, of journeying. (KL.)
maDoribu AlZRaribaAni means (assumed tropical:) The line, or long mark, upon the face of the animal called ZrbAn [as though it were a place upon which it had been struck]. (TA in art. Zrb, q. v.)
And maDoribN, (assumed tropical:) A place where a tent is pitched, or set up. (Msb.)
See also miDorabN.

Also, (thus in the TA in art. swf, as from the A,) or maDorabN↓, (thus in a copy of the A in the present art.,) (tropical:) i. q. masaAfapN [meaning A space, or tract, or an extent, over which one journeys; as being a place of beating the ground]: so in the saying, baEiydN bayonahumo maDorabN↓ [or maDoribN, i. e. (tropical:) Between them is a far-extending space to be traversed]. (A.)

[maDoribu EasalapK is a euphemism for (assumed tropical:) The place of injection of sperma: and hence it means (assumed tropical:) the source from which one springs; origin, ancestry, or parentage; &c.] One says, maA OaEorifu lahu maDoriba EasalapK (S, A) meaning OaEoraAqahu [i. e. (tropical:) I know not the sources (or the source) from which he has sprung; or his ancestry, or parentage]: (S:) or maA yuEorafu lahu maDoribu EasalapK (tropical:) No source or origin [or parentage], nor people, nor ancestor or father, nor nobility, pertaining to him, is know. (M, K, TA.) And maA lifulaAnK maDoribu EasalapK (S, A, in the latter lizayodK,) i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one has no source] of kindred (nasab), nor of cattle or property (maAl). (S.) And UinRahu lakariymu AlmaDoribi (tropical:) [Verily he is generous in respect of origin]. (A, TA.) [See also DariybapN.]

One says also, Oatati AlnRaAqapu EalaI maDoribihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) The she-camel arrived at the time [of year] of her being leaped by the stallion; making the time to be like the place. (S.)

maDoribN, (S, A, O, and so in the M in art. rm,) or maDorabN↓, (K, * TA,) with fet-h to the m, (K, TA,) and to the r also, (TA,) [but this is app. a mistake, as the weight of authority is in favour of the former,] (assumed tropical:) A bone in which is marrow: (S, O, K:) or a bone that is broken and from which marrow is extracted [or sought to be extracted]. (M in art. rm.) One says, of a sheep or goat, (S, A,) that is emaciated, (S,) maA yurimRu minohaA maDoribN (tropical:) [Not a bone of her that is broken for its marrow contains any marrow]; i. e. when a bone of her is broken, no marrow
will be found in it. (S, A.)

And maDoribN (S, Msb, K) and maDorabN↓ (Msb, K) and maDoribapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and maDorabapN↓ (Msb, K) and maDorubapN↓ (Sb, TA) signify The part of a sword, with which one strikes: (Msb, and Ham p. 129:) or [the part] about a span from the extremity: (S, TA:) or the part exclusive of, or below, the Zubap [q. v.] (duwna AlTRubapi): (TA:) or the edge (HadR) thereof; (K, TA;) thus expl. by several of the leading lexicologists: (TA:) and so DariybapN↓: which last also signifies a sword: (K:) [i. e.] a sword itself is sometimes thus called, as ISd says: (TA:) the pl. of maDoribN is maDaAribu. (Ham ubi suprà.)

[maDoribu mavalK means (assumed tropical:) The secondary idea, or thing, signified by a parable or proverb, and compared to the primary idea, or thing; the thing, or case, to which a parable or proverb is applied: correlative of maworidu mavalK: pl. maDaAribu.]
And [the pl.] maDaAribu signifies (assumed tropical:) Stratagems in war. (IAar, TA.)
muDoribN [part. n. of OaDoraba, q. v.]. You say, raOayotu HayRapF muDoribFA (S, TA) and muDoribapF (TA) (tropical:) I saw a serpent still, not moving. (S, TA.)

miDorabN [A thing with which one beats, strikes, smites, or hits;] a thing with which the action termed AlDRarob is performed; as also miDoraAbN↓. (K.) A wooden instrument [a kind of mallet] with which the bow-string is struck in the operation of separating cotton. (Msb.)

And, (S, A, K,) as an epithet applied to a man, (S, A,) it signifies Xadiydu AlDRarobi [One who beats, strikes, smites, or hits, vehemently]; (S, O;) or kaviyru AlDRarobi [one who beats, &c., much]; as also DaruwbN↓ (A, K) and DarRaAbN↓ (A) and DariybN↓ (K, TA) and DaribN↓. (O, K, TA. [But in none of these lexicons is this signification mentioned in such a manner as to show that it necessarily relates to any but the first of these words, namely, miDorabN: that it does so, however, is indicated by the measures of all of them.])

Also, (O, K, TA,) or maDoribN↓, with fet-h to the m and kesr to the r, (Mgh,) [thus] written like majolisN by MF, and pronounced by the vulgar maDorab, but both of these are [said to be] incorrect, (TA,) A [tent such as is called] qubRap: (Mgh:) or a great [tent of the kind called] fusoTaAT; (O, K, TA;) the fsTAT of a king: (TA:) pl. maDaAribu. (Mgh, TA.)
maDoribapN and maDorabapN and maDorubapN: see maDoribN.
muDarRabN Sewed [meaning quilted] with cotton: applied in this sense to a bisaAT [or thing that is spread like a carpet, &c.]. (Mgh, Msb.)
muDarRabapN [a subst. signifying A quilt; a quilted garment and the like: see 2]. (S, Mgh, Msb.)

miDoraAbN The thing [i. e. plectrum] with which a lute (Euwd) is struck [or played]: (S:) pl. maDaAriybu. (TA in art. Trb.) [See an ex. voce Tarwb. The plectrum commonly used for this purpose in the present day is a slip of a vulture's feather, and is termed riyXapN: see the chap. on music in my “ Modern Egyptians. ”]
See also miDorabN.
maDoruwbN: see DarobN and DariybN, the latter in two places. Dhu-r-Rummeh says, speaking of a cake of bread (xubozap),

[Many a thing (meaning many a cake of bread) beaten for no offence, free from blame, I have broken for my companions in haste, with a vigorous breaking]. (TA, after explaining the phrase OaDoraba Alxubozu [q. v.].)
Also (assumed tropical:) Staying, abiding, or remaining, [fixed, or settled,] in a tent, or house. (TA.)

muDaAribN One who is employed by another to traffic for him with his (the latter's) property, on the condition of their sharing the gain together: and also one who employs another to traffic for him with his (the former's) property, on that condition: thus expl. by En-Nadr; and Az also allows the use of the word in these two senses. (TA.)
muDoTarabN may mean AiDoTaraAbN [i. e. it may be used as an inf. n. of AiDoTaraba (q. v.), agreeably with a general rule]:

and it may mean A place of AiDoTiraAb: (Ham p. 142:) [thus used it often means a place in which one goes to and fro seeking the means of subsistence: and simply a place in which one seeks gain: see AiDoTaraba fiI Oumuwrihi: and see also the syns. muraAgamN (in two places) and munotafadN.]
[It is also a pass. part. n.: and hence the phrase muDoTarabaAtN lilomaEaAXi, meaning The things that are desired to be gained for subsistence, or sustenance: see maraAgibu.]
muDoTaribN [A thing having its several parts in a state of collision: and hence, a thing, and a man, in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, &c.: see its verb, 8].
One says, jaMCa muDoTariba AlEinaAni [lit. He came with quivering rein]; meaning he came discomfited, or put to flight, and alone. (K.)

And rajulN muDoTaribu Alxaloqi (tropical:) A man incongruous, unsound, faulty, or weak, in respect of make: (A, TA:) tall, and [loose, lax, flabby, uncompact, slack, shaky, or] not strong of make. (TA.)

And HadiyvN muDoTaribu AlsRanadi (assumed tropical:) A tradition unsound, faulty, or weak, in respect of the authority upon which it rests, or to which it is traced up or ascribed; syn. muxotalRN. (S, TA.)

1. Darajahu, (S, O, L, K,) aor.
Darija
, (O,) or
Daruja
, (L,) inf. n. DarojN, (O, L,) He split it, slit it, or rent it asunder or open; (S, O, L, K;) and so DrRjhu↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, or said of a number of things, inf. n. taDoriyjN]; namely, a garment, &c. (L.) [Hence,] Daraja AlnRaAra i. q. fataHa lahaA EayonFA [i. e. He made an opening in the live coals of the fire, in order that it might burn up well]. (AHn, TA.)

And He smeared it, daubed it, or defiled it; (O, L, K;) and so DrRjhu↓ [but app., in this case also, in an intensive sense, or said of a number of things]; namely, a garment, (A, L,) &c., (L,) with blood, (A, L,) or with something similar thereto, that was red, or with something yellow. (L.)
And He threw it, or threw it down. (K.)

Darajato bijirRtihaA and jaraDato [signify the same, i. e. She was choked with her cud; or she swallowed her cud with difficulty; the former verb being app. formed by transposition from the latter; but jariDato seems to be better known than jaraDato]; said of a camel. (O, TA.)
2: see above, in two places.
One says also, DrRj Oanofaha bidamK, (S, O,) or biAldRami, (K,) He made his nose to bleed. (S, O, K.)

And DrRj AlvRawoba, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taDoriyjN, (S, O,) He dyed the garment, or piece of cloth, of a red colour, (S, O, K,) making it less fully dyed than that which is termed muXobaE, and more so than that which is termed muwarRad. (S, O.)

[Hence,] DrRj AlkalaAma, (A, K,) inf. n. as above, (O,) (tropical:) He embellished the speech, (A, O, K,) and amplified it, (A,) as one does in excuses, or pleas, (O,) with truth, or with falsehood. (A, O.)

DrRjt jayobahaA She (a woman) loosened her jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom of her shift or the like, so that the edges were not drawn together, or buttoned]. (O, K: * in the latter, DrRj Aljayoba, inf. n. as above.)
DrRjnA AlUibila We urged on the camels, in making a hostile, or predatory, incursion. (O, K. *)
5: see 7, in four places.

tDrRj also signifies It (a garment, A, L) became smeared, daubed, or defiled, (S, A, O, L, K,) with blood, (S, A, O, L,) or with something similar thereto, that was red, or with something yellow. (L.)

And tDrRj AlxadRu (tropical:) The cheek became red, (O, K, TA,) on an occasion of shame. (O.) You say, kalRamotuhu fataDarRaja xadRaAhu (tropical:) I spoke to him and his cheeks became red. (A, * TA.)
And tDrRjt AlmaroOapu (tropical:) The woman displayed her finery, or ornaments, and beauties of person or form or countenance, to men, (A, O, K, TA,) and embellished herself. (A, TA.)

7. AnDrj It (a thing, or garment, &c., L) split, slit, or rent asunder or open; (S, O, L, K;) as also AnDrj; (TA in art. DrH;) and so tDrRj↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, or said of a number of things]: (L:) the latter is said of a garment in the former sense; (TA;) or as meaning it became much rent, or rent in several places. (L.) When the fruits of herbs, or leguminous plants, appear, one says, AinoDarajato EanohaA lafaAYifuhaA and OakomaAmuhaA [i. e. Their envelopes, or pericarps, and their calyxes, rent asunder or open, so as to disclose them]. (A, TA. [And the like is said in the S and O.]) And one says also, Eani Albaqoli lafaAYifuhu taDarRajato↓, meaning AinofataHat [i. e.
The envelopes, or pericarps, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, opened so as to disclose what was within them]. (S, O.) And AlnRaworu tDrRj↓ The blossoms opened. (K.) And AnDrj AlXRajaru The buds of the trees burst open and the extremities of the leaves appeared. (L.) And tDrRj↓ said of lightning means taXaqRaqa [i. e. It clave the clouds, and extended high, into the midst of the sky; or it was in a state of commotion in the clouds; or it spread wide and long]. (S, A, O, K.)

Also It was, or became, wide, or ample. (El-Muärrij, S, O, K.) You say, AnDrjt lanaA AlTRariyqu The road was, or became, wide to us. (TA.) And AnDrj maA bayona Alqawomi The space between the people was, or became, far-extending: (As, S, O, K: *) and so AnDrj. (S in art. DrH.)
AnDrjt AlEuqaAbu The eagle darted down upon the prey: (O, K:) or betook itself, or advanced, to it: (O:) or took a sidelong course to it. (O, K. *)

DarijN A garment, or piece of cloth, smeared with a red, or yellow, colour; as also UiDoriyjN↓: or this latter is only [applied to a garment, or piece of cloth,] of [the kind called] xazR. (TA.) [And Dariju AlOanaAmili means Having the ends of the fingers smeared, or defiled, by blood: see Ham p. 799.]
DarojapN and DarajapN A species of bird. (TA.)
EadowN DariyjN A vehement running. (S, K.)

UiDoriyjN A yellow [garment of the kind called] kisaMC; (K;) a yellow sort of Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC]: (S, O:) or a ksMC made of excellent [down of the kind called] miroEizRaI: (TA:) or Oakosiyap made of the best of miroEizRaI: (Lth, O, TA:) and, (O, K,) accord. to Lh, (TA,) red [cloth of the kind called] xazR: (O, K, TA:) and Oakosiyapu AlUiDoriyji signifies the Aksyp of red xazR; (A, TA;) or of yellow xazR. (TA. See also DarijN.) And vawobN UiDoriyjN A garment saturated with redness. (A.)
And A red dye: (O, K, TA:) so it is said to signify: and hence vuwobN muDarRajN↓ [meaning A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed of a red colour in the manner expl. voce DrRj]. (TA.)

And A horse that is swift and excellent; or swift, or excellent, in running; (AO, S, O, K, TA;) vehement in running; (S, O, TA;) or having a large mane: (AO, TA:) or wide in the labaAn [or breast, or middle of the breast]. (TA.)
miDorajN: see its pl., maDaAriju, below.
muDarRajN: see UiDoriyjN.
muDarRaju AlxadRayoni (tropical:) Having the cheeks made red. (A, * TA.)
AlmuDarRaju, (so in the O,) or AlmuDarRiju↓, (so accord. to the K, there said to be like muHadRiv,) The lion. (O, K.)
AlmuDarRiju: see what next precedes.
EayonN maDoruwjapN An eye wide in the fissure: (S, O, K:) a wide eye. (A.)
maDaAriju i. q. maXaAqRu [i. e. Fissures; lit. places of slitting: pl. of maXaqRN]. (O, K.) Himyán Ibn-Koháfeh Es-Saadee says, describing the tushes of a stallion-camel,
[That widened the fissures of the sides of his mouth]. (O.)
Also Old and worn-out garments, (A'Obeyd, S, O, K,) that are used for service and work, like what are called maEaAwizu: sing. miDorajN↓. (A'Obeyd, S, O.)

1. DaraHahu, (S, O, L, K,) aor.
DaraHa
, (K,) inf. n. DaroHN, (S, A, O, L,) He removed it from its place; put it away or aside; pushed, or thrust, it away: (S, A, * O, L, K:) he took it, and threw it away or aside: (L:) he pushed it, or thrust it, away with his foot: (Expos. of the “ Amálee ” of El- Kálee:) [and] DaraHa biAlXRaIoCi [if not a mistranscription for DrH AlXRaIoCa] He threw [from him] the thing; and put it away or aside: and DaraHa Eanohu AlvRawoba He cast off from him the garment. (A.) See also 4. [And see 8.] [Hence] DaraHotu EanRiI XahaAdapa Alqawomi (tropical:) I invalidated the testimony of the people or party, or annulled its claim to credibility, (jaraHotuhaA,) and cast it from me, or rejected it: (S, A, O, K: *) said by one against whom false witness has been borne, and who has shown its falseness. (A.)

And DaraHati AldRaAbRapu birijolihaA, (S, O, K,) aor.
DaraHa
, (K, * TA,) inf. n. DaroHN (S, O) and DiraAHN, (S, * O, K,) this latter from Sb, (TA,) [but it seems to be implied in the K that the verb with DiraAHN for its inf. n. has its aor., as well as this inf. n., like that of kataba, which I do not think to be the case,] The beast kicked with its hind leg: (S, O, K:) or AlDRaroHu is with the fore legs; and AlrRamoHu, with the hind legs. (TA.) One says, fiyhaA DiraAHN [It has a habit of kicking with the hind leg: or, with the fore leg]; a phrase mentioned by I'Ab. (S.)

DaraHa, (S, K,) or DaraHa DariyHFA, (A, Msb,) aor.
DaraHa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. DaroHN, (S, K,) He dug a DariyH [q. v.], (S, A, Msb, K,) lilomayRiti [for the corpse]. (A, * K.)

DaraHa, inf. n. DaroHN, also signifies [He clave the ground; (see DariyHN;) and] he split, slit, or rent asunder or open, anything; like Daraja, with j: (TA:) but the phrase DaraHonaA Alburuwda, in a verse of Dhur-r-Rummeh, as some relate it, is expl. by AA as meaning We threw off the [garments called] brwd: others relate it with j; and in this case he says that it means “ we rent asunder ” or “ open. ” (Az, O, TA.)
DaraHa [as though quasipass. of DaraHahu] signifies also He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote; or removed to a distance; went far away. (L.) [See also 7.]
And DaraHati AlsRuwqu, inf. n. DuruwHN (O, K, TA) and DaroHN, (TA,) The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (O, K, TA.)

3. DArHhu i. q. saAbRahu and raAmaAhu; (O, K;) i. e. DArHhu and sAbRhu and rAmAhu are [all] one [in signification, app. meaning He reviled him, or vilified him, being reviled, or vilified, by him; so that the last seems to be here used tropically]. (TA.)
And i. q. qaArabahu [He drew him near to him]; (O, K;) namely, his companion. (O.)
Also, inf. n. muDaAraHapN, He, or it, resembled, and corresponded to, him, or it; syn. DaAraEahu and qaAbalahu. (TA. [See AlDRuraAHu.])

4. ADrH i. q. OaboEada: (K:) you say, OaDoriHohu Eanoka, (so accord. to two copies of the S,) or ADoraHohu↓, (so in one of my copies of the S, [i. e. AiDoraHohu, from DaraHahu, in my other copy of the S ADorHohu, so that the correct form of the verb in this sense is doubtful,]) meaning OaboEidohu [i. e. Remove thou, or put far away, him, or it, from thee]. (S.) [In the TA, it is also expl. as meaning dafaEa, which is likewise a signification of DaraHa.]
And He corrupted, or vitiated, (O, K,) him, or it. (O.)
And OaDoraHotu AlsRuwqa I made, or found, the market to be stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; syn. OakosadotuhaA. (O, K. *)
7. AnDrH It was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA.) You say, AnDrH maA bayona Alqawomi The space between the people was, or became, far-extending: like AnDrj. (As, S.)
Also It split, slit, or rent asunder or open: like AnDrj. (TA.)

8. ADTrHwA fulaAnFA They cast such a one aside: (O, * L, TA: [see also 1, first sentence:]) the vulgar say AiTRaraHuwA, thinking it to be from AlTRaroHu, whereas it is from AlDRaroHu: or, accord. to Az, it may be that, in ATRrHwA, the t of the measure AifotaEala is changed into T, and D incorporated into it. (L, TA.)
DaroHN inf. n. of 1. (S, A, &c.)
bayoniI wabayonahumo DaroHN means Between me and them is a wide distance, and solitude. (TA.)
Also A skin. (O, K.)
niyRapN DaraHN i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or a journey: &c.]; (O, K;) as also TaraHN &c. (O.)
DaraHN applied to a man, Bad, corrupt, or vitious. (El-Muärrij, O, K.)
AlDRaraHu is also used by poetic license for [the inf. n.] AlDRaroHu. (O.)

DaraAHi, like qaTaAmi, (K, TA,) is a verbal noun like nazaAli, (TA,) meaning AiDoraHo, (K, TA,) i. e. AuboEudo: you say, DaraAHi Eanohu Remove thou to a distance, or go far away, from him, or it. (TA.)

AlDRuraAHu, (O, K, TA,) or, accord. to Mujáhid, AlDRariyHu↓, (O, TA, *) [The temple called] Albayotu AlmaEomuwru, (O, K, TA,) corresponding to, or over against, [i. e. directly over,] the Kaabeh, (O, TA,) in Heaven, (O,) in the Fourth Heaven, (K, TA,) or in the Seventh, or in the Sixth, and said to be beneath the EaroX, or in the First Heaven: (TA:) accord. to 'Alee, it is entered every day by seventy thousand angels. (O.)

qawosN DaruwHN A bow that propels the arrow with vehemence; (S, A, K; *) as also TaruwHN [q. v.]. (S and O and K in art. TrH.) And daAbRapN DaruwHN A beast that kicks with its hind leg (S, K) [or with its fore legs: see 1].
DariyHN Distant, or remote: (S, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.)

Also A trench, or an oblong excavation, in the middle of a grave; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so DariyHapN↓: (TA:) in this sense [likewise] of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) what is termed laHodN is in the side: (S:) or a grave (K, TA) altogether: (TA:) or a grave without a laHod: (K, TA:) pl. DaraAYiHu. (Msb.) One says, nawRara QllRehu DariyHahu (A, TA) i. e. [May God illumine] his grave. (TA.)
See also AlDRuraAHu.
DariyHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
maDoraHN: see maDoraHiIRN.
miDoraHN A garment, or piece of cloth, or other thing, used as a repository for clothes: pl. maDaAriHu. (O.)

maDoraHiIRN A hawk, (S, A, O, K,) and a vulture, (A,) having long wings; (S, A, O, K;) as also maDoraHN↓; (O, K;) but the former is the more common: a hawk of this description is of an excellent kind: (TA:) and to the wings of the vulture of this sort is likened the extremity of the tail of a she-camel with the coarse hairs that are upon it: (Kf, TA:) or white, applied to a hawk and to a vulture; (A;) or thus, applied to a vulture; and sometimes, so applied, black: (Ham p. 95:) or a vulture intensely red [or brown]: (AHát, O:) [and a hawk in which is redness; otherwise it is not thus called: (so in the Deewán of Jereer, accord. to Freytag:)] or i. q. OajodalN and SaqorN and qaTaAmiIRN: (A'Obeyd, TA:) [it is mentioned in the K again in art. mDrH; for,] accord. to some, the m is radical: (TA in art. mDrH:) or, applied to a hawk, it means that darts down sideways; or that thrusts the prey. (Ham ubi suprà.)
[Hence,] (tropical:) A chief, (S, A, O, K,) such as is generous, or noble, (K,) or of ancient (A, O) and generous (O) origin. (A, O.)
Also White as an epithet applied to anything. (K.)
And (tropical:) Tall, or long. (K, TA.)
XaIoCN muDoTaraHN A thing cast aside. (S, K.)
8. AiDoTarada, as though from Darada: see 8 in art. Trd.

1. Darasahu, (A, TA,) aor.
Darisa
, (TA,) inf. n. DarosN, (S, A, K,) He bit it: (TA:) or he bit it vehemently with the OaDoraAs [pl. of DirosN, q. v.]; (S, A, K;) as also DrRshu↓: (A:) or with the Daros. (T, TA.)
He (a beast of prey) chewed his flesh, (i. e., the flesh of his prey,) without swallowing it; (A;) as also DrRshu↓. (A, TA.)
He bit it (namely an arrow) to try it; to know if it were hard or weak: (S:) he marked it (namely an arrow) by biting it with his OaDoraAs, (M, A,) or with his teeth. (Az, TA.)
(assumed tropical:) He tried him with respect to his claims to knowledge or courage. (IAar.)
Darasatohu AlxuTuwbu, inf. n. DarosN, (tropical:) Things or affairs, or calamities, tried, or tested, him; as also DrRsthu↓. (TA.)
Darasatohu AlHuruwbu, inf. n. DarosN, (tropical:) Wars tried, or proved, him, and rendered him expert, or strong; (TA;) as also DrRsthu↓, (S, A, K,) inf. n. taDoriysN. (S, K.)
Darasahumu AlzRamaAnu, (S, A, K,) inf. n. DarosN, (K,) (tropical:) Fortune became severe, rigorous, afflictive, or adverse, to them; (S, A, K; *) as also DrRshm↓. (A, TA.)
Darasa naAbuhaA (tropical:) She was evil in disposition: (TA:) and DarosN [alone] the being evil in disposition. (IAar.)
DarosN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The biting of blame, or reprehension. (IAar.)
And (tropical:) The keeping silence during a day, until the night: (O, K, TA:) as though biting one's tongue. (TA.)

And Darasa AlbiYora, aor.
Darisa
(O, K, TA) and
Darusa
, (TA,) inf. n. DarosN, (O, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He cased the well with stones: (O, K, TA:) or, as some say, he closed up the interstices of its casing with stones: and in like manner one says of any building. (TA.)

Darisato OasonaAnuhu, (S, K,) aor.
Darasa
, (K,) inf. n. DarasN, (S,) His teeth were set on edge (kalRato) by eating or drinking what was acid, or sour. (S, A, * K.) And Darisa AlrRajulu The man's teeth were set on edge. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Wahb Ibn-Munebbih, that a certain bastard, of the Children of Israel, offered an offering, and it was rejected; whereupon he said, yaA rabRi yaOokulu OabawaAIa AlHamoDa waOaDorasu OanaA Oanota Oakoramu mino celika [O my Lord, my two parents eat sour herbage, and are my teeth set on edge? Thou art more gracious than to suffer that]: and his offering was accepted. (O in art. HmD.) [See Jer., xxxi. 29; and Ezek., xviii. 2.]
Also Darisa, inf. n. DarasN, (tropical:) He was angry by reason of hunger: because hunger sharpens the OaDoraAs. (TA.)
And DarisuwA biAlHarobi (assumed tropical:) They persisted in war until they fought one another. (T, O, TA.)
2. DrRshu inf. n. taDoriysN: see Darasahu, in five places.
taDoriysN also signifies (tropical:) An indentation, or serration, (Az, TA,) like OaDoraAs, (TA,) in a sapphire (yaAquwtap) and a pearl, or in wood. (Az, TA.)
3. DaArasotu AlOumuwra (tropical:) I became experienced in affairs, and knew them. (T, TS.)

DArswA, (K,) inf. n. muDaArasapN and DiraAsN; so in the Tekmileh; but in the M, tDArswA↓; (TA;) (tropical:) They warred, or fought, one against another, and treated one another with enmity, or hostility: (K, TA:) from DarasN, [inf. n. of Darisa,] signifying the “ being angry by reason of hunger. ” (TA.)
4. ADrshu It (acid, or sour, food, or drink,) set his teeth on edge; (Ibn-'Abbád, K; *) syn. OakalRa OasonaAnahu. (Ibn-'Abbád.) [And so, app., ADrs OasonaAnahu.]
Also (tropical:) He, or it, (an affair, or event, S,) disquieted him. (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K, TA.)
And ADrshu biAlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) He silenced him by speech. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
5: see what next follows.
6. tDArs, (S, A, K,) in the M tDrRs↓, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a building) was, or became, uneven, (S, M, A, K,) and irregular, (A,) having in it what resembled OaDoraAs. (M.)
tDArswA: see 3.

DarosN (assumed tropical:) Land of which the herbage is here and there (IAar, T, O, K, TA) and on which rain has fallen here and there: (IAar, T, TA:) and a portion of land upon which rain has fallen a day or part of a day. (TA.)
See also DirosN.

DirosN A tooth: (S, K:) pl. OaDoraAsN, and (sometimes, S, Msb) DuruwsN (S, Msb, K) and OaDorusN [which is a pl. of pauc., as is also, properly, the first of the pls. here mentioned]; and quasi-pl. n. Drs [written in the TA without any syll. signs, so that it may be DarosN, or DirosN (like the sing.), or DarasN]; so in the M [of which I am unable to consult the portion containing this art.]: (TA:) or [a lateral tooth; for] the ADrAs are the teeth, except the central incisors: (Mgh:) or [this explanation, which I find only in the Mgh, is incomplete, and the word sometimes means the teeth absolutely, but properly] the molar teeth, or grinders, which are twenty in number, [including the bicuspids,] next behind the canine teeth: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or i. q. OaroHaMCN: (S and Msb and K, art. rHI: [see sinRN: and see also rabaAEiyapN:] DirosN is masc.; (Mgh, K;) and sometimes fem.: (Mgh:) or what is thus called is masc. when thus called; (S, Msb;) but if called sinRN, it is fem.: (Msb:) or it is properly masc.; and if found in poetry made fem., sinRN is meant thereby: (Zj, Msb:) but As denies its being made fem.; (Msb, TA;) and as to the saying ascribed to Dukeyn,

[And an eye was put out, and a tooth, or grinder, sounded], he says that the right reading is waTanRa AlDRirosu [and the tooth, or grinder, sounded], and that he who heard these words understood them not. (TA.) What are called OaDoraAsu AlEaqoli and OaDoraAsu AlHulum [The wisdom-teeth, and the teeth of puberty] are four: they come forth after the
[other] teeth have become strong. (TA. [See naAjicN.])
[Hence,] sing. of DuruwsN (K) which signifies (assumed tropical:) The stones with which a well is cased. (S, O, K.)
And (assumed tropical:) A finod [app. as meaning a peak, or the like,] in a mountain. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) A rough [hill, or eminence, or elevated place, such as is termed] Oakamap (T, O, K, TA) and [such as is termed] OaxoXab: (T, TA:) or rough ground; written by Sgh DarosN↓: (IAar, TA:) or a portion of a [tract such as is termed] qufR, somewhat elevated, very rugged, rough to the tread, consisting of a single piece of stone [or rock], unmixed with clay, or soil, and not giving growth to anything: pl. DuruwsN. (TA.)

Also (tropical:) Light rain: (IAar, TA:) or a rain little in quantity: (S, O:) or a light rain: pl. DuruwsN: (K:) or DuruwsN mino maTarK means scattered rains: (As, TA:) or scattered showers of rain: (S, O:) and some say, i. q. judur [app. a mistranscription, probably for xadarN, which signifies rain; or clouds, or mist, and rain]: and [it is. said that] DirosN signifies also a raining cloud that has not [much] width. (TA.)
See also muDarRasN, last sentence.
DarisN A man having his teeth set on edge. (TA.)

And (tropical:) A man angry by reason of hunger; (AZ, K, TA;) because hunger sharpens the OaDoraAs: (TA:) and DariysN↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) very hungry; (K, TA;) so that there is nothing that comes to him but he eats it, by reason of hunger: (TA:) pl. of the latter DaraAsaI, like as HazaAnaI is a pl. of HaziynN. (K.)

And (tropical:) A man (S, A, O) refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (Yz, S, A, O, K:) evil in disposition, or illnatured, and very perverse or cross or repugnant and averse; syn. XarisN. (K.) You say rajulN DarisN XarisN. (Yz, S, A, O.) [See DaruwsN.]
See also muDarRasN, last sentence.
DirosapN Ruggedness, and roughness. (TA.)
DuraAsN Toothache. (MA.)
DiraAsN [seems to signify, properly, A disposition to bite].

[Hence,] AlnRaAqapu bijinRi DiraAsihaA means (assumed tropical:) The she-camel is in the case of the recentness of her bringing forth, when she defends her young one; from the epithet DaruwsN; (S, Meyd, O; but in the S and O, hiIa, referring to the she-camel, is put in the place of AlnAqp;) and is a prov., applied to the man whose nature is evil on the occasion of his defending. (Meyd.) And one says, AitRaqi AlnRaAqapa bijinRi DiraAsihaA, meaning (tropical:) Beware thou of the she-camel in the case of the recentness of her bringing forth, and of her evil disposition towards him who approaches her, by reason of her attachment to her young one. (A, TA.) [In the TA, in art. jn, this saying is mentioned with DiraAmihaA in the place of DiraAsihaA: the former may perhaps be another reading; but I rather think that it is a mistranscription for the latter. And in the present art. in the TA, it is added that Sgh has mentioned (app. in the TS, for he has not done so in the O,) El-Báhilee's having explained AlDRiraAsu as meaning siyomN lhm; and that it is likewise explained in the T as meaning siyomN: but I know no such word as siyomN; nor do I know any word of which it is likely to be a mistranscription, though I have diligently searched for such. This word siyomN has been altered by the copyist in each instance in the TA; so that it seems to have been indistinctly written by the author.]
[Hence also] DiraAsu AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) The biting of war. (Ham p. 532.)
DaruwsN A she-camel of evil disposition, (S, K,) that bites her milker: (S, A, K:) or that has a habit of biting to defend her young one. (TA.)
[Hence,] HarobN DaruwsN (tropical:) Devouring, biting, war: (TA:) or vehement war. (Ham p. 87.)
And A she-camel whose flow, or stream, of milk does not make any sound to be heard. (TA.)
DariysN (assumed tropical:) Stones resembling OaDoraAs [i. e. teeth or lateral teeth or molar teeth]: with such, a well is cased. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The vertebræ of the back. (O, K.)
Also, and maDoruwsapN↓, (assumed tropical:) A well (biYorN) cased with stones. (S, K.)
See also DarisN.
OaDorasu an imitative sequent to Oaxorasu as an epithet applied to a man. (S, K.)

muDarRasN (assumed tropical:) A sort of figured cloth or garment, (S, O, K,) having upon it forms resembling OaDoraAs [i. e. teeth or lateral teeth or molar teeth], (K,) or thought by IF to be thus called because having upon it such forms: (O:) or, applied as an epithet to [the kind of garments called] rayoT, as meaning figured with the marks of folding: or meaning folded in a square form: or, as some say, muDarRasapN signifies a sort of cloths, or garments, upon which are lines and ornamental borders. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) An arrow that is not smooth, or even; because it has in it what resemble OaDoraAs. (TA.)
And HrRapN muDarRasapN and maDoruwsapN↓ (assumed tropical:) [A stony tract] in which are stones like the OaDoraAs of dogs. (A'Obeyd, S, K.)

Also (tropical:) A man who has been tried, or proved, or tried and strengthened, by experience; (A, TA;) whom trials have befallen, as though he had been bitten thereby: (TA:) who has been tried, or proved, and rendered expert, or strong, by wars, (S, A,) and by affairs, or calamities: (A:) like munajRacN from naAjicN: (A, TA:) or who has become experienced in affairs: (AA, S:) one who has travelled, and become experienced in affairs, and fought; as also DirosN↓ and DarisN↓. (TA.)
AlmuDarRisu The lion, that chews the flesh of his prey without swallowing it: (O, K:) or the lion; so called because he does thus. (TA.)
maDoruwsapN: see DariysN: and also muDarRasN.

1. DaraTa, aor.
DariTa
; (S, Msb, K;) and DariTa, aor.
DaraTa
; (Msb;) inf. n. DariTN (S, Msb, K, in the Msb said to be of the latter verb,) and DaroTN (Msb, K, in the Msb said to be of the former verb,) and DariyTN and DuraATN, (K,) or the last is a simple subst., (Msb,) [a coarse word, signifying] He broke wind, i. e. emitted wind from the anus, with a sound. (S, K.) [When it is without sound, you say fasaA.] Hence the prov., OawodaI AlEayoru UilRaA DariTFA The ass had no power remaining except [that of] emitting wind from the anus, with a sound: (S, K:) applied to a vile, or an abject, person, and to an old man; and in allusion to a thing's becoming in a bad, or corrupt, state, so that there remains of it nothing but what is of no use: (K:) the last word is in the accus. case as denoting a thing of a different kind from that signified by the preceding noun. (O.) And Oajobanu mina Almanozuwfi DariTFA [More cowardly than he who is exhausted by emitting wind from the anus, with a sound]: another prov.: [its origin is variously related: see Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 320:] or Almanozuwfu DariTFA [or DaroTFA, for it is differently written in different copies of the K,] is a certain beast, between the dog and the cat, (K,) or between the dog and the wolf, (O,) which, when one cries out at it, emits wind from the anus, with a sound, by reason of cowardice. (Sgh, K.)
2: see 4, in two places.
4. ADrThu, and DrRThu↓, (S, O, K,) He made him to emit wind from the anus, with a sound: (S:) or he did to him that which caused him to emit wind from the anus, with a sound. (O, K.)

ADrT bihi; and bh DrRT↓, (S, K,) inf. n. taDoriyTN; (K) He derided him, and imitated to him with his mouth the action of one emitting wind from the anus, with a sound; (S;) he made to him with his mouth a sound like that of an emission of wind from the anus, and derided him. (K, * TA.) ADrT biAlsRaAYili, said in a trad., of 'Alee, means He treated the asker with contempt, disapproving what he said; he derided him. (TA.)
DariTN: part. n. of DariTa. (Msb.)

DaroTapN [inf. n. un. of 1; A single emission of wind from the anus, making a sound]. It is said in a prov., of him who has done a deed of which he has not done the like before nor after, kaAnato minohu kaDaroTapi AlOaSamRi [There proceeded from him what was like the DrTh of the deaf]. (Sgh, TA.)
DuraATN An emission of wind from the anus, with a sound: (S, TA:) or the sound thereof: (K, TA: [in the CK, Sawotu AlfaqoHi is put for Sawotu Alfayoxi:]) a subst. from 1. (Msb.)
DaruwTN: see DarRaATN.
DurayoTN: see surRayoTaI.
DurayoTaI: see surRayoTaI.
DurayoTaMCu: see surRayoTaI.

DarRaATN and DaruwTN↓ and DirRawoTN↓ are all [intensive] epithets from 1; (K;) [signifying One who emits wind from the anus, with a sound, much, or frequently;] the last mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)
DirRawoTN: see the next preceding paragraph.
DurRayoTN: see surRayoTaI.
DurRayoTaI: see surRayoTaI.
DirRiyTaI: see surRayoTaI.
OaDoraTu: see OaToraTu, in art. TrT.

muDarRiTu AlHijaArapi (assumed tropical:) [as though signifying He who makes the stones to emit sounds, from fear:] an appellation given to 'Amr Ibn-Hind, because of his strength and hardiness and courage, (S,) or because of the awe which he inspired. (A, TA.)
1. DaraEa, said of a lamb or kid, He took [with his mouth] the DaroE [meaning dug] of his mother. (TA.) [This seems to be regarded by some as the primary signification.]

And (TA) the same, (S, Msb, K,) said of a man, (S,) aor.
DaraEa
; (Msb, K;) and DariEa, aor.
DaraEa
; and DaruEa, aor.
DaruEa
; (K;) inf. n. (S, Msb, K) of the first (S, Msb, TA) and of the third (TA) DaraAEapN, (S Msb, K,) and (K) of the second (TA) DaraEN; (K;) He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; (S, K;) and low, abject, or abased; (S, Msb, K;) Uilayohi (K) and lahu [to him]: (TA:) or DariEa and DaraEa signify he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself, (K, * TA,) [like tDrRE, which is more commonly used in this sense,] and made petition for a gift: (TA:) and DaruEa, (Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. DaraEN, (Msb,) or DaraAEapN, (TA,) he was, or became, weak; (K, TA;) and it is said that the verb in this last sense is from DaraEa in the sense expl. in the first sentence: so in the “ Mufradát ” [of Er-Rághib]: DariEa, likewise, like fariHa [in measure], signifies he was, or became, weak in body, slender, spare, or light of flesh: and DuruwEN, [app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is DaraEa,] the being lean, or emaciated. (TA.) For another explanation of DaraAEapN, see 5.
[DaraEa is made trans. by means of b:] one says, DaraEa bihi farasuhu His horse humbled him, or abased him: (O, K, TA:) or, as in the L, overcame him. (TA.)
DaraEa minohu, said of an animal of prey, (IKtt, K, TA,) inf. n. DuruwEN, (K,) He approached (IKtt, K, TA) him i. e. a man, (IKtt, TA,) or it i. e. a thing. (K.)
See also the next paragraph.

2. taDoriyEN signifies The drawing near, or approaching, by little and little, in a deceitful, or guileful, manner, going this way and that, or to the right and left; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) as also taDarRuEN↓: (K:) you say DarRaEa and taDarRaEa. (O, TA.)

And DarRaEati AlXRamosu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) (tropical:) The sun approached the setting; (S, O, K;) [like DjREt;] and DaraEat↓ signifies the same; [like DajaEat;] or the sun set; (K;) and AlXRamosu DaAriEati↓, inf. n. muDaAraEapN, signifies the same as DaraEat and DrREt. (TA.)

And DarRaEati Alqidoru i. q. HaAna Oano tudorika [i. e.
