, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. ns. as above, meaning He erred, strayed, or went astray, from the road, or way; (Msb;) he did not find the way to the road: (Mgh, Msb:) and of anything stationary, if you miss the place thereof, you say Dalalotuhu and Dalilotuhu: (Az, Msb:) or you say, Dalilotu AlTRariyqa, (K,) or Dalilotu Almasojida, and AldRaAra, (ISk, S, O,) [I missed, or lost, the right way to the road, or the mosque, and the house,] when you know not the place thereof: (ISk, S, O:) and in like manner, anything stationary, to which one does not find the way: (ISk, S, O, K:) and AA says the like: but that one says of a thing that falls from his hand, and a thing that quits its place, OaDolalotuhu↓, (IB, TA,) which means I lost it, and knew not its place; meaning, for instance, a horse, or she-camel, or the like: (Az, Msb:) [thus] one says, OaDolalotu biEiyriI [I lost my camel, and knew not his place,] (AA, ISk, S, IB, O) when his shank has been tied up to his arm and one does not find the way to him, and when he has been left loose and has gone away whither one knows not: (AA, IB, TA:) but Yoo differs from others respecting this case; for, accord. to him, one says, ADlR fulaAnN baEiyrahu and also DalRahu, in the same sense; (O, TA;) and the like is said in the K: (TA:) and it is also said in the Bári' that when you seek an animal and miss its place and find not the way to it, it is regarded as in the category of stationary things, and therefore you say Dalilotuhu. (Msb.)
DalRa signifies also He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA.)

Also, aor.
Dalila
(S, O, K) and
Dalala
, (K,) the pret. being like zalRa and malRa, (TA,) inf. n. DalaAl, It (a thing, S, O, TA) became lost; [as though it went astray;] it perished, came to nought, or passed away. (S, O, K, TA.) Thus in the phrase DalRa EanRiI kacaA Such a thing became lost from me. (Mgh.) One says to him from whom pieces of money have dropped, qado DalRato Eanoka [They have become lost from thee]. (TA.) And to him who has done a deed from which no profit has resulted, you say, qad DalRa saEoyuka (tropical:) [Thy labour has been lost]: the like occurs in the Kur xviii. 104, meaning DaAEa. (TA, in two places.)

And (tropical:) He (a man, TA) died, and became dust and bones. (K, TA.) In this sense the verb is used in the Kur xxxii. 9: but some there read, in the place of DalalonaA, SalilonaA [q. v.], with S: (TA:) or the verb in that instance has the meaning here next following. (S.)

And (assumed tropical:) He, or it, (a man, S, TA, or a camel, Msb, and a thing, TA,) was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, unapparent, latent, hidden or concealed, or absent, (S, Msb, K, TA.) Hence the phrase, DalRa AlmaMCu fiI AllRabani (tropical:) [The water became unperceived, or concealed, in the milk]. (TA.) One says of a road to which he has not been able to find the way, DalRa EanRiI
[It has become hidden from me]. (K, TA.) And hence also the saying of a man, as is related in a trad., (S, O, TA,) after his having charged his sons by saying to them, “ When I die, burn ye me; and when I shall have become ashes, pound me; then scatter me in the water: ” (O, TA:) laEalRiI OaDilRu QllReh (S, O, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) May-be, I shall be unperceived by God, or concealed from Him: (S:) or may-be, I shall be hidden, or absent, from God's punishment: (O, TA:) or, as El-'Otbee says, may-be, I shall escape God, and my place will be hidden from Him. (TA.) And DalRa said of one forgetting means (assumed tropical:) His memory became absent from him. (O, Msb, TA.) Oano taDilRa UiHodaAhumaA, or Uino taDilRa, in the Kur [ii. 282], accord. to different readers, (TA,) in which instance Oano and Uino are syn., (Mughnee, [see Oano, in p. 106, cols. 1 and 2,]) means If one of them twain [referring to women] be absent from her memory: or if the memory of one of them twain be absent from her: [or if one of them twain err in her memory:] or, accord. to Zj, the meaning of the verb in this case is that which next follows. (TA.)

Dalilotu AlXRaIoCa also signifies (assumed tropical:) I forgot the thing: whence one says of a woman, DalRato OayRaAma HayoDihaA (assumed tropical:) [She forgot the days of her menstruation]; and so OaDalRatohaA↓: (Mgh:) or DalRa fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He was made, or caused, to forget such a one. (K. [In the CK, Aunosiyohi is erroneously put for Ounosiyahu.]) It is said that laA yaDilRu rabRiI, in the Kur xx. 54, means (assumed tropical:) My Lord will not be unmindful: or nothing will escape Him. (TA.)

And one says, DalRaniI fulaAnN, (Msb, K,) or DalRaniI fulaAnN falamo Oaqodaro Ealayohi, (O,) meaning Such a one went away from me, (O, Msb, K,) and I was unable to compass him [or to find him]: so in the Bári'. (Msb.)
DulRa, as a verb of wonder: see DulRN.

2. Dlalhu, (S, MA, O, K,) inf. n. taDoliylN and taDolaAlN, (K,) He, or it, made, or caused, him to pursue a course that led to error, or deviation from the right way: (K: [see also 4:]) he, or it, led him astray; seduced him: (MA:) [or] he attributed, or imputed, to him error, or deviation from the right way. (S, MA, O.) DulRila saEoyuhumo, a phrase used by a poet, means Error, or deviation from the right way, was attributed to their labour; because they did not reach their goal. (Ham p. 771.)
[Hence,] one says, DalRilo maAlaka Send forth, or set free, thy cattle to pasture, or to pasture where they please, by themselves. (O.)
See also the next paragraph.

4. ADlRhu, inf. n. UiDolaAlN, He, or it, made him, or caused him, to err, stray, or go astray; to deviate from the right way or course, or from that which was right; to miss, or lose, the right way; or to lose his way. (Az, TA.) [See also 2, first sentence.] AlUiDolaAlu is of two sorts: one of these is the consequence of erring, or straying; either as in the case in which one says OaDolalotu AlbaEiyra (expl. above, see 1, former half); or the decreeing that one shall err, or stray, &c., because he has done so already, and this is sometimes the case when the UiDolaAl of a man is attributed to God: the other sort is the embellishing [or commending] to a man that which is false, or wrong, or vain, in order that he may err, or stray, &c.: and God's UiDolaAl of a man is of two sorts; one of which has been expl. above; the other is God's so constituting man that when he observes [and pursues] a certain course, or way, [of acting or the like], whether it be such as is commended or such as is discommended, he habituates himself to it, and esteems it pleasant, and keeps to it, and finds it difficult to turn from it, wherefore it is said that custom is a second nature. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Also He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to perish, or become lost; syn. Oaholakahu, (S, TA,) and OaDaAEahu, (El-Fárábee, S, O, Msb,) or DayRaEahu; (TA;) [ADAEhu and DyREhu signifying the same; and so ADlRhu and DllRehu↓; whence,] Oalamo yajoEalo kayodahumo fiI taDoliylK, in the Kur cv. 2, means [Did He not make their plot to be such as ended] in a causing to perish, or become lost, (fiI taDoyiyEK,) and in annulment? (Ksh, Bd.) OaDalRa OaEomaAlahumo, in the Kur [xlvii. 1 and 9, which may be rendered (assumed tropical:) He will cause their works to be lost, or to be of no effect], means, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, He will not recompense them for their good works; the phrase being similar to the saying qado DalRa saEoyuka [expl. above]. (TA.) And OaDalRa QllRehu DalaAlaka (assumed tropical:) [May God make thine erring to be no more, or to come to an end,] is expl. by ISk as meaning may thine erring pass away from thee, so that thou shalt not err; and he adds that the saying malRa malaAluka means cahaba Eanoka HatRaI laA tamalRa. (TA.)

Also (tropical:) He buried, and hid, or concealed, him, or it. (K, TA.) You say, OuDilRa AlmayRitu (tropical:) The dead was buried. (S, O.) The phrase OaDalRato bihi OumRuhu, meaning (tropical:) His mother buried him, in a verse cited by IAar, is extr., or anomalous. (TA.)

And He found him to be erring, straying, going astray; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which was right; missing, or losing, the right way; losing his way; not rightly directed, or not finding the way to the truth: like as one says OaHomadahu, and Oaboxalahu. (TA.)
And you say, OaDalRaniI kacaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a thing was, or became, beyond my power, or compass. (IAar, Msb, TA.)
See also 1, near the end.
5. tZlRl It went away: so in the saying, tDlRl AlmaMCu mino taHoti AlHajari [The water went away from beneath the stone]. (O, TA.)
6. tDAlR He feigned himself to be erring, straying, going astray; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which was right; missing, or losing, the right way; or losing his way. (O, TA.)

10. AstDlR DalaAluhu His erring demanded that he should err [the more], so that he did err [the more: like as erring is said to be a cause of one's being made to err: see 4: and see also DalRa DalaAluhu, near the beginning of the art.]: so in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
[The heart beheld her, and his erring demanded that he should err &c.]. (Skr, S, TA.)
DalRN: see DalaAlN.
DulRN: see DalaAlN.
[Also, app. as meaning A lost state; a state of perishing, coming to nought, or passing away;] a subst. from DalRa signifying DaAEa and halaka. (S, TA.)

And hence [its usage, in the manner of a proper name, in] the saying, huwa DulRu bonu DulRK, (S,) which means, (S, O, K,) as also huwa DilRu bonu DilRK↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) He is the unknown, the son of the unknown; (S, Z, O, K;) and in like manner, bonu AltRalaAli AlDRalaAlu↓; (S, O;) and qulRu bonu qulRK: (TA:) or he is one in whom is no good: (K:) or he is one who persists in error. (M, K.)

[Hence also, perhaps, it is said that] yaA DulRa maA tajoriI bihi AlEaSaA [in the CK DalRa] means yaA faqodahu and yaA talafahu [i. e., app., O the loss, or O the coming to nought, of that by reason of which the mare El-'Asà is running!]: (K, TA:) a prov.; said by Kaseer Ibn-Saad to Jedheemeh El-Abrash, when he went with him to Ez-Zebbà; for when they were within her province, he repented, and Kaseer said to him, “ Mount this my horse, and escape upon him, for his dust will not be cloven [by the pursuer, ” i. e. he will not be overtaken]: (TA: [but the mare is thus made a male:]) or it was said by 'Amr Ibn-'Adee, when he saw El-'Asà, the mare of Jedheemeh, with Kaseer upon her: qawomu is suppressed after yA; and DulRa↓ is of the forms [of verbs] denoting wonder, originally Dalula, with damm, like HubRa in the phrase HubRa bifulaAnK, originally Habuba; and the meaning of the prov. is, O people, what a case of perdition is that by reason of which El-'Asà is running! i. e., the death of Jedheemeh. (Meyd.)
DulRN bitaDolaAlK [in CK DalRN] means A vain, or futile, thing: (S, O, K:) [or a vain, misleading thing; taDolaAlN being an inf. n. of DalRala:] 'Amr Ibn-Shás El-Asadee says,
[I remembered Leylà when it was not a time for remembering her, the ribs having become bent by the bending of the back with age: it was a vain, misleading thing]. (S, O.)
DulRu OaDolaAlK: see DilRapN.
huwa DilRu bonu DilRK: see DulRN.
DilRu OaDolaAlK: see DilRapN.

DalRapN Confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see the right course: (K:) [or error: for] one says, faEala celika DalRapF He did that in error (fiI DalaAlapK): and cahaba DalRapF He went away not knowing whither he went: (TA:) and fulaAnN yaluwmuniI DalRapF Such a one blames me wrongly: (S, O:) [or, behind my back, or in my absence: for] DalRapN signifies
also speech respecting a person behind his back, or in his absence; relating to good and to evil. (M, K, TA.)
[Freytag explains it as signifying also One in whom is no good, on the authority of Meyd.]
DulRapN Skill in guiding, or directing aright, in journeying. (Fr, K, * TA.)
DilRapN: see DalaAlN.
[Hence,] huwa Qbonuhu liDilRapK (tropical:) He is his son unlawfully begotten, or not trueborn. (AZ, A, K, TA.)
cahaba damuhu DilRapF (tropical:) His blood went unrevenged, or without retaliation. (K, TA.)

And huwa tiboEu DilRapK, (Th, O, K, TA,) with kesr to the t and to the D, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, tabaEu,] and tiboEN DilRapN, (K, TA,) thus related by IAar, (TA,) but the former only accord. to Th, (TA in art. tbE,) (assumed tropical:) He is a follower of women: (TA in that art.:) or he is one in whom is no good, and with whom is no good: (IAar, Th, TA:) or he is a very cunning man (daAhiyapN), one in whom is no good; (IAar, O, K, TA;) and so tiboEu SilRapK, (O, L, TA,) as some relate it; (L, TA;) and in like manner, OaDolaAlK DilRu↓, (Lh, O, K, TA,) and OaDolaAlK DulRu↓, (K, TA,) and SilRu OaSolaAlK, [q. v.,] which is with kesr only, (K, TA,) a phrase similar to DirRu OaDoraArK. (TA in art. Dr.)
DalalN: see DalaAlN.
Also Water (O, K) running (K) beneath a rock, which the sun does not reach: (O, K:) one says maMCN DalalN: (O:) or running among trees. (K.) [See also DalalN.]

DalaAlN [an inf. n. of 1: used as a simple subst.,] Error; contr. of raXaAdN, (S, O, TA,) and of hudFI; (K, TA;) as also DalaAlapN↓, (S, O, K,) and DalRN↓, and DulRN↓, and DilRapN↓, and DalalN↓, and DaloDalapN↓, (K,) and DulaDilapN↓, (O, TA,) and OuDoluwlapN↓, (K,) of which last the pl. is OaDaAliylu, (Lth, O, TA,) as in the saying tamaAdaI fiI OaDaAliyli AlhawaI [He persevered in the errors of love], (TA,) or OaDaAliylu, as some say, has no sing., or its sing. is supposed, or has been heard, and is OuDoluwlapN or OuDoluwlN or UiDoliylN or some other form: (MF, TA:) the primary signification of AlDRalaAlu is the going away from the right course, or direction: (Ham p. 357:) or it signifies, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the loss, or missing, of that which brings, or conducts, to the object sought: or, as some say, the pursuing a way that will not bring, or conduct, to that object: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the deviating from the right way: and it is said to be any deviation from that which is right, intentional or unintentional, little or much; because the right and approved way is very difficult; wherefore it may be used of him who commits any mistake whatever, and is imputed to prophets and to unbelievers, though between the DlAl of the former and that of the latter is a wide difference: and in another point of view, it is of two sorts; one is in the speculative departments of knowledge, as in acquaintance with the unity of God, and with the prophetic function or office, and the like, indicated in the Kur iv. 135; or it is in the practical departments of knowledge, as in acquaintance with the ordinances of the law, that is, religious services. (TA.)
Also A state of perdition: so in the Kur liv. 24: (S, O:) [and in like manner DalaAlapN↓; for] DalaAlapu AlEamali signifies The annulled and lost state of work. (TA.)
And Absence, or a state of concealment. (Msb. [This is there said to be the primary signification.])
huwa AlDRalaAlu bonu AltRalaAli see expl. voce DulRN.
DaluwlN: see DaAlRN.

DalaAlapN: see DalaAlN, in the beginning, and near the end, of the paragraph. One says, hiIa AlDRalaAlapu waAltRalaAlapu; (S, O;) in which the latter noun is an imitative sequent. (S and K in art. tl.)

DilRiylN A man (S, O) who errs, strays, goes astray, or deviates from the right way or course, much, or often: (S, O, K:) or (tropical:) who errs, &c., much, or often, in religion: (TA:) and muDalRalN↓, (S, TA,) which in some of the copies of the S is written thus and also muDalRil, (TA,) signifies the same; (S, TA;) or one who is not disposed, or directed, to good; in the K, AlRcI lA yuwafRiI bixayorK, [or yuwfiI bxyr, as in the CK,] but correctly AlRcI lA yuwafRaqu lixayorK; or, as some say, a committer of errors, and of false, wrong, or vain, actions: and DilRiylN is also expl. as signifying one who will not desist from error. (TA.) Imra-el-Keys was called Almaliku AlDRilRiylu [The much-erring king], (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlDRaliylu,]) and Almlk AlmuDalRalu↓. (K.)

DaAlRN Erring, straying, or going astray; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right; missing, or losing, the right way; or losing his way; (S, * Msb, TA;) and DaluwlN↓ is syn. therewith; (K;) [or rather with DilRiylN, accord. to a general rule:] pl. of the former DulRaAlN, [of which see an ex. in a verse cited voce risolN,] and DuAlRuwna: [in the Kur i. last verse,] some read walaA QlDRaOalRiyna, to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters. (TA.) You say DaAlRN taAlRN; (S, O;) in which the latter epithet is an imitative sequent. (S and K in art. tl.)
[Also Becoming lost; &c.

And Forgetting. It is said that] waOanaA mina QlDRaAlRiyna [in the Kur xxvi. 19] means (assumed tropical:) I being of those that forgot. (K, TA.) And AimraOapN DaAlRapN means (assumed tropical:) A woman forgetting the days of her menstruation. (Mgh.)

DaAlRapN an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, (IAth, TA,) A stray; i. e. a beast that has strayed: (S, O, TA:) or a camel remaining in a place where it is lost, without an owner (K, TA) that is known: (TA:) or a lost animal (IAth, Msb, TA) or other thing, whatever it be: (IAth, TA:) applied to the male and to the female, (S, O, Msb, K,) and to two and to a pl. number: (TA;) and it has for its pl. DawaAlRu, (Msb, TA,) like dawaAbRu pl. of daAbRapN. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., DaAlRapu AlmuWomini Haraqu AlnRaAri [expl. in art. Hrq]. (TA.) And one says, AlHikomapu DaAlRapu AlmuWomini (assumed tropical:) [Wisdom is the object of persevering quest of the believer]; meaning that the believer ceases not to seek wisdom like as a man seeks his stray. (TA.)

DalaDilN and DalaDilapN↓, (As, S,) as though contracted from DalaADilN [and DalaADilapN], (S,) or OaroDN DalaDilapN↓ and DalaDilN [in the CK DalaDalapN and SalaDalN] and DulaDilapN↓ and DulaDilN↓ (K) and DulaADilN↓ (Lh, K) and DuloDulapN, (IDrd, K,) Rugged land or ground. (As, S, K.) And makaAnN DalaDilN, originally DalaADiylu, A hard, stony place. (Fr, TA.)

Also, (so in the K,) i. e. (TA) DalaDilN and DalaDilapN↓, accord. to As, (O, TA,) or DulaDilapN↓, (S, O, TA,) [said to be] the only instance of its kind among reduplicate words, (S, O, TA, [in which last the same assertion is quoted from the T, app. in relation to the last, or last but one, of these words,]) and, as in the Jm, DuloDulapN↓, (O, TA,) A stone, (As, S, O,) or stones, (K,) such as a man can lift from the ground and carry: (As, S, O, K:) or, accord. to the T, DlDlp [thus in the TA, app. DalaDilapN↓ or DulaDilapN↓,] signifies any stone such as a man can lift from the ground and carry, or above that, smooth, found in the interiors of valleys. (TA.)
DulaDilN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Also, (IAar, O, TA,) in the K, erroneously, SulaDilapN, (TA.) and DulaADilN↓, A skilful guide of the way. (IAar, O, K, TA.)
DaloZalapN: see DalaAlN.
DuloDulapN: see DalaDilN, in two places.

DalaADilu AlmaMCi, (O, K,) and SalaASiluhu, (O,) [said in the O, in this art., to be pls. of which the sings. are DulaDilapN and SulaSilapN, but the sings. are correctly DuloDulapN and SuloSulapN, (see the latter of these two in its proper art.,)] The remains of water: (O, K:) so says Lh. (O.)
DalaDilapN: see DalaDilN, in four places.
DulaDilapN: see DalaAlN:
and maDalRapN:
and DalaDilN, in three places.
DulaADilN: see DalaDilN:
and DulaDilN.
OuDoluwlapN: see DalaAlN.

waqaEa fiI waAdiI tuDulRila, (Ks, S, O, K, *) like tuxuyRiba and tuhulRika, all imperfectly decl., (S, O,) and tuDalRila, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and taDalRila, with two fet-hahs, and tiDilRili, with two kesrehs, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA,) meaning AlbaATil [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He fell into that which was vain, unreal, nought, futile, or the like, and consequently, into disappointment]: (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, waqaEuwA fI wAdI tDlRl means (tropical:) They perished. (TA.)

TariyqN muDilRN A road that causes to go astray, or to deviate from the right course. (TA.) And, accord. to As, muDilRN signifies A land (OaroDN) in which one loses his way. (TA. [See also the next paragraph.]) [Hence,] fitonapN muDilRapN means [A trial, or sedition, or discord, &c.,] that causes men to go astray, or to deviate from that which is right. (TA.) And [hence also,] AlmuDilRu means The saraAb [or mirage]. (TA.)

maDalRapN a subst. like majobanapN and maboxalapN [i. e., as such, signifying A cause of erring, straying, going astray, or deviating from the right way or course or from that which is right, &c.]: (TA:) [and used in the manner of an epithet:] one says OaroDN maDalRapN A land that causes one to err, &c.: (TA:) or, as also maDilRapN↓, (S, O, Msb, K, TA, [in the CK miDalRapN,]) and DulaDilapN↓, (O, K,) a land in which one errs, or strays, from the [right] way; (S, O, Msb, K; *) in which one does not find the right way: and xaroqN mDlRpN [A desert, or farextending desert, &c., in which one errs, &c.]: it is used alike as masc. and fem. and pl.: but one says also OaraDuwna mDlRAtN. (TA.)
maDilRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muDalRalN: see DilRiylN, in two places.

mutaDaAlRN [part. n. of 6, q. v.]. One says, UinRaka tahodiI AlDRaAlRa walaA tahodiI AlmutaDaAlRa [Verily thou wilt direct aright the erring, &c., but thou wilt not direct aright him who feigns himself to be erring, &c.]. (S, O.)

1. DalaEa, aor.
DalaEa
, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. DaloEN, (S, O, Msb,) It, or (assumed tropical:) he, inclined, or declined: (S, O, K:) it, or (assumed tropical:) he, declined, or deviated, from that which was right, or true: (S, O, Msb, K:) (assumed tropical:) he acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, * O, * K.) You say, DalaEa Eanohu (tropical:) He deviated, or turned away, from him, or it; or he did so, acting wrongfully, &c.: and DalaEa Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) he acted wrongfully, &c., against him. (TA.) And DaloEuka maEa fulaAnK (S, O, Msb, * K *) (assumed tropical:) Thy inclining, (S, O, Msb, K,) and thy love, or desire, (S, O,) is with such a one [i. e. in unison with that of such a one]. (S, O, Msb, * K: * in the Msb and K, maEahu is put in the place of maEa fulaAnK.) And laA tanoquXi AlXRawokapa biAlXRawokapi faUinRa DaloEahaA maEahaA, (S, O, K,) or bimivolihaA [in the place of bAlXwkp], (Meyd,) [lit. Extract not thou the thorn by means of the thorn, or by means of the like of it, for its inclination is with it,] meaning, demand not aid, in the case of thy want, of him who is more benevolent to the person from whom the object of want is sought than he is to thee: (Meyd:) a prov.: (S, Meyd, O:) applied to the man who contends in an altercation with another, and says, “ Appoint thou between me and thee such a one; ” pointing to a man who loves what he [i. e. the opponent of the speaker] loves: (S, O, K:) the author of the K adds, it is said that it should by rule be DalaEaka, for they say DaliEa maEa fulaAnK, like fariHa, [as though meaning he inclined with such a one,] but they have contracted it; which is wonderful, in consideration with his having mentioned shortly before, DalaEa, like manaEa, as signifying maAla. (TA.) One says also, xaASamotu fulaAnFA fakaAna DaloEuka EalaIRa i. e. (assumed tropical:) [I contended in an altercation with such a one and] thy inclining [was against me]. (S, O.)

DaliEa, aor.
DalaEa
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. DalaEN, (Mgh, Msb,) means It (a sword, K, or a thing, Msb) was, or became, crooked, or curved: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and tDlRE↓ may mean the same: (Ham p. 80:) a poet says, (namely, Mohammad Ibn-'Abd-Allah El-Azdee, TA,)

L.foreign: EalaI DalaEK fiI matonihi wahowa qaATiEu

sense.s:
[And verily, or sometimes, or often, its owner bears the tried sword, notwithstanding crookedness in its broad side, it being sharp]: (S, O:) and (K) DalaEN signifies the being crooked, or curved, by nature; (S, O, K;) as also DaloEN; whence the saying, laOuqiymanRa DalaEaka and DaloEaka [I will assuredly straighten thy natural crookedness]: (K:) thus in the copies of the K; but this is a mistake, occasioned by the author's seeing in the T and M laOuqiymanRa DalaEaka and SalaEaka meaning Eawajaka, and his imagining both these nouns to be with D and to differ in the manner stated above: (TA:) you say, DaliEa, aor.
DalaEa
, inf. n. DalaEN i. e. he, or it, was, or became, crooked, or curved, by nature: (S, O:) or DalaEN in the camel is like gamozN in horses or the like, [meaning the limping, or halting, or having a slight lameness, in the hind leg,] and the verb is DaliEa; and the epithet [or part. n.] is DaliEN↓: (K:) or this is rather the explanation of DaloEN, with Z; (TA;) [or as Mtr says,] DaloE as meaning what resembles EarajN [or natural lameness] is correctly ZaloE: (Mgh:) but when it (i. e. the crookedness, TA) is not natural, one says, DalaEa, like manaEa, (K, TA,) [but this seems rather to relate to the meaning of “ limping, ” agreeably with what I have cited above from the Mgh,] and the inf. n. is DaloEN: (TA:) and the epithet [or part. n.] is DaAliEN↓. (K.)

DaluEa, [aor.
DaluEa
,] inf. n. DalaAEapN, He (a man, S, O, Msb, [and app. also a horse and the like, see its part. n. DaliyEN,]) was, or became, strong, or powerful; (S, O, Msb, K;) and strong, hard, or firm, in the OaDolaAE [or ribs]. (S, O, K. [The latter is said in Har p. 6 to be the primary meaning; and the former, metaphorical.])
DalaEa as syn. with taDalRaEa: see the latter.
DalaEa fulaAnFA He struck such a one upon his DilaE [or rib]. (K.)
2: see 4, in two places.

taDoliyEu AlOaEomaAli is said by some to mean (assumed tropical:) The making deeds to deviate from the right, or direct, way or course: and by some to mean (assumed tropical:) the making them heavy, or burdensome. (Har p. 77.)
taDoliyEu AlvRawobi signifies The figuring the garment, or piece of cloth, with the form of OaDolaAE [or ribs]. (S, O, K.) [See also the pass. part. n., below.]

4. ADlEhu, (K,) inf. n. UiDolaAEN, (S, O,) It, or he, made it, or (assumed tropical:) him, to incline, or decline; (S, O, K;) [and so DlREhu↓; for] AlUiDolaAEu and AltRaDoliyEu signify AlUimaAlapu. (Har p. 77.)
[And It, or he, made it, or him, to be crooked, or curved; and so DlREhu↓; for] AlUiDolaAEu and AltRaDoliyEu signify also AltRaEowiyju. (Har ubi suprà.)
[Hence,] one says also, OaDolaEatohu AlxuTuwbu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Affairs, or great or grievous affairs,] burdened him [as though making him to incline, or curving him]. (TA.)
See also 8.
5. tDlRE: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

[Also,] (S, O, K,) and DalaEa↓, like manaEa, (K,) said of a man, (S, O,) He became filled, (S, O, K,) or what was between his OaDolaAE [or ribs] became filled, (TA,) with food, (S, O, K,) or drink: (S, O:) or with drink so that the water reached his OaDolaAE, (K, TA,) and they became swollen out in consequence thereof: (TA in explanation of the former verb:) and the former verb is also expl. as meaning he drank much, so that his side and his ribs became stretched. (TA.) And tDlRE mina AlTRaEaAmi He became filled with the food; as though it filled his ribs. (Msb.)

8. AlAiDoTilaAEu is from AlDRalaAEapu [inf. n. of DaluEa] meaning “ the being strong, or powerful; ” (ISk, S, O, and Har p. 391;) AlAiDoTilaAEu biAlXRaIoCi signifying The raising the thing upon one's back, and rising with it, and having strength, or power, sufficient for it. (Har ibid.) And you say, ADTlE biHamolihi, meaning He had strength, or power, to bear it, or carry it. (Mgh, and Har p. 645.) [See also the part. n., below.] And biAlOamori OaDolaEa↓ (assumed tropical:) He had strength, or power, sufficient for the affair; as though his ribs had strength to bear it. (Msb.)
DaloEN: see DilaEN, first sentence.
DiloEN: see DilaEN, first and last sentences.

DalaEN The weight, or burden, of debt, that bends the bearer thereof. (IAth, O, K.) And Strength, or power; (As, S, O, Msb, K;) a subst. in this sense, from DaluEa; (Msb;) and the bearing, or endurance of that which is heavy, or burdensome. (As, S, O, K.)
Also inf. n. of DaliEa [q. v.]. (Mgh, Msb, K.)

DaliEN Crooked, or curved, by nature. (S, O, TA.) And applied to a spear as meaning Crooked, or curved; not straightened: (TA:) or, so applied, inclining, or bending: (Ham p. 80:) and DaliyEN↓ and DaAliEN↓, so applied,
[likewise] mean crooked, or curved. (TA.)
See also 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.

DilaEN and DiloEN↓, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former of the dial. of El-Hijáz and the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (Msb, TA,) and DaloEN↓, which is the only form, or almost the only one, that is used by the vulgar, is said by MF to be mentioned by some one or more of the commentators, but not known in the lexicons, (TA;) [A rib;] a certain appertenance of an animal, (Msb,) well known; (K;) the curved thing of the side; (TA;) a single bone of the bones of the side: (Mgh, Msb:) of the fem. gender, (Msb, K, TA,) accord. to common repute; or, as some say, masc.; or, accord. to some, whose opinion in this case is preferred by Ibn-Málik and others, of both genders: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] DuluwEN and [of pauc.] OaDolaAEN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and OaDoluEN, (O, Msb, K,) and OaDaAliEu also is a pl. of DilaEN, or, as some say, of [its pl.] OaDoluEN. (TA.) DilaEu Alxalofi [and Alxilofi] is [The rib] in the lowest part of the side [of a man, i. e. the lowest rib; and the hindmost rib in a beast]: (TA:) and signifies also A burn in the part behind what is thus termed. (O, K, TA.)

Also (assumed tropical:) A piece of stick or wood; syn. EuwdN; [erroneously supposed by Golius and Freytag to mean here the musical instrument thus called;] (IAar, O, K;) so in a saying of the Prophet to a woman, respecting a blood-stain on a garment, HutRiyhi biDilaEK (assumed tropical:) [Scrape thou it off with a piece of stick]: (IAar, O:) or (assumed tropical:) such as is wide and curved; as being likened to the DilaE (O, K) of an animal. (K.)
And (tropical:) An oblong piece of a melon; (O, * K, TA;) as being likened to the DilaE [properly thus called]. (O, TA.)
And (tropical:) A trap for birds; because of its gibbous shape: so in the saying, naSaba DilaEFA lilTRayori [He set up a trap for the birds]. (A, TA.)
And The base, or lower part, of a raceme of a palm-tree. (TA in art. Ehn.)
And (assumed tropical:) A line that is made on the ground, after which another line is made, and then the space between these two is sown. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) A small mountain apart from others: (S, O, K:) or a small mountain, such as is not long: (TA:) or a low and narrow mountain, (Aboo-Nasr, S, O, K, TA,) long and extended: or, accord. to As, a small mountain, extending lengthwise upon the earth, not high. (TA.) And [the pl.] DuluwEN signifies (tropical:) Curved tracts of ground: or tracks (TaraAYiq) of a [piece of stony ground such as is termed] HarRap. (O, K, TA.)
Also (assumed tropical:) An island in the sea; pl. OaDolaAEN: or, as some say, it is the name of a particular island. (TA.)
[In geometry, (assumed tropical:) A side of a rectilinear triangle or square or polygon.
And (assumed tropical:) A square root; called in arithmetic jacorN: see XaIoCN, near the end of the paragraph.]

One says also, humo EalaIRa DilaEN jaAYirapN, (S, A, O, K, in the last of which, between hm and ElIR is inserted kacaA,) and DiloEN↓ is allowable, (S, TA,) meaning (tropical:) They are assembled against me with hostility: (A, TA:) the origin of which is the saying of AZ, one says, humo EalaIRN UilobN waAHidN [or OalobN waAHidN] and SadoEN waAHidN and DilaEN waAHidN, meaning as above. (TA.)
DilaEapN A certain small fish, green (xaDoraMC), short in the bone. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
DaliyEN: see DaliEN:
and see also maDoluwEN, in three places.

Also, applied to a man, (S, O, Msb,) Strong, or powerful; (S, O, Msb, K;) and strong, hard, or firm, in the OaDolaAE [or ribs]: (S, O, K:) or, as some say, long in the OaDolaAE, great in make, bulky; applied to any animal, even to a jinnee: (TA:) pl. DuloEN, (K,) or app., DuluEN [of which the former may be a contraction]. (TA.) And, applied to a horse, Complete, or perfect, in make or formation, large in the middle, thick in the [bones called] OalowaAH, having many sinews: (ISk, S, O, K:) or, so applied, thick in the OalowaAH; strong, hard, or firm, in the sinews: (Msb:) or, as some say, long in the ribs (AlOaDolaAE), wide in the sides, large in the breast. (TA.) And DaliyEu Alfami A man large in the mouth: (Kt, O, K:) or wide therein: (A 'Obeyd, O, K:) expl. in the former sense, and in the latter, as applied to the Prophet; (O, TA;) width of the mouth, (Kt, O, K, TA,) and largeness thereof, (TA,) being commended by the Arabs, and smallness thereof being discommended by them; (Kt, O, K, TA;) whereas the Persians, or foreigners, (AlEajam,) commend smallness thereof: (TA:) or having large teeth, closely and regularly set together; (Sh, O, K;) and thus also expl., by Sh, as applied to the Prophet: (O, TA:) and DaliyEu AlvRFnaAyaA a man whose central incisors are thick. (TA.)
DaAliEN Inclining, or declining: (TA: [like ZiAliEN:]) declining, or deviating, from that which is right, or true: acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, O, K, TA.)
See also DaliEN.
And see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.
DawolaEN (tropical:) Inclining with love or desire. (IAar, O, K, TA.)

OaDolaEu, applied to a man, [and accord. to the CK to a beast (daAbRap) also,] Whose tooth is like the DilaE [or rib]; (Lth, O, K;) fem. DaloEaMCu [perhaps applied to the tooth, but more probably, I think, to a woman]; (TA;) and pl. DuloEN. (K.)
Also, (O, [but accord. to the K “ or, ”]) Strong, thick, (O, K, TA,) large in make. (TA.)
And Stronger, or more powerful. (O, * TA.)

muDoliEN A load heavily burdening, or overburdening, (S, IAth, O, K, TA,) to the OaDolaAE [or ribs]; (TA;) as though leaning, or bearing, upon the OaDolaAE: (IAth, TA:) or a heavy load, which one is unable to bear; as also muDalRiEN↓. (Har p. 77.) [See also muZoliEN.] And, daAhiyapN muDoliEapN (tropical:) A calamity that heavily burdens, or overburdens, and breaks, the OaDolaAE [or ribs]. (TA.)
And daAbRapN muDoliEN A beast whose OaDolaAE [or ribs] have not strength sufficient for the load. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, L, K.)
See also muDoTaliEN.

muDalRaEN A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with stripes, like thongs, or straps, (O, K, TA,) these being of Uiboriysam, or of qazR, [i. e. silk, or raw silk,] wide, like OaDolaAE [or ribs]: (TA:) or [simply] figured: (Lh, TA:) or variously woven, and thin: (TA:) or partly woven and partly left unwoven. (ISh, Az, O, K, TA.)
And qubRapN muDalRaEapN [A ribbed dome or cupola; i. e.] having the form of OaDolaAE. (TA.)
muDalRiEN: see muDoliEN.
maDoluwEN Having the DilaE [or rib] broken. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

And qawosN maDoluwEapN A bow in the wood of which are a bending (EaTofN) and an evenness (taqawRumN, as in the O and K, or taqowiymN, as in the L), [app. towards each extremity,] the rest of it (saAYiruhaA) being similar to its kabid [which means its middle part, or part where it is grasped with the hand, or part against which the arrow goes, &c., for it is variously explained]; (O, K, TA;) so accord. to As, (O, TA,) and AHn; (TA;) as also DaliyEN↓, (O, K, TA,) and DaliyEapN↓; for which last, maDoluwEapN is erroneously repeated in the K; [app. from its author finding it said in the O that such a bow is termed DaliyEN and maDoluwEapN; and in the TK, muDawolaEapN is substituted for it:] qawosN DaliyEapN↓ is also expl. as meaning a thick bow. (TA.)

muDoTaliEN is from AlDRalaAEapu [inf. n. of DaluEa]: so in the saying, fulaAnN muDoTaliEN bihecaA AlOamori i. e. Such a one is possessed of strength, or power, sufficient for this affair: so says ISk: and he adds that one should not say muTRaliEN: Aboo-Nasr Ahmad Ibn- Hátim says, one says huwa muDoTaliEN bihecaA AlOamori and muTRaliEN lh [also]; AlAiDoTilaAEu being from AlDRalaAEapu meaning AlquwRapu; and AlAiTRilaAEu being from AlEuluwRu, from the saying AiTRalaEotu AlvRaniyRapa meaning EalawotuhaA [I ascended upon the mountain, or mountain-road, termed vaniyRap]; i. e. he is one who has ascendancy with respect to this affair, who is master of it: (S, O, TA:) Lth expressly allows muTRaliEN for muDoTaliEN by the incorporation of the D into the [letter that is originally] t, so that the two together become T with teshdeed. (TA.) And lihecaA AlOamori huwa muDoliEN↓ means the same as muDoTaliEN as first expl. above, i. e. He is possessed of strength, or power, sufficient for this affair. (O, K. [In both, in this instance, lihecaA, not bihecaA.]) In the phrase UicaA kaAna muDoTaliEFA EalaI HaqRihi [If he be possessed of power, or ability, to obtain his right, or due], it seems that mDTlEA is made trans. by means of ElI because made to imply the meaning of qaAdirFA or muqotadirFA. (Mgh.) musotaDoliEN↓,
likewise, signifies Having strength, or power. (TA.)
musotaDoliEN: see what next precedes.

1. DamRahu, [aor.
Damuma
,] inf. n. DamRN, He drew it, put it, brought it, or gathered it, together; collected it; or contracted it. (Msb.) You say, DamRa XayoYFA UilaI XaIoCN, (S, MA, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, He drew, put, or brought, together [and joined or adjoined] a thing to a thing. (MA, K.) And Damamotuhu UilaI SadoriI [I drew him, or pressed him, to my bosom;] I embraced him. (TA.) And DamRa Alqawomu, [Oanofusahumo being app. understood, or perhaps it is correctly DumRa,] The people, or party, collected themselves together, or became collected. (TA.) And AallRahumRa QDomumo naXariI (assumed tropical:) O God, compose what is discomposed, or disorganized, [lit. bring together what is scattered,] of my affairs. (K * and TA in art. nXr.) And DumRa janaAHaka Eani AlnRaAsi (assumed tropical:) [Contract thy side from men;] meaning be thou gentle, courteous, easy to deal with, or compliant, to men. (TA.) And DumRato Ealayohi AlOanaAmilu The ends of the fingers were drawn together upon it. (Ham p. 21. [See also a similar phrase in what follows, with the verb in the act. form, virtually meaning the same.])
[Also He compacted it: and he compressed it.

And He, or it, comprised it; or enclosed it: and he grasped it: as also DamRa Ealayohi, in both of these senses.] You say, DamRato Ealayohi AlOanaAmilu The ends of the fingers grasped it. (Ham p. 21. [See a similar phrase above.]) And DamRa EalaI AlmaAli He took [or grasped] all the property. (TA.) And DamRa mino maAlihi He took of his property. (TA.)

[DamRa AlHarofa, aor. and inf. n. as above, a conventional phrase in lexicology and grammar, He pronounced the letter with the vowel-sound termed DamR: and he marked the letter with the sign of that vowel-sound.]

3. DAmRhu, (S, MA, K, TA,) inf. n. muDaAmRapN, (TA,) He became, or drew, near, or close, to him; he became conjoined with him; (MA;) i. q. Uilayohi AnDmR↓; (S, * MA, K; *) and tDAmR↓. (K.) And DaAmamotu AlrRajula I continued conjoined with the man occupied in one affair. (TA.) And DAmR AlXRaIoCu UilaI AlXRaIoCi The thing became [adjoined to the thing, or] conjoined with the thing. (TA.) See also 6.
4. OaDomamotuhu kitaAbFA UilaI OaxiI [app. I made him, or it, to be accompanied by, or I made it to comprise, a letter to my brother]. (TA.)
5. taDamRamotuhu I took it, or devoured it, altogether. (TA in art. Eb.) [See also R. Q. 1.]

6. taDaAmRuwA They became, or drew, near, or close, together, or one to another; or became conjoined, one with another. (S, MA, TA. [See also 8.]) Hence the saying in a trad., laA taDaAmRuwna fiI ruWoyatihi [originally tataDaAmRuwna]; but some relate it otherwise, saying lA tuDaAmRuwna↓; and some, lA tuDaAmuwna, from AlDRayomu; (TA in this art.;) and some, lA tuDaArRuwna; and some, lA tuDaAruwna, from AlDRayoru. (TA in art. Dr: for explanations, see 3 in that art.) See also 3 above. [Hence,] tDAmR fiI sujuwdihi wajuluwsihi [He drew himself together in his prostration and his sitting, in prayer]. (S, * and K in art. Hfz.)

7. AnDmR It was, or became, drawn, put, brought, or gathered, together; collected; or contracted. (Msb.) AnDmR Uilayohi is syn. with DaAmRahu, q. v. (S, * MA, K. *) [And it signifies also He adjoined himself, got him or got himself, betook him or betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to him, or it. And AnDmR Ealayohi It became drawn together upon it. AnDmR AlI kacaA is expl. in the TA as meaning AinoTawaI: but I think that AlI is evidently a mistranscription for EalaI; and that the meaning therefore is, It infolded such a thing, or enclosed it, like ADTmR Elyh, q. v.]
8. ADTmR AlXRaIoCa He drew, brought, or gathered, the thing to himself: (K:) the T is substituted for t because of the D. (Az, TA.)

Hence, in a trad., ADTmR baEoDuhumo UilaI baEoDK [They drew near, or close, one to another]. (TA. [See also 6.]) And, in another trad., ADTmR Ealayohi AlnRaAsu The people, or men, pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together upon him. (TA.)
And ADTmR Ealayohi It comprised it, or enclosed it. (K.) You say, AiDoTamRato Ealayohi AlDRuluwEu The ribs comprised it, or enclosed it. (S. [See also 7.])
R. Q. 1. DamoDama EalaI AlmaAli He took all the property; (K;) as though he drew it, or gathered it, (DamRahu,) to himself. (TA.) [See also 5.]
And DamoDama He (a man, TA) encouraged his heat; or became courageous in heart. (K, accord. to different copies.)
And, said of a lion, He [roared, or] uttered a cry: (K, TA:) inf. n. DamoDamapN. (TA.)
DamRN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, &c.)
[As a conventional term of lexicology and grammar, A certain vowel-sound, well known.]

AlDRimRu and AlDRimaAmu↓ Severe calamity or misfortune; (K, TA;) accord. to Lth: (TA:) but app. mistranscriptions, and correctly with S [i. e. AlSRimRu and, by implication, AlSRimaAmu, but the latter is app. only SamaAmi, without the art., like qaTaAmi]; (K, TA;) so says Az. (TA.)
DamRapN [inf. n. un. of 1 (q. v.): and as such signifying] An embracing. (TA.)
Also A number of horses assembled from every quarter for a race: (K, TA:) thus called because so assembled. (TA.)
[And, as a conventional term in lexicology and grammar, The sign of the vowel-sound termed DamR.]
DumaAmN: see what next follows.

DimaAmN, (S, KL,) with kesr; (S;) or DumaAmN↓, like guraAbN; (K;) [the former app. the right, being agreeable with analogy, like ribaATN and wivaAqN and UisaArN and EiqaAlN &c.;] A thing, (S, K,) or thread, string, cord, or the like, (KL,) by means of which one thing is drawn, and joined, or adjoined, to another thing. (S, K, KL.) One says, AltRaqowaI DimaAmu Alxayori kulRihi [Piety is that which draws and attaches to its possessor every good thing]. (TA.)
See also AlDRimRu, above.

DamuwmN Any valley along which one goes between two long hills of the kind termed Oakamap: or any valley flowing [with water] between two long hills of that kind: (so accord. to different copies of the K:) [the former explanation is app. the right; for] AHn says, when one goes along a valley between two long hills of the kind termed Oakamap, that places is termed AlDRamuwm. (TA.)
DamiymN [i. q. maDomuwmN↓]. One says, Oarosalotu fulaAnFA wajaEalotu Damiymahu fulaAnFA [I sent such a one, and made such a one his adjunct]. (TA.)
DimaAmapN: see UiDomaAmapN.

DimaAmataA AlmuSoHafi means The two sides [or boards] of the book, that embrace it between them. (T and M and TA voce dafRapN.) And in like manner, DimaAmataA AlsRaroji and AlrRaHol [The two boards of the horse's saddle and of the camel's saddle, that embrace it between them]. (M ibid.)
DamRaAmN One who collects together the seed-produce. (TA.)
DaAmRN act. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.)

DaAmRapN [a subst. from DaAmRN, rendered such by the affix p]. You say, nahaDa fulaAnN liloqitaAli wahuwa DaAmRapu qawomihi [Such a one rose and sped to fight, or to the fight, he being the musterer of his people, or party]. (TA.)
Also A want, or an object of want, that brings one and causes him to have recourse [to a thing]. (Meyd, in explanation of a prov. cited voce DaAYimN, in art. Dym, q. v.)
DamoDamN A lion that grasps everything; as also DumaADimN↓. (S.) [See also DamoDaAmN: and see what here follows.]
Also, (S,) Angry; (S, K;) applied to a man: (S:) and, as also DumaADimN↓ and SumaDimN↓, an angry lion: (K, TA:) or simply a lion: (TA:) and bold, or daring; (K, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)
And Big, bulky, or corpulent: (K, TA:) but it is mentioned by IAar as with the unpointed S. (TA.)
DumaDimN: see DamoDamN.
Also Niggardly in the utmost degree. (IAar, TA.) [See also DumaADimN.]
DimoDimapN: see zimozimapN and SimoSimapN.
DamoDaAmN One who takes, or gets, everything within his grasp; (K, TA;) drawing it to him self. (TA.) [See also DamoDamN.]
DumaADimN: see DamoDamN, in two places.

Also
One who eats much; who has an inordinate appetite for food; who appropriates to himself exclusively of others: or who eats much, and does not become satiated. (TA.)
And A niggardly man. (TA.) [See also DumaDimN.]

UiDomaAmapN A bundle, (HuzomapN, Msb,) or number put, or joined, together, (TA,) i. q. UiDobaArapN, (S, TA,) of books or writings; (S, Msb, TA;) as also DimaAmapN↓: (TA:) pl. of the former OaDaAmiymu. (S.) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN biUiDomaAmapK mino kutubK [Such a one brought a bundle of books or writings]. (S.)

And A company, or collection, (S, K, TA,) of men, or people, not of one stock, but of different tribes mixed together; [and of horses;] as though collected and joined, one to another: pl. as above. (TA.) One says, farasN sabRaAqu AlOaDaAmiymi i. e. [A horse that often outstrips] the collections (S, K) of horses. (K.)
And its pl. OaDaAmiymu signifies also Stones: (TA:) or collections of stones: (Mgh in art. SqE:) occurring in a trad. respecting the stoning of an adulterer. (Mgh, TA.)
maDamRN A place of assembling of military forces. (TA.)
maDomuwmN pass. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.) See also DamiymN.
munoDamRN [part. n. of 7, q. v.
Hence,] Lean; or slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; as though one part thereof were drawn and adjoined to another. (TA.)
Q. 4: accord. to some, but Q. Q. accord. to most. AiDomaHalRa: see art. DHl.
Q. 4. AiDomaHanRa i. q. AiDomaHalRa [q. v. in art. DHl]; formed from the latter by substitution [of n for l: mentioned by Yaakoob. (TA: and mentioned in the K in art. DmHl.)
1: see the next paragraph.

2. DmRxhu biAlTRiybi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. taDomiyxN; (S, A, K;) and Damaxahu↓, (ISd, TA,) aor.
Damuxa
, (TK,) inf. n. DamoxN; (ISd, K;) He daubed, or smeared, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) him, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or his body, (L, K,) with perfume, or some odoriferous or fragrant substance, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) copiously, (L,) so that it seemed to drip. (L, K.) It is said in a trad., kaAna yuDamRixu raOosahu biAlTRiybi He [Mohammad] used to daub, or smear, his head copiously with perfume. (L.)

5. tDmRx biAlTRiybi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and AnDmx↓, and AiDoTamaxa↓, (K,) and AiDRamaxa↓, (L,) He daubed or smeared himself, or he became daubed or smeared, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) copiously, (L,) with perfume, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that it seemed to drip. (L, K.)
7: see what next precedes.
8. AiDoTamaxa, and its var. AiDRamaxa: see 5.
DimoxapN A fat woman or she-camel. (K.)
And Fresh ripe dates (ruTab [so in copies of the K, accord. to the TA raTob, app. a mistranscription,]) from which something drips.

1. Damada AljuroHa, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
Damuda
(S, L, K) and
Damida
, (K,) inf. n. DamodN; (S, L;) and DmRdhu↓, (A, K,) inf. n. taDomiydN; (TA;) He bound the wound (and in like manner one says of other things, L) with a DimaAd or DimaAdap i. e. a bandage, or fillet, (S, A, L, K,) or kerchief. (A.) This is the primary signification. (L.) And Damada raOosahu, (L,) or biDimaAdK DmRdhu↓, (Lth,) He wound a piece of rag round his head, after anointing it, or wetting it with water: (Lth, L:) and DmRd↓ raOosahu, inf. n. taDomiydN, He bound his head with a fillet, or bandage, (S, A,) or a kerchief, (A,) or a piece of cloth, not a turban. (S.) And Damada AljuroHa, inf. n. DamodN, also signifies He applied a remedy [or dressing] to the wound, without bandaging it. (L.) And Eayonayohi biAlSRabiri DmRd↓ He applied aloes to his eyes. (L, from a trad.) And Damadaha biAlzRaEofaraAni waAlSRabiri He smeared him, or it, over, [or poulticed him, or it,] with saffron and aloes. (Az, L.)

And AuDomudo Ealayoka viyaAbaka Bind thou upon thee thy garments, (Ibn-Málik, A,) and EimaAmataka [thy turban]. (A.) And Oujido Damoda hecaA AlEidoli Make thou good the binding of this half-load. (L.)

And Damadahu (assumed tropical:) He struck him, or hit him, on his head with a staff or stick: (S, K:) sometimes used in this sense: (S:) or he cut, or wounded, (A, L,) him (L,) or it, i. e. his head, (A,) in the place of the turban, with a sword; syn. EamRamahu. (A, L.)
DamodN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The treating with gentleness, or blandishment; soothing, coaxing, wheedling, or cajoling; or striving, endeavouring, or desiring, to do so. (S, L, K,)

And Damadato, (A, L,) aor
Damida
and
Damuda
, (L,) inf. n. DamodN (AA, S, L, K) and DimaAdN, (Fr, A, L,) (tropical:) She (a woman) took to herself two friends, (S, A, L, K,) or secret friends, or amorous associates, (A,) together: (S, A, L, K:) or she took another man beside her husband (AA, A, L) as her friend, or secret friend, or amorous associate; (A;) or two other men: (AA, L;) or she associated as a friend with two or three men in a time of drought, in order that she might eat with one and then with another so as to satiate herself. (Fr.) And Damadatohu, aor, as above, (assumed tropical:) She (a woman having a husband or a friend [or lover]) took him (another man) as her friend [or lover]. (L.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,

L.foreign: wahalo yujomaEu AlsRayofaAni wayoHaki fiI gimodi

sense.s: (assumed tropical:) [Thou desirest to take me as thy lover together with Khálid: but can the two swords (mercy on thee) be combined in one scabbard?]. (S, L.) And one says, DamadaAhaA (assumed tropical:) They both associated as friends [or lovers] with her, or made love to her. (L.)

Damida, aor.
Damada
, It dried; (Hr, L, K;) said of blood upon the throat of a slaughtered sheep or goat. (Hr, L.)
Also, inf. n. DamadN, He acted wrongfully, or injuriously, or unjustly. (L.)

And Damida Ealayohi, aor.
Damada
, inf. n. DamadN, He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him: (S, L, K: *) or held fast rancour, &c., against him in his heart. (L.) And He was angry with him: or vehemently enraged against him and angry with him: or he was enraged against him; i. e. one over whom he had power to vent his rage. (L.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, in four places.
4. OaDomadahumo (tropical:) He collected them together. (K, TA.)
And ADmd AlEarofaju The [plant called] Erfj contained its xuwSap [q. v.] lying hidden within it, not yet appearing. (S, K. *)
5. tDmRd It (a wound) was bound with a bandage or fillet [or kerchief (see 1)]. (K.) It (a man's head) was bound with a bandage or fillet [or kerchief] or with a piece of cloth, not a turban. (S.)
[And tDmRd bihi He used it, or applied it, as a poultice or the like.]

DamodN Such as is fresh, or moist, of herbage or trees: and such as is dry thereof: (S, * L, K: *) thus having two contr. meanings: (K:) or fresh and dry herbage mixed together: and herbage of which every twig, or shoot, has put forth its leaves. (L.) DamodN mina AldRami means Such as is dry of blood; dry blood. (L.)

Also The better, or best, and the worse, or worst, of sheep or goats: (S, L, K:) or the young, and the old: or such as are in a sound, or good, state, and such as are in an unsound, or a bad, state: or the slender, and the large. (L.) A man says to his creditor, OaqoDiyka mino Damodi hecihi Alganami [I will pay thee with some of the better, or best, or of the worse, or worst, &c., of these sheep or goats]. (S.)
DimodN (assumed tropical:) A friend; or a true, or sincere, friend; or a special, or particular, friend. (K.)

DamadN A remainder, that is due to one, of a fine for blood, or of any other debt. (S, K.) One says, lanaA Einoda fulaAnK DamadN A remainder of a fine for blood, or of another debt, is owed to us by such a one. (S.)
EabodN DamadapN A bulky, thick, slave. (El-Hejeree, TA.)

DimaAdN A bandage, or fillet, (S, A, K,) or a kerchief, (A,) that is bound upon a wound; (S, A, K;) as also DimaAdapN↓: (S, K:) and a piece of rag that is wound round the head, after anointing it, or wetting it with water: (Lth, L:) and sometimes put upon the head on account of a headache: pl. DamaAYidu. (L.)
Also A remedy [or dressing, such as a poultice and the like,] that is applied to a wound. (Ibn-Háni.)
DimaAdapN: see DimaAdN.

OanaA EalaI DimaAdapK mina AlOamori
means I have become on the point, or verge, of the affair, or event. (S.)
DaAmidN i. q. laAzimN [Cleaving, clinging, holding fast, &c.]. (AHn.)

miDomadapN [A sort of yoke;] a piece of wood which is put upon the necks of the two bulls [in ploughing], having at each extremity a perforation, and between the two perforations, in its upper side, a notch [app. for the tying of the beam of the plough thereto so that it may not shift from the middle], each of the perforations having a string put into it with the two ends thereof coming forth beneath the mDmdp, and each end of the string having a [short] staff, or stick, tied to it; the neck of the bull being put between the two staves, or sticks. (TA.)

1. Damara, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Damura
; (S, Msb, K;) and Damura; (S, Msb, K;) inf. n. DumuwrN, of the former, and DumorN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the former also, (A, Mgh,) or of the latter, (Msb,) [also written DumurN, (see an ex., voce nahaArN,)] He (a horse, [&c.,] S, A, &c.) was, or became, lean, or light of flesh: (S:) or slender, and lean: (Msb:) or lean, and lank in the belly: (A, K:) or lank in the belly by reason of leanness: (Mgh:) and ADTmr↓ signifies the same. (S, K.) [See also 5 and 8.]
Also, inf. n. DumuwrN, He became lean and weak. (TA.)
Damura AlEinabu (assumed tropical:) The grapes became withered, so as to be neither fresh grapes nor raisins. (Sgh.)
Damarati AlHinoTapu (assumed tropical:) The wheat, being parched over the fire, became contracted and small. (Mgh.)
2. DmRrhu, inf. n. taDomiyrN, He made him (a horse) lean, or light of flesh; [&c.;] as also ADmrhu↓. (S.)

He prepared him (i. e. a horse) for racing, [or for a military expedition, (see muDamRirN,)] by feeding him with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after he had become fat; as also ADmrhu↓. (Msb:) he fed him with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after he had become fat; as also ADmrhu↓: (K:) or he fed him with fodder so that he became fat, and then reduced him to food barely sufficient to sustain him; which is done during forty days: (S:) or he saddled him, and put on him a housing, in order that he might sweat under it, and so lose his flabbiness, and become firm in flesh; and then mounted upon him a light boy or young man, to make him run, but not to make him go so quick a pace as that which is termed Eanaq; by the doing of which, one becomes in no fear of his losing his breath in running, and a quick run does not cut him short: this (says AM) is what I have seen the Arabs practise; and they term it taDomiyrN, and also miDomaArN↓. (T, L.)
Also He, or it, weakened, and subdued, and diminished, him: and the same signification is assigned to it [tropically] when the objective complement is a word denoting a sensation or passion. (TA.)
AltRaDomiyru also signifies The plaiting well, and the anointing well, the lock of hair termed Damiyrap. (TA.)
4: see 2, in three places.
ADmrhu signifies also He determined, or resolved, upon it, fiI Damiyrihi in his heart, or mind. (Msb.)
He conceived it in his heart, or mind. (MA, KL.)
He concealed it, syn. OasarRahu, (A,) or OaxofaAhu, (K,) fiI qalobihi in his heart, (A,) or fI nafosihi in his mind. (S.)
[And hence, He suppressed it, (namely a word or the like,) meaning it to be understood.
And hence also ADmr meaning He made use of a pronoun.]
And ADmr Sarofa AlHarofi [He suppressed the vowel of the final letter;] he made the movent [final] letter quiescent. (TA.)

And OaDomaratuhu AlbilaAdu (tropical:) The lands, or countries, hid him, by his having travelled far: (A:) and ADmrth AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) the earth hid him, either by reason of travel, or by death. (K, TA.)
ADmr is also syn. with AisotaqoSaI [q. v.]. (O, K.) [Accord. to the TK, one says ADmr AlXRaIoCa meaning AstqSAhu.]
5. tDmRr wajohuhu His face became shrivelled, or contracted, by emaciation. (Sgh, L, K.)
7. AnDmr It (a branch, or twig,) became dried up. (TA.)
8. ADTmr: see 1.
Also He, (a horse,) after having been fed until he had become fat, was reduced to food barely sufficient to sustain him. (TA.) [See 2.]
DamorN: see DaAmirN, in two places.

Hence, in the opinion of ISd, as he says in the M, it is also applied to a horse as meaning daqiyqu AlHajaAjayoni [i. e. Thin in the bones surrounding, or projecting over, the cavities of the eyes: in the TA, AlhjAjyn, an obvious mistranscription; and in the TK, AlHjAjtyn, which is also wrong]: on the authority of Kr: in the copies of the K, AlHaAjibayoni. (TA.)
And Narrow; (O, K;) applied to a place. (O.)
And i. q. DamiyrN↓ [app. in the first of the senses assigned to the latter below]. (O, K: in the CK DimRiyr.) See also. muDomarN.

DamoraAnN (S, O, K) and DumoraAnN↓ (TA) A certain plant, (S, O, K,) of the shrub-kind (mino diqRi AlXRajari): (K:) or of the kind called HamoD: AM says, it is not of the shrub-kind, and has [what are termed] hadab [q. v.] like the hadab of the OaroTaI: (TA:) AHn says, it resembles the rimov, except that it is yellow (OaSofaru [app. a mistranscription for OaSogaru i. e. smaller]), and it has little wood, [and] the small and dry parts of its branches are fed upon [by the camels] (yuHotaTabu): he adds, on the authority of the ancient Arabs of the desert, that it is [of the kind called] HamoD, green, lank, pleasing to the camels: and Aboo-Nasr says that it is of the kind called HamoD. (O.)
See also what next follows.

DumoraAnu (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K, TA) and DamoraAn↓, thus, with fet-h, as said by As on the authority of ISk; each of the names of dogs; (TA;) a name of a male dog; (O, K;) not of a bitch, as J asserts it to be. (K.)
See also the next preceding paragraph.
DimaArN A place, or a valley, that is depressed, concealing him who is journeying in it. (O.) [Accord. to the K, AlDRimaAru is “ A place; ” i. e. the name of a certain place.]
maAlN DimaArN Property of which one hopes not for the return: (K:) or absent property of which one hopes not for the return: (A 'Obeyd, Msb, TA:) if not absent, it is not thus called. (A 'Obeyd, TA.)
dayonN DimaArN A debt of which the payment is not hoped for: (S:) or for the payment of which no period is fixed. (K, * TA.)
EaTaMCN DimaArN A gift that is not hoped for. (A.)

waEodN DimaArN, (S,) and EidapN DimaArN, (A, K, [mn AlEacAbi in the CK being a mistranscription for mina AlEidaAti, as in other copies of the K and in the TA, in which latter is added that EidaAt is pl. of EidapN, which is syn. with waEodN,]) A promise of which the fulfilment is not hoped for: (S, A:) or of which the fulfilment is delayed. (K.)
DimaArN also signifies Anything of which one is not confident, or sure. (S.)

And A debt of which the payment is deferred by the creditor to a future period; or a sale upon credit, in which the payment is deferred to a definite period; or a postponement, or delay, as to the time of the payment of a debt or of the prince of a thing sold &c.; syn. nasiyoYapN. (Fr, TA.)
Also Unseen; not apparent; contr. of EiyaAnN. (K.) A poet says, censuring a certain man,
[And his present gift is a thing not hoped for, like the unseen debt of which the payment is deferred by the creditor:] meaning, his present gift is like the absent that is not hoped for. (TA.)
cahabuwA bimaAliI DimaArFA means They took away my property by gaming. (Fr, TA.)
Also A certain idol, which was worshipped by El-Abbás Ibn-Mirdás. (O, K, TA. [It is implied in the K that it is with the art. Al; but it is not so accord. to the O and TA.])

DamiyrN A thing that thou concealest, or conceivest, or determinest upon, (tuDomiruhu,) in thy heart, or mind: (Lth, TA:) a secret; syn. sirRN: (K:) a subst. from OaDomara fiI nafosihi XayoYFA: (S:) pl. DamaAYiru. (S, K.)

[Hence used as meaning A pronoun; which is also termed muDomarN↓, and AisomN muDomarN, lit. a concealed noun, i. e. a noun of which the signification is not shown by itself alone; opposed to muZoharN: pl. of the first as above; and of the second muDomaraAtN.]
See also DamorN.

And AlDRamiyru signifies The heart [itself]; the mind; the recesses of the mind; the secret thoughts; or the soul; syn. qalobu AlUinosaAni, and baATinuhu, (Msb,) or daAxilu AlxaATiri: (A, K:) pl. as above, (Msb, K,) the sing. being likened to sariyrapN, of which the pl. is saraAYiru. (Msb.) [See also muDomarN. And see an ex. in a verse cited in art. syH, 7th conj.]
Also Withered, or shrivelled, grapes, (O, K,) that are neither fresh grapes nor raisins. (O.)

laqiytuhu biAlDRumayori is a phrase mentioned by Sgh [in
the O] as meaning I met him at sunset: but it is correctly [biAlSRumayori,] with the unpointed S. (TA.)
DamiyrapN A lock, or plaited lock, of hair, such as is termed DafiyrapN and gadiyrapN: pl. DamaAYiru. (As, TA.)

DaAmirN Lean, and lank in the belly; [&c.; see 1;] (A, K;) applied to a he-camel, (K,) and to a horse, as also DamorN↓, and muDamRarN↓, and muDoTamirN↓; (A;) and to a she-camel, (S, A, K,) as also DaAmirapN; (S;) [and to a man;] DaAmirN applied to a she-camel being regarded as a possessive epithet [signifying caAtu DumorK]: (TA:) and DamorN↓ signifies also lank in the belly, and small and slender in person; applied to a man: (S, A, K:) fem. with p: (A, K:) the pl. of DaAmirN is DumRarN. (Ham p. 473.)

And A horse in a state of preparation for racing, by his having been fed with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after having become fat: and you say xayolN DaAmirapN and DawaAmiru, meaning horses in that state. (Msb.)
Applied to grain, it means Thin, or slender: (Mgh:) and to a branch or twig, sapless; dried up; as also munoDamirN↓. (K.)

DawomaraAnN (S, O, Msb, K) and DawomuraAnN (Msb) and DamoyuraAnN↓ (O, Msb, K) and DayomaraAnN (Msb) A species of the rayaAHiyn [or sweet-smelling plants]: (S, O:) or of the wild rayoHaAn: (K:) or the rayoHaAn faArisiIR: (Msb, K:) Aboo-Nasr says that the DymrAn is the XaAhasofaram [or XaAhisofaram, i. e. basil-royal, or common sweet basil, ocimum basilicum]: AHn says, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of El-Yemen, that the DymrAn is exactly like the Hawok [which is one of the names now applied to sweet basil], of sweet odour, and is therefore asserted by some to be the XAhsfrm, but the DymrAn is wild; and he says that some call it DawomaraAn. (O.)
DayomuraAnN and DayomaraAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muDomarN Concealed, (K,) [or conceived,] in the mind. (S.) You say, hawFI muDomarN, meaning Concealed love; as also DamorN↓; as though the latter were believed to be an inf. n. [used in the sense of a pass. part. n.] from the unaugmented, for the augmented, verb. (TA.) See also DamiyrN.
Also The place of concealment, (K,) [or of conception,] in the mind. (S.) A poet, (S,) ElAhwas Ibn-Mohammad El-Ansáree, (TA,) says,

L.foreign: sataboqaI lahaA fiI muDomari Alqalobi waAlHaXaA

sense.s: [There will remain to her, in the hiding-place of the heart and the bowels, a secret love, (lit. a secret of love,) on the day when secrets shall be revealed]. (S, TA.)
muDamRarN: see DaAmirN.
muDamRirN One who prepares his horses, by reducing them to scanty food, (yuDamRiruhaA,) for a military expedition or for racing. (TA.)

miDomaArN A training-place in which horses are prepared for racing [or for military service] by being fed with food barely sufficient to sustain them, after they have become fat: (S, * Msb, K: *) [a hippodrome; a place where horses are exercised:] pl. maDaAmiyru. (A.) You say, jaraI fiI AlmiDomaAri [He ran in the hippodrome, or place of exercise]. (A.) And AlginaMCu miDomaAru AlXRiEori (tropical:) [app. meaning Singing is that in which the excellences of poetry are displayed, like as the excellences of a horse are displayed in the hippodrome]. (A.)

Also The time, of forty days, during which a horse is reduced to food barely sufficient to sustain him, after his having been fed with fodder so that he has become fat; (S, TA;) the time during which a horse is thus prepared for racing or for an expedition against the enemy: pl. as above. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aaloyawoma miDomaArN wagadFA QlosRibaAqu waAlsRaAbiqu mano sabaqa QlojanRapa [To-day is a time for training, and to-morrow is the race, and the winner is he who wins Paradise:] i. e., to-day one is to work, in the present world, for the desire of Paradise; like as a horse is trained for racing. (Sh.) [One of the explanations of AlmDmAr in the K is gaAyapu Alfarasi fiI AlsRibaAqi, or, as in the TA, lilsRibaAqi; app. meaning The goal, or limit, of the horse in racing: but in the TA, these words are made to form part of an explanation which I have given before, i. e., the time during which a horse is prepared for racing, &c.]
See also 2.
luWoluWN muDoTamirN Contracted pearls: (K:) or pearls having somewhat of contraction in the middle. (S.)
See also DaAmirN.
munoDamirN: see DaAmirN, last sentence.

1. Damina AlXRaIoCa, (IAar, S, K,) or AlmaAla, (Mgh, Msb,) and Damina bihi, (Msb, K,) aor.
Damana
, (K,) inf. n. DamaAnN (IAar, S, Msb, K) and DamonN, (K,) He was, or became, responsible, answerable, accountable, amenable, surety, or guarantee, (S, Mgh, K,) for the thing, (S, K,) or for the property: (Mgh:) or he made himself responsible, &c., for it; syn. Ailotazamahu; (Msb;) and so, in this sense, tDmRnhu↓, (S, * K,) quasi-pass. of DamRanahu: (S, K:) [as though he had it within his grasp, or in his possession; for] the primary signification of AlDRamaAnu is AltRaHoSiylu: (Msb:) some of the lawyers say that it is from AlDRamRu; but this is a mistake; (Msb, TA;) for the n is radical. (Msb.) And Damina lahu kacaA He was, or became, responsible, &c., to him for such a thing. (MA.) And Damina AlmaAla minoha He was, or became, responsible, &c., to him for the property [received from him]. (Mgh.)
See also 5, in four places.
Daminahu signifies also (assumed tropical:) He learned it; acquired a knowledge of it. (TA.)

And Damina, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Damana
, (K,) inf. n. DamanN, (S, Msb, K, *) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S) had, or was affected with, a malady of long continuance, or such as crippled him; (S, Msb, K;) was afflicted in his body (S, * K, TA) by some trial, or fracture, or other ailment. (S, * TA.) And Daminato yaduhu, inf. n. DamaAnapN, (assumed tropical:) His arm, or hand, was affected with a malady of long continuance, or such as crippled. (Fr, TA.)

2. DmRnhu AlXRaIoCa, (S, MA, K,) or AlmaAla, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. taDomiynN, (S,) He made him to be responsible, answerable, accountable, amenable, surety, or guarantee, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) for the thing, (S, MA, K,) or for the property. (Mgh, Msb.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce muEabRadN.]

DamRanotu AlXRaIoCa kacaA I made the thing to comprise, comprehend, or contain, such a thing. (Msb.) Hence, DamRana QllRehu OaSolaAba AlfuHuwli AlnRasola [God has made the loins of the stallions to comprise, in the elemental state, the progeny]. (Msb.) And DmRnhu AlwiEaMCa He put it (i. e. anything) into the receptacle. (S, K.) And DmRn AlmayRita Alqabora He deposited the dead body in the grave. (TA.) And DmRn AlkitaAba kacaA (assumed tropical:) He made the writing to comprise, or include, such a thing. (MA.) [And DmRn AlkalaAma kacaA (assumed tropical:) He made, or held, the sentence, or speech, or phrase, to imply such a thing. And DmRn Alkalimapa maEonaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He made the word to imply or import, such a meaning.]

AltRaDomiynu as a conventional term of those who treat of elegance of speech is (assumed tropical:) The making poetry to comprise a verse [of another poet]: (TA:) or the introducing into poetry a hemistich, or a verse, or two verses, of another poet, to complete the meaning intended, and for the purpose of corroborating the meaning, on the condition of notifying it as borrowed, beforehand, or of its being well known, so that the hearer will not imagine it to be stolen: and if it is a hemistich, or less than that, it is termed rafowN. (Har p. 267.) And as a conventional term of those who treat of versification, (assumed tropical:) The making a verse to be not complete otherwise than with what follows it. (TA.)
5: see 1, first sentence.

tDmRn AlXRaIoCu kacaA The thing comprised, comprehended, or contained, such a thing. (Msb.) Hence, taDamRanato OaSolaAbu AlfuHuwli AlnRasola and Daminatohu↓ [The loins of the stallions comprised, in the elemental state, the progeny]. (Msb.) And tDmRn Alqaboru AlmayRita The grave had the dead body deposited in it. (TA.) And tDmRn AlkitaAbu kacaA [and Daminahu↓] (assumed tropical:) The writing comprised, or included, such a thing. (S, MA, K.) And tDmRn AlkalaAmu kacaA [and Daminahu↓, as is indicated in the first sentence of this art.,] (assumed tropical:) The sentence, or speech, or phrase, comprehended, or comprised, within its scope, [or implied,] such a thing; syn. HaSRalahu. (Msb.) [And taDamRanati Alkalimapu maEonaI kacaA and Daminatohu↓ (assumed tropical:) The word implied such a meaning.]

DimonN (tropical:) The TaIR, (S, MA, K,) i. e. the inside, (MA, TK,) [lit. the folding,] of a writing, or letter. (S, MA, K, TA.) You say, Oanofacotuhu Dimona kitaAbiI i. e. fiI TayRihi (tropical:) [I sent it, or transmitted it, within the folding of my writing or letter; mean-
ing infolded, or enclosed, in it; included in it; or in the inside of it]. (S, TA.) And fiI Dimoni kalaAmihi [and kitaAbihi] means (assumed tropical:) Among the contents, or implications, of his speech [and of his writing or letter] (fI maTaAwiyhi); and the indications thereof. (Msb.)

A thing that satisfies the stomach: thus, maA OagonaI EanRiI fulaAnN DimonFA means Such a one did not stand me in stead, or supply my want, of anything, even as much as a thing that would satisfy the stomach. (IAar, TA.)

DamanN (S, K) and DamaAnN↓ and DamaAnapN↓ (S, Msb, K) (tropical:) A malady of long continuance, or such as cripples; (S, Msb, K, TA;) an affliction in the body, (S, * K, TA,) by some trial, or fracture, or other ailment; (S, TA;) and DumonapN↓ signifies the same; (K;) and [simply] a disease, or malady; (S, K;) as in the saying, kaAnato Dumonapu fulaAnK OarobaEapa OaXohurK (tropical:) [The disease of such a one was four months in duration]. (S, TA.) [See also 1, last two sentences.]
DamanN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A burden; syn. kalRN: so in the saying, fulaAnN DamanN EalaI OaSoHaAbihi [Such a one is a burden upon his companions]. (AZ, TA.)
It is also an epithet: see the next pargaraph.

DaminN (applied to a man, S) (assumed tropical:) Affected with a malady of long continuance, or such as cripples; (S, Msb, K, TA;) afflicted in the body, (S, * K, TA,) by some trial, or fracture, or other ailment: (S, TA:) and DamanN↓ signifies [the same; or simply] affected with a disease, or malady; applied to a man [and to two and more and to a female; being originally an inf. n.]; having no dual nor pl. nor fem. form: (TA:) pl. of the former DamonaI (S, * Msb, K, * TA) and Daminuwna, or the former of these is pl. of DamiynN↓ [which signifies the same as DaminN]. (TA.) Aikotataba DaminFA [in the CK DamanFA] means (assumed tropical:) He wrote himself down [as one affected with a malady of long continuance, &c., or] in the register of the DamonaI, i. e. the zamonaI; (S, K, TA;) i. e. he asked that he might write himself down [as such], and took for himself a billet from the commander of the army in order to excuse himself from fighting against the unbelievers: (TA:) of such it is said that God will raise him in that state on the day of resurrection. (S, TA.) maEobuwTapN gayoru DaminapK, occurring in a trad., means Slaughtered not having any disease. (TA.)
Also (tropical:) [Loving: (See DamaAnapN:) or] loving excessively, or admiringly. (K, TA.)
DumonapN: see DamanN.

DamaAnN an inf. n.: [see 1, first sentence:] (IAar, S, Msb, K:) [used as a simple subst.,] Responsibility, answerableness, accountability, amenability, suretiship, or guaranteeship; syn. kafaAlapN: (Mgh:) but it is more common [in signification] than kafaAlapN; for it sometimes signifies what is not kafaAlapN, namely, [indemnification; or] restoration of the like, or of the value, of a thing that has perished. (Kull.) [DamaAnu maAlK, and guromK, signify Responsibility, &c., for property, and for a debt, owed by another person. And DamaAnu nafosK, and HuDwrK, signify Responsibility, &c., for the appearance, or presence, of another person, to answer a suit.] DumaAn darak is a vulgar phrase; correctly DamaAnu AldRaraki [expl. in art. drk]. (TA.)
See also DamanN.
DamiynN: see DAminN:
and see also DaminN.
DamaAnapN: see DamanN.
Also (tropical:) Love: (K, TA:) [or] excessive, or admiring, love. (TA.)

DaAminN and DamiynN↓ One who is responsible, answerable, accountable, amenable, surety, or guarantee: (S, Msb, K:) both are mentioned by IAar as syn., like saAminN and samiynN. (TA.) God is represented by the Prophet as saying, mano xaraja mujaAhidFA fiI sabiyliI waQbotigaMCi maroDaAtiI faOanaA Ealayohi DaAminN wahuwa EalaIRa DaAminN, meaning [Whoso goes forth as a warrior in my cause, and seeking, or seeking earnestly, to obtain my approval,] I am responsible to him for what I have promised him, to recompense him living and dead; DAmn being made trans. by means of ElI because it implies the meaning of muHaAmK and raqiybN; and the last clause means nearly the same, but is rendered as meaning and he is one who has [a claim to] responsibility on my part, as though care and mindfulness [of him] were obligatory on me. (Mgh.) And it is said in a trad., AlUimaAmu DaAminN waAlmuWacRinu muWotamanN: (Mgh, JM, * TA:) [the latter clause has been expl. in art. Omn (voce OamiynN):] the former clause means, The imám [or leader of prayer] is as though he were responsible for the correctness of the prayer of those who follow him: (JM, TA: [and the like is said, with other, similar, explanations, in the Mgh:]) or it means, the imám is careful, or mindful, for the people [who follow him], of [the correctness of] their prayer. (TA.)
DaAminN and miDomaAnN↓ applied to a she-camel, signify Having a fœtus in her belly: and the pls. are DawaAminu and maDaAmiynu. (IAar, L and TA in art. lqH and in the present art.)
DaAminapN applied to rights, or dues, (Huquwq,) is used by Lebeed as meaning maDomuwnapN; [see maDomuwnN;] like as raAHilapN is used as meaning maroHuwlapN. (TA.)
DaAminapN [fem. of DaAminN, q. v.].

AlDRaAminapu signifies What is included within the middle of any town or country or the like. (TA.) AlDRaAminapu mina AlnRaxoli, (AO, S, K, * TA,) occurring in a letter of the Prophet, (AO, S, TA,) means What are included within the cities or towns or villages, of the palmtrees: (AO, S, K, * TA:) or what are surrounded, thereof, by the wall of the city: (K:) but Az says that they are so called because their owners are responsible for their culture and keeping: (TA:) opposed to AlDRaAHiyapu mn AlbRaEoli, which means what are in the open country, of the palm-trees that imbibe with their roots, without being watered. (AO, S, TA. *)
muDamRanN Water included in a mug or other vessel: and milk included in the udder. (TA.)

Also (assumed tropical:) Poetry made to comprise a verse [from another poem]. (S, K. [See 2, last sentence but one.]) And (assumed tropical:) A verse [made to be] not complete otherwise than with what follows it. (S, K. [See 2, last sentence.])

And (assumed tropical:) A sound [made to comprehend with it somewhat of another:] upon which one cannot pause without conjoining it with another: (K:) in the T it is said to be [such as is exemplified in] a man's saying qifo fula [or fulu, for qifo fulaAnu Pause thou, such a one], with making the l to have a smack of the vowel-sound (biUiXomaAmi AllRaAmi UilaI AlHarakapi). (TA.)
miDomaAnN: see DaAminN, last sentence but one.

maDomuwnN pass. part. n. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above: you say XaIoCN maDomuwnN [meaning A thing, such as property, or the payment of a debt, &c., ensured by an acknowledgment of responsibility for it]. (TA.)

maDomuwnu kitaAbK means maA fiI Dimonihi and TayRihi [i. e. The contents of a writing or letter; or what is infolded, or included, in a writing or letter; what is implied therein; and what is indicated therein]: pl. maDaAmiynu. (TA.)

And AlmaDaAmiynu, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) of which the sing. is maDomuwnN, (A 'Obeyd, Msb, K,) and one may also say maDomuwnapN, as meaning nasamapN, (Msb,) signifies What are [comprised] in the loins of the stallions; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K;) i. e. the progeny [thereof, in the elemental state]: (Msb:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, [though the reverse is generally held to be the case,] AlmalaAqiyHu signifies what are in the backs of the he-camels, and AlmaDaAmiynu what are in the bellies of the females. (L in art. lqH.) The selling of the mDAmyn and the mlAqyH is forbidden. (S.) [maDaAmiynu is also pl. of miDomaAnN, q. v.]
maDomuwnu Alyadi i. q. maxobuwnuhaA, (K,) meaning maEoluwluhaA [i. e. Diseased in the arm, or hand]; (TK;) applied to a man. (TA. [See 1, last sentence, which indicates a more particular meaning.])

1. DanRa bihi, (Mgh, Msb,) first pers. Daninotu bihi, (S, Msb, *) [and one may say Ealayohi, and Eanohu, in the place of bihi, (see DaniynN,)] and DaninuwA occurs, in a verse of Kaanab Ibn-Umm-Sáhib, used by poetic license for DanRuwA, (S,) aor.
Danana
; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and DanRa, (Msb,) first pers. Dananotu, (S, Msb, *) aor.
Danina
, (S, Msb, K,) accord to Fr, (S,) or, accord. to Th, Fr said, I have heard Dananotu, though I have not heard OaDinRu, but this aor. is mentioned by Yaakoob; (TA;) inf. n. DinRN (S, Mgh, Msb, K [in the CK DinaAnFA is erroneously put for DinRFA]) and DanRN (TA) and DanaAnapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) with fet-h, (Msb, TA,) and DinRapN, (Msb,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Mgh;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, or avaricious, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of it.
(S, Mgh, Msb. [See also 8.]) You say, DanRa Ealayohi bikacaA He was, or became, niggardly, &c., to him, of such a thing. (Mgh.) And UinRamaA yuDanRu biAlDRaniyni↓ [Only he who clings is to be clung to]: a prov., meaning that you should cling to fraternizing [only] with him who clings to fraternizing with you. (Meyd, and Har p. 42.) And Daninotu biAlmanozili, inf. n. DinRN and DanaAnapN, [I kept tenaciously to, or] I did not quit, or relinquish, the place of alighting, or abode. (TA.)
8. AiDoTanRa (originally AiDotanRa, TA) He (a man, TA) was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, or avaricious. (K.) [See also 1.]
DinRN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, &c.)
Also A thing highly esteemed, of which one is tenacious. (TA.)

[Hence] one says, huwa DinRiI He is the person of whose affection I am tenacious; as also DinRatiI↓ and DaniyniI↓: (TA:) or he is my particular, or special, friend, (K, TA,) mino bayoni UixowaAniI [chosen from among my brethren]; (S, TA;) as though I appropriated him specially to myself, and were tenacious of him because of the place that he held in my estimation: as is said in the S, it is like special appropriation [of the person to oneself]. (TA.) [And as DinRN is originally an inf. n., it is used as an epithet applied to a pl. number:] it is said in a trad., UinRa lilRehi DinRFA mino xaloqihi yuHoyiyhimo fiI EaAfiyapK wayumiytuhumo fiI EaAfiyapK, (S, TA,) or mino xlqh DanaAYina↓, (K, * TA,) accord. to different relations thereof, (TA,) i. e.
