[Verily God has] specially-distinguished individuals [of his creatures, whom He causes to live in a state of freedom from disease, or from disease and trial, and whom He causes to die in a state of freedom &c.]: (K, TA:) the sing. of DanaAYin is DaniynapN↓, of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEurlapN, and meaning a thing that one specially appropriates to himself, and of which he is tenacious because of the place that it holds in his estimation. (TA.)
DinRapN an inf. n. of DanRa: (Msb:) or a subst. therefrom signifying Niggardliness, tenaciousness, stinginess, or avarice: (Mgh:) or vehement niggardliness &c.; as also maDanRapN↓. (TA.)
See also DinRN.
DananN Courageous, brave, or strong-hearted. (K.)

DaniynN Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, or avaricious, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) biXaIoCK [of a thing], (S,) or biXaIoCK nafiysK [of a thing held in high estimation]. (TA.) wamaA huwa EalaI Qlogayobi biDaniynK, in the Kur [lxxxi. 24], as some read it, others reading biZaniynK [q. v.], is expl. by Zj as meaning, And he is not a tenacious concealer of that which has been revealed to him: and if Ean or bi were substituted for EalaI, it would be correct. (TA.)
See also 1.
And see DinRN.
DanaAnapN an inf. of 1 [q. v.]. (S &c.)

[Hence,] one says, hajamotu EalaI Alqawomi biDanaAnatihimo, meaning (assumed tropical:) [I came suddenly upon the people, or party, in their close state, i. e.,] when they had not dispersed themselves. (TA.) And Oaxacotu AlOamora biDanaAnatihi (assumed tropical:) [I took to the affair] in its fresh state. (TA.)
DaniynapN; and its pl. DanaAYinu: see DinRN.
maDanRapN: see DinRapN.

hecaA Eiloqu maDanRapK and maDinRapK [the former mentioned after the latter in the S] This is a thing held in high estimation, of which one is tenacious, (S, K, TA,) and for which people vie in desire. (TA.) [See also EiroqN, last sentence.]

AlmaDonuwnu a name of [The compound of perfumes commonly called] AlgaAliyapu; (Ez-Zejjájee, S, K, TA;) as also AlmaDonuwnapu↓; (Ez-Zejjájee, S, * TA;) which latter is said by As to be a sort of perfume; and so is the former in the A: in the M the former is said to be the oil of ben: it is thus called because one is tenacious of it. (TA.)
Also, (IKh, TA,) or AlmaDonuwnapu↓, (K, TA,) a name of The well Zemzem. (K, TA.)
AlmaDonuwnapu: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1. DanaMato, aor.
DanaAa
, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. DanoCN and DunuwoCN; (S, M, O, K;) and accord. to the K, DaniYato, but MF says that this latter is unknown, i. e., it is not mentioned in the other lexicons in the sense here assigned to it in the K; (TA;) and ADnOt↓; (S, M, O, K;) She (a woman) had many children: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) [and so Danato and Daniyato, as mentioned in art. Dnw:] and in like manner one says of cattle; (M;) [i. e.] one says, DanaOa AlmaAlu (S, O, K) and DaniYa, (O, K,) and SanaOati AlmaAXiyapu and DaniYat, (TA,) [and ADnO↓ and ADnOt as is implied in the M,] The cattle multiplied, or became numerous or many. (S, O, K, TA.) And DanaOato is said to signify She brought forth. (TA.)

And SanaOa fiI AlOaroDi, (M, K,) inf. n. DanoCN and DunuwoCN [as above], (M, TA,) He hid, or concealed, himself in the land, or country: (M:) or he went away in the land, or into the country, and hid, or concealed, himself [therein]: (K:) like DabaOa. (TA.)
4: see above, in two places.
OaDonaWuwA signifies Their cattle multiplied, or became numerous or many. (S, O, K.)

8. ADoTanaOa lahu minohu He was abashed at, or shy of, and he shrank at, or from, him, or it. (M, K. [See also ADTbO.]) Et-Tirimmáh uses AiDoTanaA [or AiDoTanaI in this sense,] and yaDoTaniI: meaning ADTnO [and yDTnY]: or as being derived from AlDRanaI meaning “ disease. ” (M.)

DanoCN Children, or offspring; as also DinoCN↓; (S, M, O, K; [and so DanowN and DinowN, as mentioned in art. Dnw;]) the former accord. to El-Umawee, and both accord. to AA: (S, O:) the former signifies the offspring of anything: (TA:) and also, (K, TA, [in a copy of the M ↓the latter, but this is app. a mistranscription,]) multitude of offspring: it is like nafarN (M, K) and rahoTN, (M,) having no. n. un.: the pl. is DunuwoCN. (M, K.)

DinoCN Origin, root, race, or stock; syn. OaSolN: (El-Umawee, S, M, O, K:) and the place in which a thing originates; syn. maEodinN. (ElUmawee, S, O, K.) One says, fulaAnN fiI DinoCi SidoqK [Such a one is of an excellent origin or race or stock], (S, O, L,) and fiI DinoCi sawoCK [of a bad origin &c.]. (L.)
See also DanoCN, in two places.

DunoOapN (M, O, K) and DunaMCapN↓ (O, K) Necessity, need, or want; or difficulty, or distress; (DaAruwrapN, M, O, or DaruwrapN, K; [both meaning the same;]) that befalls a man: (O:) so in the saying qaEada maqoEada DunoOap (M, K) and DunaMCapK↓ (K) [lit. He sat in the sitting-place of necessity, &c.; meaning he was, or became, in an abject condition]: the phrase denotes disdain, or scorn; and is thought by AM to be from AiDoTanaOa meaning “ he was abashed, &c. ” (TA.)
DunaMCapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
DaAniYN (S, O, K) and DaAniYapN (Ks, S, O, Msb, K) A woman having many children: (S, O, Msb, K:) and in like manner, the latter, cattle (maAXiyapN) having numerous offspring. (TA.)

1. Danuka, aor.
Danuka
, inf. n. DanokN and DanaAkapN and DunuwkapN, (O, K,) the first and third of these, (O,) or the first and second, (TA,) accord. to IDrd, used in relation to a place, and the second and third in relation to life, or sustenance, or means of subsistence, (O, TA,) It was, or became, narrow, or strait. (O, K, TA.)
And Danuka said of a man, inf. n. DanaAkapN, He was, or became, weak in his judgment, and in his body, and in his soul, and in his intellect. (K.)
And Danuka AlsRaHaAbu The clouds became thick, collected together, and dense. (O, TA.)
Dunika, like EuniIa, He was, or became, affected with a coryza, or defluxion from the head and nose. (K.)
4. ADnkhu He (God) caused him to be affected with a coryza, or defluxion from the head and nose. (TA.)
DanokN an inf. n. of Danuka: (O, K:) its primary signification is Narrowness, or straitness, and hardship. (Aboo-Is-hák, TA.)

And Narrow, or strait; syn. DayRiqN; (S, M, O, K; [in the CK, and in a copy of the S, Diyq, which is also a correct explanation, as shown above; but not what is here meant, as appears from what follows;]) applied to anything, (M, K,) masc.
and fem., (M, K, and Bd in xx. 123,) being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Bd ibid.) [Like the Pers. tanoG.] One says makaAnN DanokN A narrow, or strait, place. (IDrd, O, TA.) And EayoXN DanokN A strait life; or strait sustenance, or means of subsistence; (IDrd, O, TA;) as also EayoXN DaniykN↓: (AA, O, K, TA:) and thus maEiyXapF DanokFA in the Kur xx. 123; where some read DanokaI↓, like sakoraI: (Bd:) or this means such as is unlawful; (O, TA;) every life that is unlawful being termed DanokN, accord. to Lth, even though it be ample: (O, TA: *) Aboo-Is-hák thinks it to mean [subsistence] in the fire of Hell: but says that most explain this phrase in the Kur as meaning the punishment of the grave: (TA:) thus it means accord. to Ibn-Mes'ood: (O:) or, accord. to Katádeh, Hell: (O, TA:) or, accord. to Ed-Dahhák, forbidden gain: (TA:) or, as some say, AlDRariyEu [q. v.], and AlzRakRuwmu [q. v.]. (Bd.)
DunokapN: see DunaAkN.
DanokaI: see DanokN.
DanaAkN: see DinaAkN.
DunaAkN A coryza, or defluxion from the head and nose; syn. zukaAmN; (S, O, K;) as also DunokapN↓. (K.)

DinaAkN; (O, K, &c.;) accord. to El-Fárábee, (O, TA,) and J [in the S], (TA,) DanaAkN↓; but accord. to others, with kesr, and this is the right; (O, TA;) Compact in flesh; applied to a woman: (El-Fárábee, S, O:) or plump, and compact in flesh; so applied: (Lth, TA:) or heavy in the hinder part, (K, TA,) and large in body; (TA;) so applied: (K, * TA:) or having much flesh; applied to a male and to a female, without p: (IAth, TA:) and firm in make, and strong; applied to a male and to a female; (K, TA;) of human beings, and of camels, and in like manner of palm-trees and of trees in general: (TA:) and, applied to a she-camel, thick in the hinder part: (TA:) and [large; applied to trees (XajarN): or] large trees. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
DaniykN: see DanokN.
Also Weak in his body, and in his intellect, (AZ, O, K,) and in his judgment, and in his soul. (K,)
And A servant who works for his bread. (AZ, O, K.)
And i. q. maqoTuwEN [Cut off; &c.]. (AA, O, K.)

DunoOakN Hard, and firm and compact in flesh; (Lh, O, K;) applied to a man; (Lh, O;) as also DanoOakN: (K:) fem. DunoOakapN; (Lh, O, K;) applied to a woman. (Lh, O.) And, applied to a she-camel, Great, (K, TA,) and compact in make: (TA:) as also with p. (K.)
muDonakN, (TA,) or mutaDanRikN↓, (O,) Affected with a constant, or chronic, pervading disease; or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (O, TA.)
maDonuwkN Affected with the malady termed DunaAk [q. v.]. (S, O,)
mutaDanRikN: see muDonakN.
1. Danati AlmaroOapu, inf. n. DanaMCN (S, M, K) and DanFA, (M, K,) The woman had many children; (S, M, K;) as also Daniyat: (K:) and so with C. (S.)
And DanaA naSiybuhu His share, or portion, became redundant; it increased, or augmented. (Sgh, K.)
DanowN and DinowN Children, or offspring; (AA, S, K;) like DanoCN and DinoCN; as also DunFA↓, accord. to IAar. (TA.)
DunFA: see what next precedes.

1. DaniIa, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
DanaIa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. DanFI; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and ADTnI↓ signifies the same; He was, or became, slender, and small in body: and hence, (Ham p. 112,) he was, or became, diseased, disordered, or sick; (S, and Ham ibid.;) because disease occasions leanness, or emaciation: (Ham:) or he was, or became, lean, or emaciated: (so accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the Mgh:) or he was, or became, affected with a disease, disorder, or sickness, (M, Msb, K,) of long continuance, and settled, (M,) or constant, so that he was at the point of death, (Msb,) or such as infected, or pervaded, him, and so that, whenever he thought himself to be recovering, he relapsed. (K.)
[See also 1 in art. Dnw.]
3. muDaAnaApN i. q. muEaAnaApN, (S, K, KL,) both signifying The suffering, or enduring, [or contending with,], the difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience, of a thing; as also muqaAsaApN. (KL.)

4. ADnAhu, said of a disease, disorder, or sickness, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) It rendered him such as is termed DanFI or DanK: (M, Msb, K:) rendered him lean, or emaciated: (Mgh:) or oppressed him; burdened him heavily; overburdened him; or overcame him, and rendered him heavy. (S, TA.)
And OaDonaI He kept to the bed by reason of what is termed DanFI [i. e. leanness, or emaciation; or disease, disorder, or sickness, or such as was of long continuance, &c.: see 1]. (TA.)
5. tDnRI He (a man) feigned himself diseased, disordered, or sick. (TA.)
8. ADTnI: see 1.
See also 8 in art. DnO.
DanFI: inf. n. of 1. (S, M, &c.)

Also, [in some copies of the K erroneously written DaniIRN,] and DanK↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) the former applied alike to a man (Fr, IAar, T, S, Msb) and to a woman (IAar, T, S, Msb) and to two persons (Msb) and to a pl. number, (Fr, IAar, T, S, Msb,) because originally an inf. n., (S, Msb,) for cuw DanFI and caAtu DanFI [&c.]; (Msb;) or some do not dualize it nor pluralize it, because it is [originally] an inf. n., and others dualize it and pluralize it; (M;) but DanK↓ has a fem. (Msb) and a dual and a pl., (S,) its fem. being DaniyapN (Msb, TA) [and its dual DaniyaAni] and the pl. is OaDonaMCN; (TA;) [Slender, and small in body: and hence, (see 1,)] diseased, disordered, or sick: (S:) [or lean, or emaciated: (see again 1:)] or affected with a disease, disorder, or sickness, (M, Msb, K,) of long continuance, and settled, (M,) or constant, so that he is at the point of death, (Msb,) or such as infects, or pervades, him, and so that, whenever he thinks himself to be recovering, he relapses. (K.) You say, tarakotuhu DanFI and DaniyFA↓ [I left him lean, or diseased, &c.]. (S.)
DanK; fem. DaniyapN; and pl. OaDonaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
DinFI, [written in the TA DnA, but the final radical is I,] with kesr, accord to IAar, signifies Pains that cause fear. (TA.)
DanaMCN, like salaAmN [in measure, The state of such as is termed DanFI or DanK], a subst. from DaniIa. (Msb.)
muDonFI Rendered lean, or emaciated; [&c.;] (Mgh;) pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. (Mgh, Msb.)

3. muDaAhaOapN is syn. with muDaAhaApN, (K, TA, [the w before AlmuDAhApu in the CK should be erased,]) i. q. muXaAkalapN: (S, O, Msb, TA:) you say, DaAhaOotuhu and DaAhayotuhu, ('Eyn, S, * O, * Msb, * TA,) i. e. I resembled him; syn. XaAbahotuhu: ('Eyn, TA:) [or I conformed with him:] or DaAhaOahu, inf. n. as above, signifies he imitated him; syn. EaAraDahu and baAraAhu; and one says also, DaAhayotuhu, inf. n. muDaAhaApN: (Msb:) the verb is read both with and without C in the Kur [ix. 30]. (O, Msb, TA.)

DaAhaA bihi, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) [or DaAhaOahu, like DaAhaAhu, mentioned in art. DhI,] inf. n. as above, (K,) He (a man) was, or became, gentle, tender, or courteous, or he acted, or behaved, gently, &c., with him, or to him. (A 'Obeyd, K, * TA.)
Q. Q. 1: or Q. 1. DahoyaOa: see art. DhyO.
DahoyaON and DahoyaOapN: see art. DhyO.

1. Dahabahu biAlnRaAri, aor.
Dahaba
, (K,) inf. n. DahobN, (TK,) He altered it, (K, TA,) and changed its colour, (TA,) by means of fire. (K, TA.) [See also 2.]

Dahaba said of a man, (O, K,) aor.
Dahaba
, (TA,) inf. n. DuhuwbN, (O, K,) (tropical:) He failed of fulfilling his promise (Oaxolafa), and was weak, and not like a man: (O, K, TA:) as though likened to meat not thoroughly cooked. (TA. [See 2.])

And Dahobu Alqawomi signifies AixotilaATuhumo [i. e. The people's being mixed, or confused]: (JK, O:) or OaxolaATuhumo [i. e. DahobN↓ is a subst., signifying a medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of people]. (So in the K. [But I think that this explanation is a mistranscription.]) [Or it signifies The people's multiplying themselves, and hastening: for] it is said in the “ Nawádir ” that haDaba
Alqawomu and DahabuwA and hulabuwA and OunabuwA and HuTRabuwA all denote AlUikovaAr and AlUisoraAE: so in the T in art. hDb. (TA.)

2. DhRb, inf. n. taDohiybN, He roasted (Lth, K, TA) flesh-meat (Lth, TA) upon heated stones: (Lth, K, TA:) or he roasted, (K,) or put into the fire, (AA, TA,) but did not cook thoroughly, (AA, K, TA,) flesh-meat. (AA, TA.)
And, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) He exposed a bow, (S, O, K,) and a spear, (S, O,) to the fire, (S, O, K,) on the occasion of straightening it, (S, O,) or to straighten it. (K.) [See also 1.]
And He collected together the fire; (JK;) and so DahoDaba↓. (JK, O, K.)
3. muDaAhabapN signifies Mutual reviling or vilifying; (K;) the addressing each other with bad words. (TA.)

Q. 1. DahoDaba: see 2, last sentence. [Mentioned in this art., as though Q. Q., contr. to the rule generally observed with respect to words of four radical letters of which the first and third are identical but not the second and fourth.]
DahobN: see the first paragraph.
qawosN DahobaMCu A bow upon which the fire has taken effect [so as to alter its colour]: (O, K:) like DaboHaMCu. (TA.)

DayohabN i. q. SayohabN, meaning A place where flesh-meat is roasted [on the ground heated by the sun]; (K; [in the CK, limaXowiIRi AllRHmi is erroneously put for limaXowaI AllRaHomi;]) accord. to Lth, any [high ground such as is called] qufR, or rugged ground, or place on a mountain, upon which the sun shines with such heat that flesh-meat will roast upon it: but Az says that what Lth means is SayohabN only, with the unpointed S; (O, * TA;) and if so, the meaning assigned here in the K is not correct. (TA.)

muDahRabN Flesh-meat roasted, but not thoroughly cooked: (S, A, O:) accord. to El-Mufaddal, flesh-meat cut in pieces; (O;) and thus in the K; (TA;) but IF says that this is nought, unless it be cut in pieces roasted: (O:) it is at variance with what is said by the leading authorities, for they say that it means flesh-meat roasted upon heated stones: or roasted upon the fire, but not thoroughly cooked: (TA:) or cooked in a fryingpan. (TA in art. ErS.) Imra-el-Keys says,

L.foreign: UicaA naHonu qumonaA Eano XiwaMCK muDahRabi

sense.s: [We wipe our hands with the manes of the swift horses when we rise from eating roast meat not thoroughly cooked]. (S, O.)

1. Dahadahu, (S, L, K,) aor. - There is no diacritic specified in the original text. , (S, L,) inf. n. DahodN; (L;) and ADThdhu↓, (as in the L, and in some copies of the K,) or ADhdhu↓; (as in other copies of the K;) He overpowered him; subdued him; oppressed him: (S, L, K:) he treated him wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (L;) as also bihi ADhd↓: (L, K:) he constrained him. (S, L.) kaAna laAyujiyzu QliAoDoTihaAda↓, occurring in a trad., means He used not to allow constraint, or compulsion, or force, in a sale, and in an oath, &c. (L.)
4: see each, in two places, in the preceding paragraph.
8: see each, in two places, in the preceding paragraph.
DuhodapN Force; constraint; compulsion. (L.)
huwa DuhodapN likulRi OaHadK means He is one who may be overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, by every one who desires to make him so. (S, L, K.)

DahoyadN Hardy, strong, robust: (L, K:) applied to a man: (L:) [said to be] the only word of the measure faEoyalN (K) in the language of the Arabs; but Kh asserts it to be a forged word: (TA:) DahoyaON and EavoyarN are also mentioned as of this measure; [but the latter is disallowed in the S and O, voce EivoyarN;] and madoyanu and maroyamu [which, however, are foreign proper names]. (MF.)
maDohuwdN and muDoTahadN↓ A man (L) overpowered; subdued; oppressed; (S, L;) abased; (L;) constrained. (S, L.)
muDoTahadN: see what next precedes.
AlmuDoTahidu The lion. (K.)
Q. 1. DahoDaba: see 2 in art. Dhb.

DahowapN A birokap of water; [i. e. a wateringtrough, or tank, or the like, of water; or a basin, pool, pond, or lake, of water; or a place where water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates;] (M, K;) as though formed by transposition from wahoDapN, which signifies a depressed piece of ground: (TA:) pl. OaDohaMCN. (M, K.)
DahowaMCu A woman whose breasts have not become prominent, or protuberant. (Lth, K.) [See also DahoyaMCu, in the next art.]

1. Dahiyato, aor.
DahaIa
, inf. n. DahFI, She was, or became, such as is termed DahoyaMC. (K.)

3. DAhAhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. muDaAhaApN, (S, Msb,) He resembled, or conformed with, him, or it; syn. XaAkalahu; (S, Msb, K;) like DaAhaOahu [q. v.]: (S, Msb:) and, like the latter, he imitated him. (Msb, TA. *) It is said in a trad., OaXadRu AlnRaAsi EacaAbFA yawoma AlqiyaAmapi AlRaciyn yuDaAhuwna xaloqa QllRehi i. e. [The most severely punished of mankind on the day of resurrection will be] those who imitate by what they make [the creation of God]; meaning the sculptors or limners or the like. (Msb.)
Also, [or DaAhaI bihi, like DaAhaOa bh, q. v.,] He was, or became, gentle, tender, or courteous, or he acted, or behaved, gently, &c., with him, or to him; namely, a man, and other than a man. (TA.)
4. ADhI He married, i. e. took to wife, a woman such as is termed DahoyaMC. (AA, K.)
And He pastured his camels upon the species of tree called DahoyaMC. (K.)
DahoyFA: see the next paragraph, in four places.

DahoyaMCu A woman that does not menstruate: pl. DuhoIN; which necessarily implies that the former is [as above, i. e.] with the long A: but AA mentions DahoyaApN↓ and DahoyaAhN↓, with p and with h, as having this meaning; which necessarily implies that DhyA is with the short A [i. e., accord. to a general rule, DahoyFA↓, with tenween, like DahoyaON, q. v. in art. DhyO, though (accord. to a general rule) this should be regarded as a masc. epithet]: (S) or DahoyaMCu, and also with the short A [app. DahoyFA↓, as above, not DahoyaA, or, as I rather incline to think, DahoyaON (which is mentioned in art. DhyO) may be here meant], signify a woman that does not menstruate nor become pregnant; (K, TA;) so that she is as though she resembled a man: (TA: [see 3:]) or that menstruates but does not become pregnant: (K, TA:) or that does not bring forth, though she menstruate: (TA:) or whose breasts do not grow forth; (K, TA;) and when this is the case, she does not menstruate: or the former signifies that does not menstruate, being pregnant. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) Land that does not give growth to anything; as also with the short A [i. e. DahoyFA↓ or DahoyaON]. (K. [In the TA this meaning is restricted, app. without reason, to the form with the short A.])

Also, (S, K,) and with the short A [i. e. DahoyFA↓ or DahoyaON], (K,) A species of tree (S, K) of the kind called EiDaAh, (K,) having a baramap [q. v.] and a pod (EulRafap) [which succeeds the baramap], and many thorns. (TA. [For further descriptions thereof, see DahoyaON, in art. DhyO.])
DahoyaApN and DahoyaAhN: see the next preceding paragraph.

DahiIRN, (S, K,) of the measure faEiylN, (S,) The like of another [thing or person]: (S, K:) one says, hecaA DahiIRu hecaA This is the like of this: (S:) or huwa DahiyRuka He is the like of thee. (K.)

Q. 1: [Accord. to the O and K, Q. Q. 1, being mentioned therein in art. DhO.] DahoyaOa Oamorahu He fell short of doing what he ought to have done in his affair, (marRaDahu, O, K,) and did not decide it, (lamo yaSorimohu, O,) or and did not perform it firmly, or soundly: (K:) like rahoyaOa. (TA.)

DahoyaON, of the measure faEolalN, or, as some say, faEoyalN; if of the latter, [said to be] the only instance of this measure in the language; DahoyadN
being a foreign proper name; (TA;) or, maroyamu being a foreign proper name; (TA;) or, accord. to Sb, the hemzeh in DahoyaON, which is with tenween, is augmentative, because it is syn. with DahoyaMCu, which is with the long A and imperfectly decl., for the I cannot be augmentative and the hemzeh radical in the latter; (MF and TA in art. DhI;) [a word like DahoyFA and DahoyaMCu (which see in art. DhI) in most, or a some seem to say in all, of its meanings;] A certain tree, resembling the sayaAl, (AZ, O, K,) each of which has its fruit in a sinofap [or pod]; it has weak thorns, and grows in the valleys and on the mountains: (AZ, O:) Ed-Deenawaree [i. e. AHn] says, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, of El-Azd, that the DhyO is a great tree of the kind called EiDaAh, having a baramap [q. v.] and a pod (EulRRafap) [which succeeds the baramap], and many thorns; its pods (EulRaf) are intensely red, and its leaves are like those of the [species of acacia called] samur. (O.)

Also A woman that does not menstruate: and that has neither milk nor breast: as also DahoyaOapN↓: (K:) or the latter is an epithet applied to a woman in these two senses: (O: [in which the former word, without p, is not mentioned:]) Seer says, in his Expos. of “ the Book ” of Sb, that DahoyaON, like DahoyaMCu [which belongs to art. DhI], is a subst. as well as an epithet, signifying a woman whose breast has not grown forth: and one who has not menstruated:

and also (assumed tropical:) A land that has not given growth to anything: (MF, TA:) or DahoyaOapN↓ signifies as above: and also (assumed tropical:) a desert (falaApN) having in it no water: (O, K, TA:) or that does not give growth to anything; app. because it has no water. (TA.) [Accord. to those who hold the I to be augmentative,] a woman is thus termed because she resembles men (liOanRahaA DaAhaOati AlrRijaAla). (O, TA.)
DahoyaOapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
R. Q. 1. DawoDawoA, [inf. n. DawoDaApN and DawoDaMCN, (see the next paragraph,)] They cried out, shouted, or clamoured; first pers. sing. DawoDayotu, the [second] w being changed into I. (S, TA.)

DawRapN [in the CK erroneously written DawAp] A crying out, shouting, or clamouring; (S, K;) so says As, and AZ says the like; (S;) as also DawoDaApN↓ (S, K) and DawoDaMCN↓, (TA in art. DwD, [these two there mentioned as inf. ns., on the authority of IKtt,]) and DawoDFI↓. (K in art. DwD.) One says, samiEotu DawRapa Alqawomi [I heard the crying out, shouting, or clamouring, of the people, or party]. (As, AZ, S.)
DawoDFI and DawoDaMCu and DawoDaApN; see the next preceding paragraph.
DuwaADK Large, big, or bulky; thick; or large in body; syn. DaxomN, (K, TA,) and EaZymN. (TA.)
DuwaADiyapN: see what next follows.
DuwayoDiyapN, (K, TA,) in the dim. form, (TA,) A calamity, or misfortune; (K, TA,) because of its greatness; (TA;) as also DuwaADiyapN↓. (K, TA.)
And A stallion [camel] excited by lust. (Sgh, K.)
muDawoDK A man crying out; shouting, or clamouring; (K and TA in art. DwD; [in the CK erroneously written muDawoDiIR;]) like muDawoDiYN. (TA in that art.)
1: see 4, in two places.
2: see the next paragraph, in two places.

One says also, DawRaOotu Eanohu [meaning I brought to light, made visible, discovered, or revealed, him, or it]. (M, TA.) A sheep, or goat, belonging to an Arab of the desert strayed; whereupon he said, AallRehumRa DawRiYo Eanohu [O God, bring it to light, or discover it]. (A, TA.)
Accord. to Lth, but he is the only authority for it known by AM, (TA,) DawRaOa Eani AlOamori, inf. n. taDowiYapN, means He declined, or turned away, from the affair. (K, TA.)

4. ADMC, (M, Msb, K,) said of a thing, (M,) [as, for instance,] of the moon, (Msb,) or ADMCt, said of fire (AlnRaAr,), (A 'Obeyd, S, O,) inf. n. UiDaMCN; (Msb;) and DaMCa↓, (M, Msb, K,) or DaMCat, (S, O,) aor. yaDuwoCu, (M,) or taDuwoCu, (S,) inf. n. DawoCN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and DuwoCN, (S, O, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) but the former verb is preferred; (TA;) It gave light, was light or bright, shone, or shone brightly. (Msb, K, * TA.) [See also an ex. of ↓the latter verb in a verse cited voce OufuqN; and cited here in the TA.] And OaDaOotu lahu [I gave light to him]. (M.)

The former verb is also trans.: you say, OaDaMCatohu AlnRaAru [The fire made it to be light or bright, to shine, or to shine brightly]: (S, O:) and OaDaOotuhu and DawRaOotuhu↓ [I made it to give light, to be light or bright, to shine, or to shine brightly]: (M, Msb, * K:) and OaDaOotu bihi Albayota and bihi DawRaOotuhu↓ [I lighted, or illumined, with it (i. e. with a lamp or the like) the house, or chamber, or tent]. (M.)

[Hence,] ADMC bibawolihi (tropical:) He ejected his urine [so as to make its drops to glisten]; or emitted it and then stopped it; syn. Hacafa bihi; (K, TA;) or xacafa bihi; (so in a copy of the M, as on the authority of Kr;) or, as in the A, OacoraEa bihi. (TA.)
And they said maA OaDowaOahu [How light, or bright, is it!]. (S voce OaZolama [q. v.].)
And ADMC signifies also OaSaAba DawoCFA [He saw (lit. lighted on, or found,) light, or brightness]. (T voce OaZolama [q. v.])

5. tDwRO He stood in the dark to see people by the light of their fire, (AZ, K, TA,) without their seeing him. (AZ, TA.) And tDwRA QmoraOapF [He stood in the dark to see a woman by the light of her fire, without her seeing him]. (TA.)

10. AisotaDaOutu bihi [I sought to obtain light by means of it; I made use of it for light]. (M, K.) laA tasotaDiyWuwA binaAri Oaholi AlXRiroki [lit. Seek not ye to obtain light by means of the fire of the people of belief in a plurality of gods], (O, K,) a saying of the Prophet, (O,) means (tropical:) seek not ye counsel, or advice, of the believers in a plurality of gods, in affairs: (O, K:) because he whose affair is confused and dubious to him is as though he were in darkness. (O.)

DawoCN and DuwoCN↓ and DiyaMCN↓ (S, M, O, K) and DiwaMCN↓, (M, K,) the last of which is [erroneously] written in the L DawaMCN, (TA,) signify the same, (S, M, O, K,) i. e. Light, syn. nuwrN, (K, TA,) accord. to the leading lexicologists; but see what follows: (TA:) and DawoCN is an inf. n. of DaMCa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) and so is DuwoCN↓, (S, O, K,) or this is a simple subst. from DaMCa, and so is DiyaMCN↓, which is also, sometimes, written DiYaMCN↓, from OaDaMCa as syn. with DaMCa: (Msb:) the pl. of DawoCN (M, TA) and DuwoCN↓ (M) is OaDowaMCN; and DiyaMCN↓ is sometimes a pl., (M, TA,) as Zj states it to be: (TA:) some say that DawoCN has a more intensive signification than nuwrN, and that hence God has likened his direction [the Kur-án] to AlnRuwr rather than to AlDRawoC; because if it were otherwise, no one had erred: and that hence, also, [in the Kur x. 5,] the sun is termed DiyaMC↓; and the moon, nuwrN: it is also said that DawoCN signifies the rays that are diffused by what is termed nuwrN: the kádee Zekereeyà affirms that these two words are syn. by their original application, but that DawoCN is more forcible accord. to usage: and some say that AlDRawoCu signifies that [light] which subsists by itself, as [that of] the sun, and fire; and AlnRuwru, to that which subsists by some other thing [as does the light of the moon]. (MF, TA.)
DuwoCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
DiwaMCN: see DawoCN.
DiyaMCN and DiYaMCN: see DawoCN, in five places.
2. DwRH: see 2, in two places, in art. DyH.
DaAdN The name of one of the letters of the alphabet. (L, Msb, K.) See the letter D.
1. DaArahu, aor. yaDuwru: see DaArahu, aor. yaDiyru, in art. Dyr.

5. tDwRr He writhed by reason of the pain of beating, (M, A, K,) or of hunger: (K:) he cried out and writhed on being beaten, (Lth, S, A,) or
by reason of vehement hunger: (S, A:) he writhed and cried out and turned over, by reason of the vehemence of fever: (TA:) he manifested harm, injury, or hurt, that he suffered; and was in a state of agitation: (IAmb, TA:) he manifested weakness: (Abu-l-'Abbás, in TA: [but for taDoEiyfN, as the explanation of the inf. n., in the TA, I read taDaERufN:]) he (a wolf, and a dog, and a lion, and a fox,) cried out (M, K) with hunger. (M.)
1. DaAzahu HaqRahu, aor. yaDuwzuhu, i. q. DaAzahu, aor. yaDiyzuhu: see art. Dyz. (K.) You say also DaAzaniI, aor. yaDuwzuniI, meaning naqaSaniI [He made me to suffer loss]. (Kr, M, TA.)
And DaAza, aor. yaDuwzu is also [intrans.] like DaOaza, q. v. (TA in art. DOz.)
qisomapN DuwzaI i. q. DiyzaI: see art. Dyz. (M, TA. *)

dictScrap.label: DwD: For words mentioned in the K under this head, see art. Dw.

sense.s: 1. DaAEahu, (aor. yaDuwEuhu, S, O,) inf. n. DawoEN, He, or it, put it, or him, into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; (S, O, K;) as also DwREhu↓, inf. n. taDowiyEN: (TA:) and disquieted, or disturbed, him, or it: and frightened him: (S, O, K:) and some say, roused, or excited, him: and DwREhu↓, also, has the last but one, or the last, of these meanings. (TA.) One says, laA yaDuwEanRaka maA tasomaEu minohaA i. e. [By no means let that which thou hearest from her move thee, or disquiet thee, or frighten thee; or] do not thou be moved by what thou hearest from her; or do not thou care for it, or regard it. (TA.) And DaAEahu Oamoru kacaA wakacaA Such and such things frightened him. (AA, TA.)
And, said of the wind, It made it to incline; namely, a branch: (K:) and it (the wind) bore heavily upon it. (TA. [The object of the verb in this sense is not there mentioned.])

And i. q. XaAqahu [He, or it, excited his desire]: (so in the O, on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád:) or i. q. XaAqRahu [he acted with him contrariously, or adversely, and inimically; &c.]. (So in copies of the K.)
And DAE AlUibila, (O,) or AldRaAbRapa, (K,) said of journeying It rendered lean, or emaciated, (O, K,) the camels, (O,) or the beast. (K.)

And DAE faroxahu, (IAar, O, K,) aor. as above, (IAar, O,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) It (a bird) fed its young one with its bill. (IAar, O, K.) When you command the bird to do so, you say DuEo DuEo. (IAar, O.)
DaAEa is also intrans.: see 5, in two places.
2: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
4. maAOaDowaEahu, said of odour, means How sweet [or fragrant] is it! (Har p. 670.)

5. tDwRE said of the wind, It became in motion. (TA.) And tDwREt raAYiHapu AlTRiybi The odour of the perfume diffused itself, or became diffused. (O.) And tDwRE Almisoku, (S, K,) as also tDyRE; (S;) or tDwRE AlXRaIoCu; (Msb,) and DAE↓, (S, O, Msb; K,) aor. yaDuwEu, (O, Msb) inf. n. DawoEN; (Msb;) and DAE, aor. yaDiyEu; (Har p. 670;) The musk, being put in motion, diffused its odour, or fragrance; (S, O, K, TA;) or the thing diffused its odour: (Msb:) so in a verse of Imra-el-Keys cited voce rayRaA, in art. rwI: [in which, in the place of taDawRaEa, some read yaDRawRaEu, for yataDawRaEu:] (TA:) and in like manner one says of a stinking thing. (IAar, K.) And tDwRE misokFA [It diffused the odour, or fragrance, of musk]. (S, O.)
And tDwRE minohu raAYiHapF He snuffed, or scented, or smelt, from him, or it, an odour. (TA.)
Also, said of the [bird called] DuwaE, It cried, or uttered a loud cry or crying. (AHát, O.)

And, (O,) said of a child, (K,) He writhed, (K,) or cried out and writhed, (O, K, * TA,) in weeping; (K, * TA; in the former, mina AlbukaMCi; but correctly, fiI AlbkMCi; TA;) as also DAE↓, (Lth, O, K,) aor. yaDuwEu, (Lth, O,) inf. n. DawoEN: (TA:) both signify he cried, or uttered a loud cry or crying, in weeping; as one does when beaten: or the former, mostly said of a child, signifies he writhed in weeping with vehemence, and raising the voice; as expl. by Lth: (TA:) or it signifies also he (a child) wept vehemently: (O:) and, said of a young bird, it writhed, or cried out and writhed; (O, K;) as when said of a child; and so AnDAE↓, said of both: (K:) or AnDAE↓, said of a young bird, (S, O, K,) as also tDwRE, (O, K,) signifies it spread its wings to its mother in order that she might feed it with her bill. (S, O, K.)
7. AnDAE: see the next preceding sentence, in two places.
Also He was frightened at a thing, and cried out at it, or uttered a loud cry or crying by reason of it. (TA.)

DuwaEN (S, O, Msb, K) and DiwaEN (AHeyth, O, K) A certain night-bird, (S, O, Msb, K,) [a species of owl, i. e.,] of the kind termed haAm: (S, O, Msb:) or [a male owl;] the male of the buwm; (S, O, Msb, K;) accord. to El-Mufaddal: (S, O:) said by ADk to be a bird that utters a scream when it perceives the daybreak: (O:) or the karawaAn [a name now given to the stonecurlew, or charadrius œdicnemus]: (K:) or a certain black bird, resembling the guraAb [or crow], (Et-Táïfee, O, K,) smaller than this, but red in its wings, these being of a roseate colour: so says AHát, on the authority of Et-Táïfee: accord. to others, he says, it is a small bird, less than the duxRal and the HumRar; (O;) and in like manner says Th: (TA:) also that the DuwaEap↓ [which may be the fem. or a n. un.] is of a colour inclining to yellow, dusky and blackish externally, and yellow and ash-coloured within, short in the neck and tail, smaller than the sparrow; and that it is thus called because of the cry that it utters at the commencement of daybreak: accord. to El-Hanashee, the DuwaE is a bird such as is termed Oabogav [q. v.], resembling the domestic hen, (O,) the flesh of which is good: (O, K:) but he adds that it has been said by some to be not a bird: and in another place of the book he says that the DuwaEap↓ is black, like the guraAb, a little larger than the Dujorap, red in the xawaAfiq: (O: [but AlxawaAfiq is an obvious mistranscription for AlxawaAfiI: see xaAfiyapN:)] the pl. is OaDowaAEN [a pl. of pauc.] and DiyEaAnN. (S, O, Msb, K.)
DuwaEapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
DuwaAEN The cry of the bird called DuwaE. (S, O, Msb, K.)

DawaAYiEu, applied to camels, (O, K,) and to other beasts, (O,) Lean, and lank in the belly: (O, K:) or emaciated: (TA:) app. from DaAEa said of journeying, meaning “ it rendered lean, or emaciated: (O:) by rule it should be DaAYiEapN. (TA.)
AlDRawRaAEu, like XadRaAd, [in the O erroneously written AlDuwaAEu,] The fox. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
maDuwEN pass. part. n. of DaAEahu. (O, TA.)
1. DaAfa Eanohu, inf. n. DawofN: see 1 in art Dyf.
maDuwfN: see art. Dyf.
maDuwfapN: see art. Dyf.
1. DaAma, aor. yaDuwmu, inf. n. DawomN, a dial. var. of DaAma, aor. yaDiymu, inf. n. DayomN: (K:) Dumotuhu, like Dimotuhu, signifying Zalamotuhu [I wronged him, &c.]. (M, TA.)
1. DawonapN, (K,) an inf. n. of which the verb is DaAna, aor. yaDuwnu, said of a man, (TK,) The having numerous offspring; as also taDawRunN↓. (K.) [Probably from DayowanN.]
5: see the preceding paragraph.
DawonN The UinofaHap [i. e. runnet, or runnet-bag, of a hid, or lamb]. (K.)

DaAnapN A nose-ring of brass (burapN M, K, mino SuforK M) for a camel: (K:) or a [camel's nose-ring such as is termed] xizaAmap; accord. to Sh: mentioned in the K in art. DOn; but this is its proper place, for it is without. (TA.)
DawonapN A young female child. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlZRaboyapu is put for AlSRabiyRapu.])

DayowanN, (S, M, K,) of the measure fayoEalN, not faEowalN, because the former is the more common, (IB, TA,) extr. [in respect of rule], preserving
its original form, (M,) without UidogaAm [i. e. not having its w incorporated into the I so as to become DayRanN, as it should by rule,] because it is a primitive noun, (S,) like Hayowapu, which is a proper name of a man, (S, M,) but more extr. because that is allowable in a proper name which is not allowable in another kind of word, (M,) [A he-cat;] i. q. sinRaworN [q. v.]; (M:) the male sinRawor: (S, K:) or a certain small beast resembling the sinRawor: (M:) pl. DayaAwinu, (S, K,) in which the w is unaltered because it is so in the sing.: (S, TA:) Sb says, the dim. is DuyayRinN↓, like OusayRidN [dim. of Oasowadu], but he who says OusayowidN may say DuyayowinN↓. (S.)
DuyayRinN and DuyayowinN: see what next precedes.

1. DawiIa, aor. yaDowaI, inf. n. DawFI, He (a child, Msb) was, or became, lean, or emaciated, (S, Msb, K,) and small in body: (Msb:) or slender in the bones, and spare of body, naturally. (M, K.) [See also 4.]

DawaI Uilayohi, (S, M, K,) aor. yaDowiI, (S, K,) inf. n. DuwiIRN (S, M, K) and DaIRN, (M, K,) He adjoined himself, got him or got himself, betook him or betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to him; syn. AinoDamRa; (S, M, K;) as also AnDwI↓; (Har p. 73;) and he had recourse, or betook himself, to him for protection, or refuge. (S, * M, K.)

And DawaI UilaIRa minohu xayorN, inf. n. DaIRN and DuwiIRN, i. q. saAla [i. e. Bounty flowed to me from him]: (M, TA:) accord. to the copies of the K, DwI AlI xabarihi sOl; which is wrong. (TA. [In my MS. copy of the K, AlI xayorh saOla.])
And DawaI signifies also It came by night: (M, K:) you say, DawaI UilayonaA xabaruhu The news, or tidings, of him, or it, came to us by night. (M, TA.)
DuwiIa, said of a camel, He was, or became, affected with the tumours termed DawFI, (Lth, TA,) or with what is termed DawaApN [q. v.]. (M.)
4. ADwI He (a man, TA) was, or became, slender (K, TA) in his body. (TA. [See also DawiIa.]) And ADwI Alqawomu The people's cattle became lean, or emaciated; like ASwI Alqwm. (IKtt, TA in art. SwI.)

And He (a man) had offspring such as is termed DaAwiIR born to him: and in like manner ADwt is said of a woman [as meaning she brought forth such offspring]; (M;) or she brought forth a boy such as is so termed. (K.) AigotaribuwA walaA tuDowuwA, (S, M, Msb,) occurring in a trad., (S,) means Marry ye among women that are remote in respect of relationship, (S, M, Msb, *) and not among the relations of your paternal uncles, (S,) or and not among your near relations, lest your offspring be such as is termed DaAwiIR: (M, Msb:) for the Arabs assert that a man's offspring from his near relation is meagre, though generous, of the nature of his people. (S, Msb.)

ADwAhu He rendered it weak. (S, Msb, K *) You say, ADwI AlOamora (tropical:) He rendered the affair weak; (S, TA;) did not render it firm, or sound; or did not perform it in a firm, or sound, manner. (S, K, TA.)
And ADwAhu HaqRahu (assumed tropical:) He curtailed him, or defrauded him, of his right, or due. (IAar, M, K. *)
ADwAhu AllRayolu Uilayohi The night made him to have recourse, or to betake himself, to him for protection, or refuge. (TA.)
7: see 1, second sentence.
DawFI inf. n. of DawiIa [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.)
See also the next paragraph.

DawaApN [mentioned in the TA as from the K, but not in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K inserted in the margin,] A ganglion (gudadapN, M, or gudRapN, K, TA) beneath the lobe of the ear, above the nakafap [q. v.]: (M, K, TA:) or, accord. to Az, [a thing] resembling a gudRap. (TA.) And A tumour occurring in the fauces of camels and other animals: pl. DawFI↓: (M:) or this latter [is properly termed a coll. gen. n., of which DawaApN is the n. un., and] signifies tumours accidental to the camel, in his head, having an overpowering effect upon his eyes, and rendering it difficult to attach to him the [halter called] xiTaAm; and sometimes it is in the side of the mouth. (Lth, TA.) And (M, TA) A siloEap [or ganglion] (S, M, TA) in a camel, (S,) or in any part of the body. (M, TA.)
Also A certain thing, or small thing, (hanapN,) that comes forth from the she-camel's vulva before the coming forth of the fœtus. (M, K, TA.)
DaAwK: see the next paragraph.
Also Coming by night; syn. TaAriqN [which Golius here explains as meaning “ Lucifer, ” and supposes to be for DaAwiYN]. (M, K.)

DaAwiIRN, (S, M, Msb, K,) of the measure faAEuwlN, [originally DaAwuwIN,] (S, Msb,) and DaAwK↓, (Msb, TA,) applied to a boy, (S, M, K,) and with p applied to a girl, (S, Msb, K,) Lean, or emaciated, (S, Msb, K,) and small in body: (Msb:) or slender in the bones, and spare of body, naturally: (M, K:) and likewise applied to any species of animal: (M:) accord. to the T, the offspring of an incestuous union. (TA.) AlDRaAwiIRu, (T, TA,) not without teshdeed, as the text of the K implies it to be, (TA,) was the name of A certain horse, (T, K, TA,) belonging to Ghanee. (T, TA.)
Also the former, disordered, or diseased, and near to dying: [so I render HaAriDN, q. v.:] and weak; in a bad, or corrupt, state. (TA.)
fiyhi DaAwiyRapN In him is leanness or emaciation [&c.]: (S:) i. q. DawFI [the inf. n. of DawiIa, used as a subst.]. (TA.)
maDowiIRN, applied to a camel, part. n. of DuwiIa [q. v.]. (Lth, TA.)
1. DaAHa AllRabana: see 2, in two places.
DaAHati AlbilaAdu The tracts of land became vacant, (K, TA,) by reason of drought. (TA.)

2. DyRH AllRabana, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taDoyiyHN, (S,) He mixed the milk with water, (S, O, K,) so that it became DayoH; (S;) as also DawRaHahu, as heard by Az from an Arab of the desert; (TA;) and DaAHahu↓, (O, K,) inf. n. DayoHN, but this last is said by IDrd to be obsolete: (O:) or DaAHahu↓, inf. n. DayoHN, he poured water into it, it being thick, and then stirred it about until it became of a uniform consistence. (T, TA.)
And DyRHhu He gave him to drink thin milk, mixed with water, such as is termed DayoH; (S, K;) as also DwRHhu. (K.)
4. ADAH, said of the muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm] It became what is termed DayoH, and fit to be eaten. (O.)
5. tDRyH It (milk) became what is termed DayaAH; (K;) i. e. it was diluted with water, and stirred about until it became of a uniform consistence: and so any medicine, or poison. (TA.)
And He (a man) drank what is termed DayaAH. (K.)

DayoHN and DayaAHN↓ Thin milk, mixed (S, O, K, TA) with much water: the former expl. by As as meaning milk in which is much water: the latter expl. in the T as thick milk into which water is poured, and which is then stirred about until it becomes of a uniform consistence: also, both words, milk, whether it be fresh or such as is termed raAYib [q. v.], upon which water is poured until it has become thin: and DayaAHN↓ and muDayRaHN↓ any medicine or poison having water poured into it, and then stirred about until it becomes of a uniform consistence: or, accord. to Lth, only milk is termed DayaAH. (TA.) [See an ex. voce xaDaArN.]
DayoHN also signifies Honey. (O, K.)
And Ripe muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm]: (O, K: [see 4:]) this is of the dial. of El-Yemen, universally. (O.)
DiyHN i. q. DiHRN [q. v.]: (K:) ascribed by IDrd to the vulgar. (TA.)
Also an imitative sequent to ryH, (K,) [i. e.] a corroborative of ryH, (O,) in the phrase jaMCa biAlrRiyHi waAlDRiyHi [expl. voce DiHRN], and therefore having no meaning if used alone. (O, * TA.)
DaAHapN The sight: (O, K:) one says, maA Oajowada DaAHatahu [How good, or excellent, is his sight!]: (O:) or the eye. (K.)
DayoHapN A single drink, or draught, of thin milk, such as is termed DayoH. (TA.)
DayaAHN: see DayoHN, in two places.
muDayRaHN: see DayoHN.
EayoXN maDoyuwHN (tropical:) A turbid life; syn. mamocuwqN. (Fr, O, K, TA.)

mutaDayRiHN (tropical:) Coming to the watering-trough when
most of the contents thereof has been drunk and there remains but little, mixed, (IAth, * O, K, TA,) and turbid; (IAth, TA;) this being likened to milk mixed with water: (TA:) or coming to water the last of the people. (AHeyth, TA.)

1. DaArahu, aor. yaDiyru, inf. n. DayorN; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also DaArahu, aor. yaDuwru, inf. n. DaworN; (S, M, K;) It (a thing, M, K) harmed, injured, hurt, mischiefed, or damaged, him; i. q. DarRahu, (S, M, K,) or OaDarRa bihi. (Msb.) You say, hecaA mimRaA laA yaDiyruka [This is of the things that will not harm thee]: and lawo faEalotahu lamo yaDiroka [Hadst thou done it, it had not harmed thee]: and laA Dayora Ealayoka [No harm shall befall thee]. (A.) And maA yaDiyruka EalaI AlDRabRi SiyodN i. q. maA yaDurRuka q. v. (A in art. Dr.) And Ks says that he had heard (from one of the people of El-' Áliyeh. TA) the phrase laA yanofaEuniI celika walaA yaDuwruniI [That will not benefit me, nor will it harm me]. (S, TA.) See also a reading of a phrase in a trad. cited in art. Dr. conj. 3.

1. DaAza, (S, K,) aor. yaDiyzu, inf. n. DayozN, (TA,) He deviated from the right course; or acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (S, K;) fiI AlHukomi in the judgment: (S:) like DaOaza. (TA in art. DOz.)

DaAzahu HaqRahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He deprived him, or defrauded him, of a part, or the whole, of his right, or due: (S, M, K:) like DaAzahu, aor. yaDuwzuhu: (K:) he refused it to him, or withheld it from him: (AZ, M, TA:) and sometimes one says DaOazahu, aor. yaDoOazuhu, inf. n. DaOozN. (S, TA.)

qisomapN DiyzaI An unjust, (S, M,) or a defective, (K in art. DOz,) division: (S, M, K:) as also DuwzaI: (M:) DyzI in the Kur liii. 22 is read by all without hemz: (TA:) it is of the measure fuEolaI, like TuwbaI and HubolaI; but the D is with kesr in order that the I may remain unchanged; for there is not in the language an epithet of the measure fiEolaI; this being a measure of substantives, like AlXRiEoraI and AldRifolaI: (S:) or, accord. to Aboo-' Alee, it is not an epithet, but an inf. n., like cikoraI, as though the meaning were qisomapN caAtu jaworK: (Har p. 524:) Fr says that some of the Arabs say DaOozaI, and DuWozaI: and AHát mentions AZ's having heard the Arabs say DiYozaI, with hemz. (S.)

1. DaAEa, aor. yaDiyEu, inf. n. DayaAEN and DayoEapN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and DayoEN and DiyEN, (K,) It (a thing, S, Mgh, O, Msb) perished, came to nought, passed away, or became lost. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad. of Saad, UinRiI OaxaAfu EalaI AlOaEonaAbi AlDRayoEupa i. e. [Verily I fear, for the grapes,] their [lit. the] perishing, or becoming lost. (TA.)

And DAE, (K, TA,) inf. n. DayaAEN and DayoEapN, (TA,) It (a thing) was left; left, or let, alone; or neglected. (K, TA.) Hence, DAEt AlUibilu, and DAE AlEiyaAlu, The camels, and the family, or household, were left untended, and unminded; and were left alone, or neglected. (TA.)
DAE, aor. yaDiyEu, said of perfume, or sweet odour, i. q. DAE having for its aor. yaDuwEu. (Har p. 670.) [See 5 in art. DwE: and see also 5 in the present art.]

2. DyRE AlXRaIoCa, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. taDoyiyEN; (S;) and ADAEhu↓, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiDaAEapN; (S;) both signify the same; (S, O, Msb, K;) He made, or caused, the thing to perish, or become lost; he destroyed it, wasted it, or lost it. (Msb, K, TA.) Hence, DayRaEuwA fulaAnFA is used by the vulgar as meaning They beheaded such a one with the sword. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlSRayofa DayRaEoti AllRabana [In the spring, or in the summer, thou losedst the milk], in which the t is with kesr when the words are addressed to a male, or to a female, or to a pl. number, because originally addressed to a woman, the wife of a wealthy man, whom she disliked because of his being aged, wherefore he divorced her, and a poor man married her, and she sent to her first husband requesting a gift, and he answered her thus; (S, O, K; *) AlSyf being in the accus. case as an adv. n.: so says Yaakoob: (S, O:) or El-Aswad Ibn-Hurmuz divorced his wife El- ' Anood Esh-Shenneeyeh, (O, K,) of the BenooShenn, (TA,) preferring to her a beautiful and wealthy woman of his people; (O, K; *) then there occurred between them what led to their separation, and he sought to obtain [again] El- ' Anood, and sent a message to her; but in replying to him she said,

[Thou hast begun to seek our union: in the spring, or in the summer, thou losedst the milk]: (O, * K:) the t in this case being with fet-h. (K. [See more in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 197-8, or in Har p. 577; in both of which, however, and in the O, DyREt is with kesr in the latter case, as in the former.]) [One says also, DyRE Eahodahu, meaning He broke his compact, contract, or covenant]. The phrase, in a trad., nahaI Eano AlmaAli UiDaAEapi↓ means He forbade the expending of wealth otherwise than in obedience to God, and the squandering thereof, and extravagance. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
4. ADAE AlXRaIoCa: see 2, first sentence, and last but one.

Also, [and app. DyREhu↓ likewise, accord. to the K,] He left the thing; left it, or let it, alone; or neglected it. (K, TA.) You say, ADAE EiyaAlahu He neglected his family, or household; omitted taking good care of them, or being mindful of them. (TA.) wamaA kaAna QllRehu liyuDiEa UiymaAnakumo, in the Kur [ii. 138], means And God will not neglect [or make to be lost] your prayer. (TA.) OaDaAEuwA AlSRalaApa, in the same, [xix. 60,] means Who neglected, or omitted, prayer, (Bd, TA,) altogether: (TA:) or deferred it: (Bd:) or who performed it in other than its right time: but the first explanation is more suitable, for the unbelievers are meant thereby. (TA.)
ADAE [is also intrans., and] may signify He found his affair to be coming to nought. (Ham p. 33.)
And His estates (DiyaAEuhu) became wide-spread, (S, O, K,) and many, or numerous. (S, O, Msb, K.)
5. tDyRE, said of the wind, It blew: because it [often] destroys that upon which it blows: so says Er-Rághib. (TA. [But it may be from what here follows.])
Said of musk, It diffused its odour, or fragrance: (S, O, K;) a dial. var. of tDwRE: (S:) or an instance of substitution [of I for w]. (O.) [See also 1, last explanation.]
maAta DiyoEFA and DiyaEFA: see DayaAEN.
DayoEapN an inf. n. of 1. (S, &c.)
See DayaAEN, below, last sentence but one.
Also A single case, or occasion, of perishing, coming to nought, passing away, or becoming lost; or of being left, left or let alone, or neglected. (TA.)
tarakotuhu biDayoEapK means I left him unsought-after, or unminded, or unmissed. (TA. [See also a similar phrase voce DayaAEN.])

Also i. q. EaqaArN [meaning An estate consisting of land, or of land and a house, or of a house or land yielding a revenue, or of a house and palm-trees, or the like]; (S, O, Msb, K;) and [particularly] land yielding a revenue; (K;) or with the people of the towns and villages and cultivated lands it signifies the property, of a man, consisting of palm-trees and grape-vines and land: but the Arabs [of the desert] know not the word in this sense: (Az, TA:) IF says, I do not reckon the application of this word as a name for the EaqaAr to be of the original language, but think it to be an innovation in speech; and I have heard it said that this is termed a DyEp because, when frequent attention to it is neglected, it perishes; and if it be so, this is an evidence of what we have said, that it is of the innovated speech: (O, TA:) the dim. is DuyayoEapN↓, for which one should not say DuwayoEapN: (S, O, K:) the pl. is DiyaAEN and DiyaEN, (S, O, Msb, K,) as though the latter were a contraction of the former, (Msb,) and DayoEaAtN: (K:) accord. to Lth, the first of these pls. signifies places of alighting or abode or settlement; which are thus called because, when the paying frequent attention to them, or taking good care of them, and the keeping them, or putting them, in a good state, or state of repair, is neglected, they come to nought: and DayoEaAtN occurs in a trad. as meaning the means of subsistence. (TA.) And, (T, O, Msb, K,) as used by the Arabs [of the desert], who know not the word in any other sense than this, (T, O,) A craft, or handicraft, by which one gains his subsistence; a mode, or manner, of gain; or any
habitual work or occupation of a man; (T, O, Msb, K) as the sewing of skins or boots and the like; and the twisting of ropes; and the weaving, or plaiting, of palm-leaves; and the culture of palm-trees (Eamalu AlnRaxoli); and the pasturing of camels; and the like thereof; (T, O;) including the sowing, or tilling, of land: (TA:) or the DayoEap of the Arabs was the management, or tending, of camels and of sheep and goats: and the term includes a man's craft, or handicraft, or means of gain: (Sh, O:) and his traffic: (Sh, O, K:) one says to a man, qumo UilaI DayoEatika [Arise to thy craft, &c.]: (Sh, O:) and kulRu rajulK waDayoEatahu, [Every man should occupy himself with his proper craft, &c.] (Msb.) OafoXaI QllRehu, DayoEatahu, occurring in a trad., means God made or may God make, his means of subsistence to be abundant. (TA.) And one says, faXato DayoEatuhu, [or, more commonly, faXato Ealayohi DayoEatuhu, as in the TA in art. fXw, &c.,] which is said to mean His property was, or became, large, or abundant, [or wide-spread,] so that he was unable to collect it together: and [hence] his means of attaining his object [or his affairs (as in the TA in art. fXw)] became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin: (TA:) or he took to doing an affair that did not concern him: (TA, and Ham p. 33:) it is nearly like the saying AitRasaEa Alxaroqu EalaI AlrRaAqiEi [expl. in art. xrq]. (Ham ibid.) And UinRiI laOaraI DayoEapF laA yuSoliHuhaA UilRaA DajoEapN [Verily I see property that nothing but a sleep will restore to a right state] a prov.; said by a pastor whose camels had dispersed themselves, and who, desiring to collect them together, and being unable to do so, sought aid of sleep. (O.)
maAta DiyEapF: see the next paragraph.

DayaAEN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, &c.) [Hence] one says, maAta DayaAEFA, as also DiyaEFA↓, and DiyoEFA↓, and DiyEapN↓, He (a man, TA) died unsought-after, or unminded, or unmissed. (K, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce DayoEapN.])

Also A family, or household: (ISh, O, K:) or the meaning is EiyaAlN DuyRaEN, (Mgh, O, K, *) i. e. a family, or household, neglected, untended, and unminded; (TA;) or such as are exposed, or liable, to perish, (biEaraDi Oano yaDiyEa,) as young children, and those who are crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, who cannot manage their own affairs: (Mgh:) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that when a man died leaving such as are thus termed, (taraka DayaAEFA,) they were to be brought to the Prophet, (Mgh, O,) to be maintained by means of the government-treasury: (Mgh:) a prefixed noun is to be understood [i. e. it is for EiyaAla DayaAEK or the like]: (Mgh:) or it is an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]: (Mgh, O:) or, accord. to one relation of the trad., the word is DayoEapF↓ [which is likewise an inf. n., and in this case to be expl. in the same manner]: (Mgh:) if read DiyaAEFA, it would be pl. of DaAYiEN. (Mgh, O.)
Also A sort of perfume, or odoriferous substance. (K.)
DuyayoEapN dim. of DayoEapN, q. v. (S, O, K.)

DaAYEN Perishing, coming to nought, passing away, or becoming lost: (Mgh, * Msb:) [and being left; left, or let, alone; or neglected:] part. n. of 1: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. DiyaAEN (Mgh, O, Msb, K) and DuyRaEN. (Mgh, O, * Msb, K. *) [See an ex. of the latter pl. in a verse cited voce daAna, in art. dyn. See also saAYiEN, in art. swE.]
And A man in a state of poverty: or having a family, or household, to sustain: or in a state of circumstances by means of which he is unable to subsist. (TA.)

fulaAnN yaOokulu fiI miEFI DaAYiEK means jaAYiEK [i. e. Such a one eats into a hungry, or an empty, gut]: and it was said to the daughters of ElKhuss, “ What is the sharpest thing? (maA OaHadRu XaIoC;) and she answered, naAbN jaAYiEN yuloqiI fiI miEFI DaAYiEK [A hungry canine tooth that throws the food into an empty gut]. (S.)
OaDoyaEu means Oakovaru DayaAEFA: so in the saying, fulaAnN OaDoyaEu mino fulaAnK [Such a one is in a more perishing state than such a one]. (TA.)
muDiyEN act. part. n. of the trans. v. ADAE. (TA.) [See misoyaAEN, in art. swE.]
And part. n. of the intrans. v. ADAE; as such signifying One whose estates (DiyaAEuhu) are becoming wide-spread, and many, or numerous. (S, TA.)

maDiyEapN and maDoyaEapN i. q. DayaAEN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]. (Mgh, O, Msb, K.) So in the saying, taraka EiyaAlahu bimaDiyEapK or bimaDoyaEapK [He left his family, or household, in a state of perishing, &c.]. (Mgh.) So too in the saying, AlsRaAriqu laA yuqoTaEu fiI maAlK bimaDiyEapK [The thief shall not suffer amputation of his hand in the case of his stealing property in a neglected state]. (Mgh.) And so in the saying, huwa bidaAri maDiyEapK (S, * O, K) and maDoyaEapK (O, K) [He is in a place (lit. an abode) of perdition, &c.]: or as meaning in this saying, abandonment, and ignominy. (TA.) And huwa muqiymN bidaAri maDiyEapK or maDoyaEapK means [He is dwelling in the abode of indolence; or] his characteristic in his affairs is indolence. (Msb.)

Also, [or perhaps the latter only, as meaning A cause of perishing &c., this latter being app. of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.,] A desert, or waterless desert, that is cut off [from inhabited regions]: or, as expl. by IJ, a place in which a man perishes, or is lost. (Msb.)
muDayRiEN: see what follows.
rajulN miDoyaAEN lilomaAli i. q. lahu muDayRiEN↓ [i. e. A man who wastes, or squanders, wealth, or property]. (S, O, K.)
1. DaAfa, (M, K,) [aor. yaDiyfu,] inf. n. DayofN; (TK;) and ADAf↓, (M,) and tDyRf↓, and DyRf↓; (K;) He, or it, inclined, (M, K,) and approached, or drew near; Uilayohi [to him, or it]. (M.)

And DAft AlXRamosu, (S, M, Mgh,) or DAft AlXms liloguruwbi, (O,) aor. taDiyfu, inf. n. DayofN; (M;) and tDyRft↓, (S, M, Mgh,) or tDyRft llgrwb; (O;) and DyRft↓, (S, M, Mgh,) DyRft llgrwb; (O;) The sun inclined, (S, Mgh, O,) or drew near, (M,) to setting. (S, M, Mgh, O.)
And DAft said of a woman, aor. as above, She menstruated; (O, K;) because she who does so inclines, or declines, from a state of pureness to menstruation. (O, TA.)

And DAf AlsRahomu, (M,) or DAf Alshm Eani Alhadafi, (S, O,) The arrow turned aside from the butt: (S, M, O:) like SAf. (S, O.) And DAf Eani AlXRaIoCi, inf. n. DawofN [and DayofN], He, or it, turned away from the thing: like SAf, inf. n. SawofN [and SayofN]. (M in art. Dwf.)

And DAf said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He feared; as also ADAf↓. (M.) And minohu ADAf↓ (assumed tropical:) He feared it, or was cautious of it; namely, an event, or affair; (S, M, O, K, TA;) as also DAf minohu: (TA:) or (tropical:) he was cautious of it with the caution of one encompassed, or beset, thereby. (Z, TA.)

Difotuhu, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor. OaDiyfuhu, (O, K,) inf. n. DiyaAfapN, (S,) or DayofN, (Msb,) or both; (M, O, K;) and taDayRafotuhu↓; (S, M, O, K;) I alighted at his abode; (M, Msb;) and inclined to him: (M:) or I alighted at his abode (S, M, O, Msb, K) as a Dayof [or guest], (S, O, K,) or and became his Dayof [or guest]. (M, O, Msb. [See also 3.]) And DAf Alqawoma, and taDayRafahumo↓, He alighted at the abode of the people, or party, as a Dayof [or guest]. (Mgh.) And taDayRafotuhu↓ I came to him as a Dayof [or guest]. (L, TA.)
[Hence,] DAfhu AlhamRu (assumed tropical:) Anxiety befell him. (S, M, * O. [See, again, 3.])

And Difotuhu signifies also I sought, or desired, of him entertainment as a Dayof [or guest]; and so taDayRafotuhu↓; (M;) or this latter, (L, Msb,) and AisotaDafotuhu↓, (M,) I asked of him such entertainment. (M, L, Msb.)
2. DyRf, intrans.: see 1, first and second sentences.
As trans.: see 4, last sentence, in four places.

[Hence,] DayRafotuhu signifies also (assumed tropical:) I protected him, or defended him, from him who sought, or pursued, him: (Msb:) (tropical:) I rendered him safe, secure, or free from fear; and became at peace with him; thus used metaphorically. (TA.)
3. DAyfhu [app. signifies He straitened him: (see 6:) or, perhaps, he became his guest; like DaAfahu, &c.].
[Hence one says,] DAyfhu AlhamRu (tropical:) [Anxiety straitened him: or, perhaps, befell him; like DaAfahu]. (TA.)
[And DAyfhu, inf. n. muDaAyafapN, signifies also It was, or became, correlative to it; as, for instance, fathership to sonship. See also the next paragraph.]
4. ADAf, intrans.: see 1, in three places.

Also, said of a man, He ran, and hastened, made haste, or sped, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) and fled, or
turned away and fled: (K:) and said of a dog as meaning he ran away, or fled. (TA in art. jbn.)
And ADAf EalaI AlXRaIoCi i. q. OaXorafa Ealayohi [He looked upon, or viewed, the thing from above: or he was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of the thing: &c.]. (O, K, * TA.)
tuDiyfu UilaI Sawoti AlfaHoli, said of a she-camel, means She hears with desire of going to him the voice, or sound, of the stallion. (M.)

And AlUiDaAfapu and AltRaDaAyufu↓ signify Correlation, or reciprocal relation, so that one of the two cannot be conceived in the mind without the other; as in the case of AlOubuwRapu and AlbunuwRapu [i. e. fathership and sonship]. (KT. [See also 3.])

ADAfhu Uilayohi He made it to incline towards it; (S, M, * O, Msb, K; *) namely, a thing (S, O) to a thing. (S, O, Msb.) He made it to lean, rest, or stay itself, against it, or upon it. (M, TA.) You say, ADAf Zahorahu UilaI AlHaAYiTi He leaned his back against the wall. (MA.) And ADAf Uilayohi OamorFA (tropical:) He rested, or stayed, upon him an affair, and desired him to do what would suffice. (TA.)
And He made him to have recourse to it, or to betake himself to it for refuge. (S, O, K.)
And He adjoined it to it. (Msb.)

And hence AlUiDaAfapu as a conventional term of the grammarians; because the first [of two nouns in the case to which it applies] is adjoined to the second: (Msb:) [for] UiDaAfapu AlAisomi UilaI AlAisomi is [The prefixing the noun to the noun so that the former governs the latter in the gen. case] as when you say gulaAmu zayodK; in which instance, glAm is termed muDaAfN↓, and zyd is termed Uilayohi muDaAfN↓: and this is done for the purpose of particularizing or appropriating, and of making known or definite: therefore the UiDaAfap of a thing to itself [i. e. the prefixing a noun in this manner to one identical therewith in meaning] is not allowable, because a thing does not make known, or definite, itself; (S;) unless by an ellipsis, as when you say HaqRu Alyaqiyni for HaqRu AlXRaIoCi Alyaqiyni; or, accord. to Fr, the Arabs used to do so because of the difference of the two words themselves. (S voce jaAmiEN.) [AlUiDaAfapu is also often used as meaning The state of being prefixed in the manner explained above; or the connection of a noun so prefixed with its complement. The various kinds of UiDaAfap are sufficiently explained in the grammars of De Sacy and others: they are not proper subjects of a lexicon, though much is said respecting them in the O, and more in the Msb.

Hence also, biAlUiDaAfapi UilaI kacaA meaning In comparison with (lit. to), or in relation to, (like biAlnRisobapi UilaI,) such a thing; as though in juxtaposition to it: a phrase of frequent occurrence: see an ex. in Bd ii. 6.]

OaDafotuhu (inf. n. UiDaAfapN, Msb) and DayRafotuhu↓ (inf. n. taDoyiyfN, O) both signify the same, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) from AlDRiyaAfapu; (O;) i. e. both signify I made him a guest, or lodged him, or gave him refuge or asylum, syn. Oanozalotuhu, (S, M, Msb,) with me, as a Dayof [or guest], (S,) and entertained him: (S, M, Msb:) OaDaAfuwhu and DayRafuwhu↓ both signify Oanozaluwhu: (Mgh:) accord. to Th, OaDafotuhu signifies I lodged him at my abode as a Dayof: and I gave him (i. e. one in fear) protection, or refuge or asylum: (Msb:) and DayRafotuhu↓ is also expl. as meaning I fed him: and DyRfhu↓ as meaning he made him to be in the condition of OaDoyaAf [or guests]. (TA.)
5: intrans.: see 1, first and second sentences.
taDayRufN signifies also The being collected together. (KL, from the Mj.)
And The being a taAbiE [or follower, &c.]. (Id.)
As trans.: see 1, latter half, in four places.
6: see 4.

tDAyf as said of a valley, [from DiyfN “ a side, ”] It became narrow; syn. taDaAyaqa. (S, M, O.) taDaAyafona Ealayohi, a phrase used by a poet [describing camels following an old camel], They became near to him, (S, M, O,) by his side. (S, M.) And you say, tDAyfhu Alqawomu The people, or party, became on both sides of him (biDiyfayohi). (TA.) And taDaAyfuh AlsRabuEaAni The two beasts of prey hemmed him in on both sides. (TA.) And taDaAyafati AlkilaAbu AlSRayoda and taDaAyafato Ealayohi [The dogs hemmed in the object of the chase on both sides, or round about]. (TA.) [In the TA, all these are said to be tropical; but why, I see not.]
7. AnDAf Uilayohi signifies He, or it, became joined, or adjoined, or added, to him, or it: and he joined himself to him: but is perhaps postclassical.]
10: see 1, last sentence.

You say also AisotaDaAfaniI, meaning He desired me, or asked me, to grant him protection, or refuge. (Msb.) And AstDAf fulaAnN UilaI fulaAnK Such a one had recourse, or betook himself, to such a one for protection, or refuge. (IAar, M.)

DayofN A guest: and guests: (MA:) so called because adjoined to the family and fed with them: (Ham p. 124:) it is applied to one, and to a pl. number, (S, M, MA, O, Msb, K,) and to a male and to a female, (S, O, Msb, K,) because it is originally an inf. n.: (MA, Msb:) [as a sing.,] i. q. muDayRafN↓, (M,) which is syn. with naziylN: (TA:) and applied to a pl. number, it may be pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of DaAYifN↓, which is syn. with naAzilN; thus being of the class of zawozN and SawomN: (M:) and it is also pluralized, having for its pls. OaDoyaAfN and DiyfaAnN (S, M, MA, O, Msb, K) and DuyuwfN (S, M, MA, O, K) and DiyaAfN, (MA, TA,) the first of which is properly a pl. of pauc., but is also used as a pl. of mult.: (M:) and a female is termed DayofapN as well as DayofN: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) El-Ba'eeth says,
[A castaway with whom his mother became pregnant while she was a guest]: (S, M, O:) or, accord. to AHeyth, the meaning here is that which follows. (O.)
DayofapN applied to a woman signifies also Menstruating: (O, K:) so says AHeyth with reference to the citation above from El-Ba'eeth. (O.)

DiyfN The side (T, S, M, O, K) of a valley (T, M) and of a mountain (M) [&c.: see 6]: and, as metaphorically used by an anonymous poet, of the cakar: (M:) and maDaAyifu↓ signifies the sides of a valley. (TA.)
And one says, fulaAnN fiI Diyfi fulaAnK, meaning Such a one is in the vicinage, or quarter, of such a one. (M.)

DayofanN One who comes with a guest: (S, O:) or who so comes intruding without invitation: (K:) or one who follows a guest: derived from DayofN, accord. to Sb; but said by AZ to belong to art. Dfn: (M:) [accord. to J and Sgh] the n is augmentative: the pl. is DayaAfinu. (S, O.)
DiyaAfapN an inf. n. of Difotuhu in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above. (S, M, O, K.)

[And] a subst. from OaDafotuhu and DayRafotuhu [as such signifying The entertainment of a guest or guests; i. e. the act of entertaining: and an entertainment as meaning a repast, given to a guest or guests; a banquet, or feast]. (Msb.) [Hence, daAru AlDRiyaAfapi The house of entertainment of guests.]
DaAYifN A man alighting as a guest; syn. naAzilN: (M, TA:) see DayofN: its [proper] pl. is DuyRafN. (TA.)
muDaAfN; and muDaAfN Uilayohi: see 4.

The former signifies also (tropical:) One who is made an adjunct, or adherent, to a people, or party, (S, M, O, K, TA,) and made to incline to them, (M,) not being of them. (M, TA.) One says, maA huwa UilRaA muDaAfN (tropical:) [He is none other than an adjunct, or adherent]. (TA.)

And (tropical:) One whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected; or who makes a claim to relationship not having it: (O, K, TA:) and (K) whose origin, or relationship, is referred to a people, or party, of whom he is not a member. (O, K, TA.)
And One who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge, (M, O, K, TA,) to a narrow, or confined, place, and who is burdened with evil: (TA:) El-Bureyk ElHudhalee says,

[And he protects him who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge, when he calls for aid]. (M.) And musotaDaAfN↓ signifies the same as muDaAfN [app. in the last of the senses expl. above]: so says IB; and he cites the saying of Jowwás Ibn-Heiyán El-Azdee,
[app. meaning And verily I advance boldly in the case of fear, and I protect him who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge]. (TA.) [See also maDuwfN.]

Also One who is beset, hemmed in, or encompassed, in war, or battle: (S, O, K: said in the TA to be tropical:) or one falling among the horsemen and men of valour, having in him no strength. (M.) [See, again, maDuwfN.]
And One in a state of fear. (TA.)

maDuwfN Beset by distress of mind: (TA:) [accord. to Freytag, as from the Deewán of the
Hudhalees, constrained to seek refuge: (see also muDaAfN:)] it occurs in the saying of the Hudhalee,
[Thou answerest the prayer, or call, of him who is beset &c.]; and is formed after the manner of buwEa for biyEa. (M, TA.)

maDiyfN a dial. var. of maSiyfN [q. v.]. (TA.) [ISd says that] maDiyfFA occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb [as some relate it], cited voce karabapN, [where the reading of maSiyfFA is given,] is for DaAYifFA, meaning Turning aside; crooked. (M.)
muDiyfN Fleeing; or turning away and fleeing. (Ibn-'Abbád, O. [See also its verb.])
muDaAfapN Hardship, or difficulty, or distress. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

maDuwfapN, an anomalous word, by rule maDiyfapN, (Kh, Sb, TA in art. Dwf,) Anxiety; and want, or a want; (O and K in that art.;) and maDiyfapN↓ and muDiyfapN↓ signify the same; (O in that art. and in art. Dyf;) or these two signify anxiety, and grief: (K in this art.:) or maDuwfapN signifies an affair, or event, that is feared, or of which one is cautious; (S and M in this art.;) thus accord. to As; and maDiyfapN↓ and muDaAfapN↓ signify the same. (S, L, TA.)
maDiyfapN and muDiyfapN: see both in the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
maDoyafapN, of the measure mafoEalapN, A place of DiyaAfap [i. e. entertainment of a guest or guests: pl. maDaAyifu]. (TA.)
muDayRafN: see DayfN.
muDayRifN The master of an abode in which guests are entertained; as also maDaAyifiIRN↓. (TA.)
miDoyaAfN [One who often entertains guests]. (Har p. 579.)
maDaAyifu [pl. of maDoyafapN:
and also of a sing. not mentioned]: see DiyfN.
maDaAyifiIRN [from maDaAyifu pl. of maDoyafapN]: see muDayRifN.

UisomaMCN mutaDaAyifapN Correlative nouns; i. e. nouns significant of the existence of persons, or things, whereof the existence of one necessarily indicates the existence of another; as OabN and AibonN [father and son]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
musotaDaAfN: see muDaAfN.
musotaDiyfN [act. part. n. of 10, q. v.:] Asking, or calling, for aid, or succour. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

1. DaAqa, aor. yaDiyqu, inf. n. DayoqN (S, O, Msb, K) and DiyqN, (S, O, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) It was, or became, narrow, or strait; contr. of AitRasaEa; (Msb, K;) as also tDyRq↓, [or rather this signifies it was, or became, rendered narrow, or strait, being quasipass. of 2,] and tDAyq↓: (K:) it is said of a thing, (S, O, Msb,) and of a place. (Msb.) [See also DayoqN below.] DaAqato Ealayohimu QloOaroDu, in the Kur ix. 119, means The earth became strait to them. (Bd, Jel.) And one says, DaAqato bihi AlOaroDu [meaning, in like manner, The earth, or land, became narrow, or strait, with him]: 'Amr Ibn-El-Ahtam says,

[By thy life, or by thy religion, countries have not become narrow with their inhabitants, but the dispositions of the men become narrow]. (O, TA.) [DAq bihi often signifies, and so does bh tDAyq↓, It was, or became, choked, surcharged, or overfilled, with it; for instance, a water-course with water, and a place with people.] And tDAyq↓ bihi AlOamoru means DAq Ealayohi (tropical:) [The affair was, or became, strait to him]. (O, TA. [See an ex. in art. rHb, conj. 6.]) One says also, DAq Ealayohi maEaAXuhu: see 4. [And DAq Alwaqotu (assumed tropical:) The time became strait, or contracted.] And DAq Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom, or mind, became strait, or contracted: (Msb:) and DAq Eanohu Sadoruka (assumed tropical:) [Thy mind became so contracted as to be incapable of it: or thy mind shrank from it]. (K.) [And yaDiyqu AlEaqolu Eano taqodiyrihi (assumed tropical:) The intellect is incapable of determining its limit, or limits, or the like.] And DAq Eani AljawaAbi and biAljawaAbi (assumed tropical:) [He was straitened, or embarrassed, so as to be unable to reply, or to answer; he was incapable of replying, or answering]: both signify the same. (TA in art. znd.) And DAq bAlOamori caroEFA, (S, * O, * Msb,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The thing, or affair, was difficult, or distressing, to him, (Msb,) originally DAq caroEuhu bihi, (S, * O, * Msb,) i. e. his ability [was straitened by it, or was inadequate to it]; and his power: (Msb:) or his art, or artifice, or cunning: or his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting (macohabuhu) [was straitened, or rendered difficult, or distressing, by it]. (O. [See more voce caroEN: and see a similar phrase in the Kur xi. 79 and xxix. 32.]) And hence, app., the saying DAq AlmaAlu Eani AldRuyuwni (tropical:) The property was inadequate to the debts. (Msb.) And you say, DAq Eanoka AlXRaIoCu [meaning lamo yasaEoka (assumed tropical:) The thing was not allowable to thee]: one says, laA yasaEuniI XaIoCN wayaDiyqa Eanoka, (S, O, * TA, [in the O, erroneously, lA ystgnI,]) i. e. waOano yaDiyqa Eanoka (assumed tropical:) [A thing will not be allowable to me conjointly with its being disallowable to thee, waOano yaDiyqN meaning maEa Dayoqihi]: balo mataI wasiEaniI XaIoCN wasiEaka [but when a thing is allowable to me, it is allowable to thee]. (S in art. wsE.) And DAq, (aor. yaDiayqu, K, inf. n. DiyqN, TA,) (tropical:) He was or became, niggardly, or avaricious. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.)

2. DyRqhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. taDoyiyqN, (Msb, TA,) He made it strait, or narrow; (Msb, K;) namely, a place [&c.]; (Msb;) as also ADAqhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UiDaAqapN. (TA.) You say, DayRaqotu Ealayohi AlmakaAna, (S,) or AlXRaIoCa, i. e. I straitened, or made narrow, to him [the place, or the thing; or I scanted it, or made it scanty]; contr. of wasRaEotuhu Ealayohi. (O.) And DayRaqotu Ealayohi [alone, used elliptically, I straitened him, properly speaking; and also, (assumed tropical:) his circumstances &c.]. (Msb.) And DuyRiqa EalaI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was straitened]. (TA.) lituDayRiquwA EalayohinRa, in the Kur [lxv. 6, (assumed tropical:) In order that ye may straiten them], implies relation to expenses and to the bosom. (TA.) [See 3. AltRaDoyiyqu bayona XayoYayoni, occurring in the S and K in art. HwS, means The making a coarctation between two things.]

3. DAyqhu He straitened him: (MA:) [see also 2: or, properly, he straitened him, being in like manner straitened by him: see 1 in art. zHm: and] (tropical:) he treated him, or behaved towards him, with hardness, or harshness; (O, * K, * TA;) fiI kacaA [in, or in respect of, such a thing]. (TA.)
4. ADAq (tropical:) His means of living became strait (Ealayoih maEaAXuhu DaAqa↓); (TA;) his property went away; (S, O, Msb, K;) and he became poor. (TA.)
See also 2.
5: see 1, first sentence.

6: see 1, in three places. tDAyqwA They straitened one another; pushed, or pressed, one against another; or crowded one another; in a place of assembly; syn. zaHama baEoDuhumo baEoDFA: (Msb in art. zHm:) or they became straitened in a place, or (assumed tropical:) in disposition. (S, O.)
10. AstDAqt bidurojapK [She endeavoured to constrict her vagina by means of a pessary], (O, K, TA,) or biAlOadowiyapi [by means of medicaments]; (A, TA;) said of a woman. (A, O, K.)

DayoqN an inf. n. of 1, (S, O, Msb, K,) as also DiyqN↓, (S, O, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.: (Msb:) [both, used as simple substs., signify Narrowness, or straitness:] accord. to Fr, [both seem to signify thus; but the latter, properly; and the former, tropically; for he says that] AlDRayoqu is in that which does not [really] become wide, like the mind (AlSRador): (O:) or it is maA DaAqa Eanohu Sadoruka [that of which the mind by its being contracted is incapable, or from which the mind shrinks; an explanation not given in the K as on the authority of Fr, and deviating from his words as given in the O; whence it appears that, for maA, we should perhaps read fiymaA]: (K:) but AlDRiyqu↓ is in that which may be [really] wide, like the house and the garment: (O, K:) and the former [is also used as an epithet, being a contraction of DayRiqN in this case, and as such] has a dual and a plural and a feminine; but the latter has not: (O:) or ↓both are alike [in signification]: (K:) and DayoqapN↓ is syn. with DiyqN. (S.)

Also, and DayaqN↓, accord. to AA, (O, [the latter there expressly said to be biAltRaHoriyki,]) or the former and DiyqN↓, (K, [said in the TA to
be a mistake for DayaqN, but see what follows,]) Doubt (AA, O, K) in the heart: (K) the first is more common than the second, in this sense; and occurs in the Kur in xvi. last verse and xxvii. 72: (O:) [but] Ibn-Ketheer read, in both of these instances, Diyq↓; and this and Dayoq are dial. vars. signifying straitness of mind. (Bd.)
See also DayRiqN, in two places:
and DayoqapN, second sentence, in two places.
DiyqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
DayaqN: see DayoqN, latter part.
DayoqapN: see DayoqN, latter part.

Also (S) (tropical:) Poverty; and an evil state or condition; (S, O, K, TA;) and so DiyqapN↓: (K, TA:) and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] (Fr, S, K, TA) of the former (Fr, S, TA) is DayoqN↓: (Fr, S, K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, DiyqN:]) Fr says, when you see AlDRayoq↓ to have occurred in the place of AlDRiyq, it is in [one of] two cases; either it is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of AlDRayoqapu; or it means the narrow, or strait, thing, DayoqN being a contraction of DayRiqN. (TA.)

And AlDRayoqapu, (O,) or Dayoqapu [without the article], (JK, O, TA,) or AlDRiyqapu↓, (K, [app. a mistake, for in the O, in every case, whether as a proper name or not, AlDyqp is written AlDRayoqapu,]) is the name of A certain mansion of the moon, (JK, O, K, TA,) [not one of the Twentyeight Mansions,] close by AlvRurayRaA [or the Pleiades]: (JK, O, TA:) or, as IKt says, on the authority of Ibn-Ziyád El-Kilábee, sometimes the moon falls short of AldRabaraAn and alights in AlDyqp, i. e. two small stars, near together, between AlvRurayRaA and AldRaAbaraAn: (TA:) it is asserted by the Arabs to be an inauspicious place. (O, * TA.) Hence the saying of El-Akhtal,

[And wherefore didst not thou draw an omen from the flight of birds on the night when thou camest to her, when the moon was in Deykah, between the Pleiades and Ed-Debarán?]: he notifies that the moon, in the night of their coming together, was making its abode [in the neighbourhood of] AldbrAn, which is inauspicious: (O, TA:) or [the latter hemistich, as J relates it, app. on the authority of A 'Obeyd, is thus,]
